-phobia.definition: A combining form used as a suffix to designate specific phobias, such as agoraphobia (fear of public places), acrophobia (fear of heights).  The first part of the combining form is usually derived from Greek

-phore.definition: Combining form meaning bearer of the element preceding; as, ionophore; semaphore

-plastic.definition: A combining form signifying developing, forming, growing; as, heteroplastic, monoplastic, polyplastic

-plasty.definition: A combining form denoting the act or process of forming, development, growth; as, autoplasty, perineoplasty

-pod.definition: A combining form or suffix from Gr. poy`s, podo`s, foot; as, decapod, an animal having ten feet; phyllopod, an animal having leaflike feet; myriapod, hexapod

-poda.definition: A New Latin plural combining form or suffix from Gr. &unr_;, &unr_;, foot; as, hexapoda, myriapoda. See -pod

p.definition: the sixteenth letter of the English alphabet, is a nonvocal consonant whose form and value come from the Latin, into which language the letter was brought, through the ancient Greek, from the Phœnician, its probable origin being Egyptian.  Etymologically P is most closely related to b, f, and v; as hobble, hopple; father, paternal; recipient, receive. See B, F, and M

paage.definition: A toll for passage over another person's grounds

pablum.definition: A form of cereal for infants
A diet that does not require chewing
synonyms: Syn. -- soft diet, pap, spoon food.

pabular.definition: Of, pertaining to, or fit for, pabulum or food; affording food

pabulation.definition: The act of feeding, or providing food

pabulum.definition: The means of nutriment to animals or plants; food; nourishment
synonyms: Syn. -- comestible, edible, eatable, victual, victuals.

pabulum.definition: That which feeds or sustains, such as fuel for a fire
synonyms: Syn. -- food for thought, intellectual nourishment.

pabulum.definition: Trite or simplistic writing, sentiments, etc.; pablum{3}

pac.definition: A political action committee, a committee formed by an organization or special-interest group to raise money to support candidates for office or to influence legislation.  A PAC provides a legal means for corporations in the U. S. to support political candidates even when direct contributions from corporations to candidates is forbidden by law.  In theory, the corporation may not itself contribute to a PAC, but may pay the expenses of raising money from individuals.  PACs may also be formed by organizations other than commercial corporations, such as trade associations
A kind of moccasin, having the edges of the sole turned up and sewed to the upper

paca.definition: A large burrowing South American rodent (Agouti paca syn. Cuniculus paca, formerly Cœlogenys paca), having blackish brown fur, with four parallel rows of white spots along its sides; the spotted cavy.  It is closely allied to the agouti and the Guinea pig and is highly esteemed as food

pacane.definition: A species of hickory. See Pecan

pacation.definition: The act of pacifying; a peacemaking

pace.definition: A single movement from one foot to the other in walking; a step
The length of a step in walking or marching, reckoned from the heel of one foot to the heel of the other; -- used as a unit in measuring distances; as, he advanced fifty paces
Manner of stepping or moving; gait; walk; as, the walk, trot, canter, gallop, and amble are paces of the horse; a swaggering pace; a quick pace
Specifically, a kind of fast amble; a rack
Any single movement, step, or procedure
A broad step or platform; any part of a floor slightly raised above the rest, as around an altar, or at the upper end of a hall
A device in a loom, to maintain tension on the warp in pacing the web
The rate of progress of any process or activity; as, the students ran at a rapid pace; the plants grew at a remarkable pace
To go; to walk; specifically, to move with regular or measured steps
To move quickly by lifting the legs on the same side together, as a horse; to amble with rapidity; to rack
To walk over with measured tread; to move slowly over or upon; as, the guard paces his round
To measure by steps or paces; as, to pace a piece of ground.  Often used with out; as, to pace out the distance
To develop, guide, or control the pace or paces of; to teach the pace; to break in

paced.definition: Having, or trained in, [such] a pace or gait; trained; -- used in composition; as, slow-paced; a thorough-paced villain

pacemaker.definition: a specialized bit of heart tissue that controls the heartbeat
An implanted electronic device that takes over the function of the natural cardiac pacemaker{1}; -- used to assist people whose heartbeat is irregular
A horse used to set the pace in racing

pacer.definition: One who, or that which, paces
A horse trained to a special gait in which both feet on one side leave the ground together; a horse that paces
A horse used to set the pace in racing

pacesetter.definition: A horse used to set the pace in racing

pacha.definition: A civil or military authority in Turkey or Egypt; same as Pasha

pachacamac.definition: A divinity worshiped by the ancient Peruvians as the creator of the universe

pachak.definition: The fragrant roots of the Saussurea Costus, exported from India to China, and used for burning as incense.  It is supposed to be the costus of the ancients

pachinko.definition: A popular Japanese pinball game played on a vertical board

pachisi.definition: A game, somewhat resembling backgammon, originating in India
A game adopted from the Indian game, using disks, as of pasteboard, and dice; it is played on a cross-shaped board

pachometer.definition: An instrument for measuring thickness, as of the glass of a mirror, or of paper; a pachymeter

pachonta.definition: A substance resembling gutta-percha, and used to adulterate it, obtained from the East Indian tree Isonandra acuminata

pachouli.definition: A small East Indian shrubby mint (Pogostemon cablin); a fragrant oil from its leaves is used in perfumes

pachuca tank.definition: A high and narrow tank, with a central cylinder for the introduction of compressed air, used in the agitation and settling of pulp (pulverized ore and water) during treatment by the cyanide process; -- so named because, though originally devised in New Zealand, it was first practically introduced in Pachuca, Mexico

pachy-.definition: A combining form meaning thick; as, pachyderm, pachydactyl

pachycephala.definition: A genus of arborial insectivorous birds

pachydactyl.definition: A bird or other animal having thick toes

pachyderm.definition: Any of various nonruminant hoofed mammals having very thick skin, including the elephant, rhinoceros, and hippopotamus, one of the Pachydermata

pachyderma.definition: An abnormal thickening of the skin (usually unilateral on an extremity) caused by congenital enlargement of lymph vessel and lymph vessel obstruction

pachydermal.definition: Of or relating to the pachyderms; as, pachydermal dentition

pachydermata.definition: A group of hoofed mammals distinguished for the thickness of their skins, including the elephant, hippopotamus, rhinoceros, tapir, horse, and hog; the pachyderms.  It is now considered an artificial group

pachydermatous.definition: Of or pertaining to the pachyderms

pachyglossal.definition: Having a thick tongue; -- applied to a group of lizards (Pachyglossæ), including the iguanas and agamas

pachyglossia.definition: The condition of having an enlarged thick tongue

pachymeningitis.definition: Inflammation of the dura mater or outer membrane of the brain

pachyote.definition: One of a family of bats, including those which have thick external ears

pachyrhizus.definition: A small genus of tropical vines having tuberous roots

pachysandra.definition: Any plant of the genus Pachysandra; they are low-growing evergreen herbs or subshrubs having dentate leaves and used as ground cover

pachytene.definition: The third stage of the prophase of meiosis, the stage in which the pairing of homologous chromosomes has been completed

pacifiable.definition: Capable of being pacified or appeased; placable

pacific.definition: Of or pertaining to peace; of a peaceful character; not warlike; not quarrelsome; as, a pacific nature or condition
Promoting peace; suited to make or restore peace; conciliatory; as, pacific words or acts
of or pertaining to the Pacific Ocean; as, Pacific islands
The Pacific Ocean, the largest ocean

pacifical.definition: Of or pertaining to peace; pacific

pacification.definition: The act or process of pacifying, or of making peace between parties at variance; reconciliation

pacificator.definition: One who, or that which, pacifies; a peacemaker

pacifico.definition: A peaceful person; -- applied specif. by the Spaniards to the natives in Cuba and the Philippine Islands who did not oppose the Spanish arms

pacifier.definition: One who or that which pacifies
A small device, usually of rubber or plastic containing a protruding nipple-shaped portion which a baby may place in its mouth and suck on; -- it is used to keep babies contented

pacifism.definition: the doctrine that all violence is unjustifiable
The belief that all international disputes can be settled by arbitration

pacifist.definition: A person opposed to violence as a means of settling disputes
A person whose strong belief in pacifism causes him/her to refuse to participate in military activities, especially one who refuses to be drafted into the armed forces
Adhering to pacifism; opposed to war; -- of people

pacify.definition: To make to be at peace; to appease; to calm; to still; to quiet; to allay the agitation, excitement, or resentment of; to tranquillize; as, to pacify a man when angry; to pacify pride, appetite, or importunity
synonyms: Syn. -- lenify, assuage, appease, mollify, placate, gentle, gruntle.

pacing.definition: the speed at which a composition is to be played

pacinian.definition: Of, pertaining to, or discovered by, Filippo Pacini (1812-1883), an Italian physician of the 19th century

pack.definition: A pact
A bundle made up and prepared to be carried; especially, a bundle to be carried on the back; a load for an animal; a bale, as of goods
A number or quantity equal to the contents of a pack; hence, a multitude; a burden
A group or quantity of connected or similar things; as, a pack of lies
A large area of floating pieces of ice driven together more or less closely
An envelope, or wrapping, of sheets used in hydropathic practice, called dry pack, wet pack, cold pack, etc., according to the method of treatment
A loose, lewd, or worthless person. See Baggage

In hydropathic practice, a wrapping of blankets or sheets called dry pack, wet pack, cold pack, etc., according to the condition of the blankets or sheets used, put about a patient to give him treatment; also, the fact or condition of being so treated
The forwards who compose one half of the scrummage; also, the scrummage
To make a pack of; to arrange closely and securely in a pack; hence, to place and arrange compactly as in a pack; to press into close order or narrow compass; as, to pack goods in a box; to pack fish

To fill in the manner of a pack, that is, compactly and securely, as for transportation; hence, to fill closely or to repletion; to stow away within; to cause to be full; to crowd into; as, to pack a trunk; the play, or the audience, packs the theater
To shuffle, sort and arrange (the cards) in a pack so as to secure the game unfairly; to stack{3} (the deck)
To bring together or make up unfairly and fraudulently, in order to secure a certain result; to stack{3}; as, to pack a jury or a caucus
To contrive unfairly or fraudulently; to plot
To load with a pack; hence, to load; to encumber; as, to pack a horse
To cause to go; to send away with baggage or belongings; esp., to send away peremptorily or suddenly; to send packing; -- sometimes with off; as, to pack a boy off to school
To transport in a pack, or in the manner of a pack (i. e., on the backs of men or beasts)
To envelop in a wet or dry sheet, within numerous coverings. See Pack, n., 5

To render impervious, as by filling or surrounding with suitable material, or to fit or adjust so as to move without giving passage to air, water, or steam; as, to pack a joint; to pack the piston of a steam engine
To cover, envelop, or protect tightly with something
To make up packs, bales, or bundles; to stow articles securely for transportation
To admit of stowage, or of making up for transportation or storage; to become compressed or to settle together, so as to form a compact mass; as, the goods pack conveniently; wet snow packs well
To gather in flocks or schools; as, the grouse or the perch begin to pack
To depart in haste; -- generally with off or away
To unite in bad measures; to confederate for ill purposes; to join in collusion

package.definition: A bundle made up for transportation; a packet; a bale; a parcel; as, a package of goods
A charge made for packing goods
A duty formerly charged in the port of London on goods imported or exported by aliens, or by denizens who were the sons of aliens

packaged.definition: Enclosed in a package{2} or protective covering; as, packaged cereals

packed.definition: Crowded; as, the theater was packed

packer.definition: A person whose business is to pack things; especially, one who packs food for preservation or for the market; as, a pork packer
A ring of packing or a special device to render gas-tight and water-tight the space between the tubing and bore of an oil well

packera.definition: A genus of American or East Asian perennial herbs with yellow to orange or red flower rays; it is sometimes included in genus Senecio

packet.definition: A small pack or package; a little bundle or parcel; as, a packet of letters

Originally, a vessel employed by government to convey dispatches or mails; hence, a vessel employed in conveying dispatches, mails, passengers, and goods, and having fixed days of sailing; a mail boat
To make up into a packet or bundle
To send in a packet or dispatch vessel
To ply with a packet or dispatch boat

packfong.definition: A Chinese alloy of nickel, zinc, and copper, resembling German silver

packing.definition: The act or process of one who packs
Any material used to pack, fill up, or make close

packinghouse.definition: A place where foodstuffs are processed and packed; as, they came from an apple packinghouse
A plant where livestock are slaughtered and processed and packed as meat products

packman.definition: One who bears a pack; a peddler

packrat.definition: Any of several bushy-tailed rodents of the genus Neotoma of western North America, especially Neotoma cinerea, which hoard food and other objects in their nests
synonyms: Syn. -- trade rat, bushytail woodrat, Neotoma cinerea.

packrat.definition: A person who habitually saves items, even those unlikely to be useful

packsaddle.definition: A saddle to which loads can be attached

packthread.definition: A strong three-ply thread or small twine used to sew or tie packs or packages

packway.definition: A path, as over mountains, followed by pack animals

paco.definition: An earthy-looking ore, consisting of brown oxide of iron with minute particles of native silver

pact.definition: An agreement; a league; a compact; a covenant

paction.definition: An agreement; a compact; a bargain

pactional.definition: Of the nature of, or by means of, a paction

pactitious.definition: Setted by a pact, or agreement

pactolian.definition: Pertaining to the Pactolus, a river in ancient Lydia famous for its golden sands

pacu.definition: A South American fresh-water fish (Myletes pacu), of the family Characinidæ. It is highly esteemed as food

pad.definition: A footpath; a road
An easy-paced horse; a padnag
A robber that infests the road on foot; a highwayman; -- usually called a footpad
The act of robbing on the highway
To travel upon foot; to tread
To travel heavily or slowly
To rob on foot
To wear a path by walking
A soft, or small, cushion; a mass of anything soft; stuffing
A kind of cushion for writing upon, or for blotting; esp., one formed of many flat sheets of writing paper, or layers of blotting paper; a block of paper
A cushion used as a saddle without a tree or frame
A stuffed guard or protection; esp., one worn on the legs of horses to prevent bruising
A cushionlike thickening of the skin one the under side of the toes of animals
A floating leaf of a water lily or similar plant
A soft bag or cushion to relieve pressure, support a part, etc
A piece of timber fixed on a beam to fit the curve of the deck
A measure for fish; as, sixty mackerel go to a pad; a basket of soles
A dwelling place, usually an apartment; one's living quarters; as, come over to my pad to watch the game
A sum of money paid as a bribe to police officers, shared among them
To stuff; to furnish with a pad or padding
To imbue uniformly with a mordant; as, to pad cloth

pad elephant.definition: An elephant that is furnished with a pad for carrying burdens instead of with a howdah for carrying passengers

padder.definition: One who, or that which, pads

padding.definition: The act or process of making a pad or of inserting stuffing
The material with which anything is padded
Material of inferior value, serving to extend a book, essay, etc
The uniform impregnation of cloth with a mordant

paddle.definition: To use the hands or fingers in toying; to make caressing strokes
To dabble in water with hands or feet; to use a paddle, or something which serves as a paddle, in swimming, in paddling a boat, etc
To pat or stroke amorously, or gently
To propel with, or as with, a paddle or paddles
To pad; to tread upon; to trample
To spank with a paddle or as if with a paddle; -- usually as a disciplinary punishment of children
To mix (a viscous liquid) by stirring or beating with a paddle
An implement with a broad blade, which is used without a fixed fulcrum in propelling and steering canoes and boats
The broad part of a paddle, with which the stroke is made
One of the broad boards, or floats, at the circumference of a water wheel, or paddle wheel
A small gate in sluices or lock gates to admit or let off water; -- also called clough
A paddle-shaped foot, as of the sea turtle
A paddle-shaped implement for stirring or mixing

paddlebox.definition: a wooden covering for the upper part of the paddle wheel of a steam vessel

paddlefish.definition: A large ganoid fish (Polyodon spathula) found in the rivers of the Mississippi Valley.  It has a long spatula-shaped snout.  Called also duck-billed cat, and spoonbill sturgeon

paddler.definition: One who, or that which, paddles

paddlewood.definition: The light elastic wood of the Aspidosperma excelsum, a tree of Guiana having a fluted trunk readily split into planks

paddock.definition: A small inclosure or park for sporting
A small inclosure for pasture; esp., one adjoining a stable
An enclosure used for saddling and mounting horses prior to a race

paddy.definition: A jocose or contemptuous name for an Irishman; -- usually considered offensive
Unhusked rice; -- commonly so called in the East Indies

paddy wagon.definition: An enclosed truck used by police to transport prisoners

paddymelon.definition: Any of several small reddish-brown wallabies of scrubby areas of Australia and New Guinea, especially those belonging to the genus Thylogale

padelion.definition: A plant with pedately lobed leaves; the lady's mantle

padella.definition: A large cup or deep saucer, containing fatty matter in which a wick is placed, -- used for public illuminations, as at St. Peter's, in Rome.  Called also padelle

pademelon.definition: Any of several small reddish-brown wallabies of scrubby areas of Australia and New Guinea, especially those belonging to the genus Thylogale; a paddymelon.  See Wallaby

padge.definition: The barn owl; -- called also pudge, and pudge owl

padishah.definition: Chief ruler; monarch; sovereign; -- a title of the Sultan of Turkey, and of the Shah of Persia

padlock.definition: A portable lock with a bow which is usually jointed or pivoted at one end so that it can be opened, the other end being fastened by the bolt, -- used for fastening by passing the bow through a staple over a hasp or through the links of a chain, etc
To fasten with, or as with, a padlock; to stop; to shut; to confine as by a padlock

padre.definition: A Christian priest or monk; used as a term of address for priests in some churches (especially Roman or Orthodox Catholic in Italy, Spain, Portugal, and Spanish America); -- also used in the American military
In India (from the Portuguese), any Christian minister; also, a priest of the native region
A chaplain in one of the military services
synonyms: Syn. -- military chaplain, Holy Joe, sky pilot.

padrone.definition: The master of a small coaster in the Mediterranean
A man who imports, and controls the earnings of, Italian laborers, street musicians, etc

paduasoy.definition: A rich and heavy silk stuff

paean.definition: An ancient Greek hymn in honor of Apollo as a healing deity, and, later, a song addressed to other deities
Any loud and joyous song; a song of triumph, joy, or praise

paedogenesis.definition: Reproduction by young or larval animals

paedogenetic.definition: Producing young while in the immature or larval state; -- said of certain insects, etc

paeon.definition: A foot of four syllables, one long and three short, admitting of four combinations, according to the place of the long syllable

paeoniaceae.definition: A natural family of perennial rhizomatous herbs and shrubs, native to temperate Europe and North America

paeonine.definition: An artifical red nitrogenous dyestuff, called also red coralline

paeony.definition: Any of numerous plants widely cultivated for their showy single or double red or pink or white flowers; the Peony

pagan.definition: One who worships false gods; an idolater; a heathen; one who is neither a Christian, a Mohammedan, nor a Jew
Of or pertaining to pagans; relating to the worship or the worshipers of false goods; heathen; idolatrous, as, pagan tribes or superstitions

pagandom.definition: The pagan lands; pagans, collectively; paganism

paganic.definition: Of or pertaining to pagans or paganism; heathenish; paganish

paganish.definition: Of or pertaining to pagans; heathenish

paganism.definition: The state of being pagan; pagan characteristics; esp., the worship of idols or false gods, or the system of religious opinions and worship maintained by pagans; heathenism

paganity.definition: The state of being a pagan; paganism

paganize.definition: To render pagan or heathenish; to convert to paganism

page.definition: A serving boy; formerly, a youth attending a person of high degree, especially at courts, as a position of honor and education; now commonly, in England, a youth employed for doing errands, waiting on the door, and similar service in households; in the United States, a boy or girl employed to wait upon the members of a legislative body.  Prior to 1960 only boys served as pages in the United States Congress
A contrivance, as a band, pin, snap, or the like, to hold the skirt of a woman's dress from the ground
A track along which pallets carrying newly molded bricks are conveyed to the hack
Any one of several species of beautiful South American moths of the genus Urania
To call out a person's name in a public place, so as to deliver a message, as in a hospital, restaurant, etc
To call a person on a pager
One side of a leaf of a book or manuscript
A record; a writing; as, the page of history
The type set up for printing a page
To mark or number the pages of, as a book or manuscript; to furnish with folios

pageant.definition: An elaborate exhibition devised for the entertainmeut of a distinguished personage, or of the public; a show, spectacle, or display
Of the nature of a pageant; spectacular
To exhibit in show; to represent; to mimic

pageantry.definition: Scenic shows or spectacles, taken collectively; spectacular quality; splendor

pagehood.definition: The state of being a page

pager.definition: A small electronic communication device which signals when a telephone call has been received at a base station.  Each such device receives radio signals from the base station specifically coded for the individual to whom it is registered; the signal given by the device to the registered user may be a beeping sound, indicating that the user should call the base station to receive a message; or it may display a telephone number to which the user may call directly to return the incoming call, or may display a short message.  Such devices are small enough to carry in the pocket or pocketbook, or to clip onto a belt or other part of the clothing.  Also called beeper

pagina.definition: The surface of a leaf or of a flattened thallus

paginate.definition: To number the pages of (a book or manuscript)

pagination.definition: The act or process of paging a book; also, the characters used in numbering the pages; page number

paging.definition: The marking or numbering of the pages of a book

pagoda.definition: A term by which Europeans designate religious temples and tower-like buildings of the Hindoos and Buddhists of India, Farther India, China, and Japan, -- usually but not always, devoted to idol worship
A gold or silver coin, of various kinds and values, formerly current in India.  The Madras gold pagoda was worth about three and a half rupees

pagoda sleeve.definition: A funnel-shaped sleeve arranged to show the sleeve lining and an inner sleeve

pagodite.definition: Agalmatolite; -- so called because sometimes carved by the Chinese into the form of pagodas. See Agalmatolite

paguma.definition: Any one of several species of East Indian viverrine mammals of the genus Paguma. They resemble a weasel in form

pagurian.definition: Any one of a tribe of anomuran crustaceans, of which Pagurus is a type; the hermit crab. See Hermit crab, under Hermit

pagurus.definition: The type genus of the crustacean family Paguridae

pah.definition: An exclamation expressing disgust or contempt. See Bah

pahautea.definition: An evergreen tree (Libocedrus bidwillii) of New Zealand resembling the kawaka

pahi.definition: A large war canoe of the Society Islands

pahlavi.definition: The language of Sassanian Persia.  See Pehlevi
The script in which the Pahlavi language was written.  It was taken from the Aramaic alphabet
A gold coin formerly used in Iran, equal in value to 20 rials

pahoehoe.definition: A name given in Hawaii (formerly the Sandwich Islands) to lava having a relatively smooth or billowing surface, in distinction from the rough-surfaced lava, called aa

paid.definition: Receiving pay; compensated; hired; as, a paid attorney

paideutics.definition: The science or art of teaching

paigle.definition: A species of Primula, either the cowslip or the primrose

pail.definition: A vessel of wood or tin, etc., usually cylindrical and having a bail, -- used esp. for carrying liquids, as water or milk, etc.; a bucket.  It may, or may not, have a cover

pailful.definition: The quantity that a pail will hold

paillasse.definition: An under bed or mattress of straw

paillon.definition: A thin leaf of metal, as for use in gilding or enameling, or to show through a translucent medium

pain.definition: Punishment suffered or denounced; suffering or evil inflicted as a punishment for crime, or connected with the commission of a crime; penalty

Any uneasy sensation in animal bodies, from slight uneasiness to extreme distress or torture, proceeding from a derangement of functions, disease, or injury by violence; bodily distress; bodily suffering; an ache; a smart
Specifically, the throes or travail of childbirth
Uneasiness of mind; mental distress; disquietude; anxiety; grief; solicitude; anguish.  Also called mental pain
To inflict suffering upon as a penalty; to punish
To put to bodily uneasiness or anguish; to afflict with uneasy sensations of any degree of intensity; to torment; to torture; as, his dinner or his wound pained him; his stomach pained him
To render uneasy in mind; to disquiet; to distress; to grieve; as, a child's faults pain his parents

painful.definition: Full of pain; causing uneasiness or distress, either physical or mental; afflictive; disquieting; distressing
Requiring labor or toil; difficult; executed with laborious effort; as a painful service; a painful march

painfulness.definition: Emotional distress; a fundamental feeling that people try to avoid

painim.definition: A pagan; an infidel; -- used also adjectively

painkiller.definition: A medicine used in to relieve pain

pains.definition: Labor; toilsome effort; care or trouble taken; -- plural in form, but used with a singular or plural verb, commonly the former

painstaker.definition: One who takes pains; one careful and faithful in all work

painstaking.definition: Careful in doing; diligent; faithful; attentive
The act of taking pains; carefulness and fidelity in performance

painsworthy.definition: Worth the pains or care bestowed

paint.definition: To cover with coloring matter; to apply paint to; as, to paint a house, a signboard, etc
To color, stain, or tinge; to adorn or beautify with colors; to diversify with colors

To form in colors a figure or likeness of on a flat surface, as upon canvas; to represent by means of colors or hues; to exhibit in a tinted image; to portray with paints; as, to paint a portrait or a landscape
To represent or exhibit to the mind; to describe vividly; to delineate; to image; to depict; as, to paint a political opponent as a traitor
To practice the art of painting; as, the artist paints well
To color one's face by way of beautifying it

paint gun.definition: A device designed to rapidly cover a surface with paint by ejecting a spray of paint from a reservoir onto the surface by means of compressed air or other special mechanism.  Also called a paint sprayer.  Use of a paint gun is an efficient method to rapidly paint large surface areas

A device resembling a rifle, designed to shoot a small quantity of paint at an opponent as part of a game often conducted at specially-designed indoor locations, or outdoors.  Points are awarded to players who hit their target; success in hitting one's target is made obvious by the appearance of a spot of paint on the player who is hit

paintable.definition: Lending itself to being painted; as, a highly paintable landscape; made of sturdy eminently paintable wood.  Opposite of unpaintable

paintbox.definition: A box containing a collection of cubes or tubes of artists' paint

paintbrush.definition: A brush used to apply paint

painted.definition: Covered or adorned with paint; portrayed in colors
Marked with bright colors; as, the painted turtle; painted bunting

synonyms: Syn. -- African wild dog, African hunting dog.

painter.definition: A rope at the bow of a boat, used to fasten it to anything
One whose occupation is to paint

paintership.definition: The state or position of being a painter

painting.definition: The act or employment of laying on, or adorning with, paints or colors
The work of the painter; also, any work of art in which objects are represented in color on a flat surface; a colored representation of any object or scene; a picture
A depicting by words; vivid representation in words

paintless.definition: Not capable of being painted or described

painty.definition: Unskillfully painted, so that the painter's method of work is too obvious; also, having too much pigment applied to the surface

pair.definition: A number of things resembling one another, or belonging together; a set; as, a pair or flight of stairs. “A pair of beads.”  Chaucer. Beau. & Fl. “Four pair of stairs.” Macaulay. [Now mostly or quite disused.]
Two things of a kind, similar in form, suited to each other, and intended to be used together; as, a pair of gloves or stockings; a pair of shoes
Two of a sort; a span; a yoke; a couple; a brace; as, a pair of horses; a pair of oxen
A married couple; a man and wife
A single thing, composed of two pieces fitted to each other and used together; as, a pair of scissors; a pair of pants; a pair of tongs; a pair of bellows

Two members of opposite parties or opinion, as in a parliamentary body, who mutually agree not to vote on a given question (in order, for example, to allow the members to be absent during the vote without affecting the outcome of the vote), or on issues of a party nature during a specified time; as, there were two pairs on the final vote
In a mechanism, two elements, or bodies, which are so applied to each other as to mutually constrain relative motion
To be joined in pairs; to couple; to mate, as for breeding
To suit; to fit, as a counterpart
Same as To pair off. See phrase below
To unite in couples; to form a pair of; to bring together, as things which belong together, or which complement, or are adapted to one another
To engage (one's self) with another of opposite opinions not to vote on a particular question or class of questions

pair production.definition: The simultaneous creation of a particle and its antiparticle, such as an electron and positron, from a photon; -- usually due to its interaction with the strong field near a nucleus

paired.definition: Organized into compatible pairs; -- used of gloves, socks, etc.  See pair{1}, v. t
Growing in pairs on either side of a stem; -- of leaves etc

pairing.definition: The act or process of uniting or arranging in pairs or couples

pais.definition: The country; the people of the neighborhood

paisano.definition: A comrade; a pal; a buddy

pak-choi.definition: An Asiatic plant (Brassica rapa chinensis) grown for its cluster of edible white stalks with dark green leaves
synonyms: Syn. -- bok choy, bok choi, pak choi, Chinese white cabbage, Brassica rapa chinensis.

pakistan.definition: A country in South Asia formerly part of British India

pakistani.definition: Of or relating to Pakistan or its people or language; as, Pakistani mountain passes
A native or inhabitant of Pakistan

pal.definition: A mate; a partner; esp., an accomplice or confederate

palace.definition: The residence of a sovereign, including the lodgings of high officers of state, and rooms for business, as well as halls for ceremony and reception
The official residence of a bishop or other distinguished personage
Loosely, any unusually magnificent or stately house

paladin.definition: A knight-errant; a distinguished champion; as, the paladins of Charlemagne

palaeontology.definition: The branch of archeology that studies fossil organisms and related remains

palaeopathology.definition: The study of diseases of former times (as inferred from fossil evidence)

palaeotype.definition: A system of representing all spoken sounds by means of the printing types in common use

palaetiology.definition: The science which explains, by the law of causation, the past condition and changes of the earth; the explanation of past events in terms of scientific causes, such as geological causes

palama.definition: A membrane extending between the toes of a bird, and uniting them more or less closely together

palamedeae.definition: An order, or suborder, including the kamichi, and allied South American birds; -- called also screamers.  In many anatomical characters they are allied to the Anseres, but they externally resemble the wading birds

palanka.definition: A camp permanently intrenched, attached to Turkish frontier fortresses

palanquin.definition: An inclosed carriage or litter, commonly about eight feet long, four feet wide, and four feet high, borne on the shoulders of men by means of two projecting poles, -- used in India, China, etc., for the conveyance of a single person from place to place

palapteryx.definition: A large extinct ostrichlike bird of New Zealand

palatable.definition: Agreeable to the palate or taste; savory; hence, acceptable; pleasing; as, palatable food; palatable advice.  Opposite of unpalatable

palatableness.definition: The quality or state of being agreeable to the taste; relish; acceptableness

palatal.definition: Of or pertaining to the palate; palatine; as, the palatal bones
Uttered by the aid of the palate; -- said of certain sounds, as the sound of k in kirk
A sound uttered, or a letter pronounced, by the aid of the palate, as the letters k and y

palatalize.definition: To modify, as the tones of the voice, by means of the palate

palatalized.definition: Produced with the front of the tongue near or touching the hard palate as "y"; or with the blade of the tongue near the hard palate as "ch" in "chin" or "j" in "gin"

palate.definition: Relish; taste; liking; -- a sense originating in the mistaken notion that the palate is the organ of taste
A projection in the throat of such flowers as the snapdragon

palatial.definition: Of or pertaining to a palace; suitable for a palace; resembling a palace; royal; magnificent; as, palatial structures

palatinate.definition: The province or seigniory of a palatine; the dignity of a palatine

Either of two regions in Germany, formerly divisions of the Holy Roman Empire; the Lower Palatinate or Rhine Palatinate is now within the Rhineland-Palatinate; the Upper Palatinate is now within Bavaria.  It is usually referred to as the Palatinate

palatine.definition: Of or pertaining to a palace, or to a high officer of a palace
Of or pertaining to the Palatinate
Of or pertaining to a Palatine{1}
One invested with royal privileges and rights within his domains; a count palatine. See Count palatine, under 4th Count
Of or pertaining to the palate; palatal

palatine hill.definition: One of the "seven hills" of Rome, situated southeast of the Capitoline and north-northeast of the Aventine.  It borders on the Roman Forum; is the traditional seat of the city founded by Romulus; was the seat of private and later of imperial residences; and contains many antiquities

palatize.definition: To modify, as the tones of the voice, by means of the palate; to palatalize; as, to palatize a letter or sound

palato-.definition: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate relation to the palate, or connection with the palate; as in palatolingual

palatopterygoid.definition: Pertaining to the palatine and pterygoid region of the skull; as, the palatopterygoid cartilage, or rod, from which the palatine and pterygoid bones are developed

palaver.definition: Talk; conversation; esp., idle or beguiling talk; talk intended to deceive; flattery
In Africa, a parley with the natives; a talk; hence, a public conference and deliberation; a debate
To make palaver with, or to; to used palaver; to talk idly or deceitfully; to employ flattery; to cajole; as, to palaver artfully

pale.definition: Wanting in color; not ruddy; dusky white; pallid; wan; as, a pale face; a pale red; a pale blue
Not bright or brilliant; of a faint luster or hue; dim; as, the pale light of the moon
To turn pale; to lose color or luster
To make pale; to diminish the brightness of
A pointed stake or slat, either driven into the ground, or fastened to a rail at the top and bottom, for fencing or inclosing; a picket
That which incloses or fences in; a boundary; a limit; a fence; a palisade
A space or field having bounds or limits; a limited region or place; an inclosure; -- often used figuratively
A region within specified bounds, whether or not enclosed or demarcated
A stripe or band, as on a garment
One of the greater ordinaries, being a broad perpendicular stripe in an escutcheon, equally distant from the two edges, and occupying one third of it
A shore for bracing a timber before it is fastened
To inclose with pales, or as with pales; to encircle; to encompass; to fence off

palea.definition: The interior chaff or husk of grasses
A pendulous process of the skin on the throat of a bird, as in the turkey; a dewlap

paleaceous.definition: Chaffy; resembling or consisting of paleæ, or chaff; furnished with chaff; as, a paleaceous receptacle

palearctic.definition: Belonging to a region of the earth's surface which includes all Europe to the Azores, Iceland, and all temperate Asia

paleechinoidea.definition: An extinct order of sea urchins found in the Paleozoic rocks.  They had more than twenty vertical rows of plates.  Called also Palaeechini

paleencephalon.definition: The more primitive parts of the brain phylogenetically; it includes most structures other than the cerebral cortex

paleface.definition: A white person; -- an appellation supposed to have been applied to the whites by the American Indians

paleichthyes.definition: A comprehensive division of fishes which includes the elasmobranchs and ganoids

palely.definition: In a pale manner; dimly; wanly; not freshly or ruddily

palempore.definition: A superior kind of dimity made in India, -- used for bed coverings

paleness.definition: The quality or condition of being pale; want of freshness or ruddiness; a sickly whiteness; lack of color or luster; wanness

palenque.definition: A collective name for the Indians of Nicaragua and Honduras

paleo-.definition: A combining form meaning old, ancient; as, palearctic, paleontology, paleothere, paleography

paleobotany.definition: That branch of paleontology which treats of fossil plants

paleocrinoidea.definition: A suborder of Crinoidea found chiefly in the Paleozoic rocks

paleocrystic.definition: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, a former glacial formation

paleogaean.definition: Of or pertaining to the Eastern hemisphere

paleogeography.definition: The study of the geography of ancient times or ancient epochs

paleogeology.definition: The study of geologic features once at the surface of the earth but now buried beneath rocks

paleographer.definition: One skilled in paleography; a paleographist

paleographist.definition: One versed in paleography; a paleographer

paleography.definition: An ancient manner of writing; ancient writings, collectively; as, Punic paleography
The study of ancient inscriptions and modes of writing; the art or science of deciphering ancient writings, and determining their origin, period, etc., from external characters; diplomatics

paleola.definition: A diminutive or secondary palea; a lodicule

paleolith.definition: A relic of the Paleolithic era

paleolithic.definition: Of or pertaining to an era marked by early stone implements.  The Paleolithic era (as proposed by Lubbock) includes the earlier half of the “Stone Age;” the remains belonging to it are for the most part of extinct animals, with relics of human beings

paleologist.definition: One versed in paleology; a student of antiquity

paleology.definition: The study or knowledge of antiquities, esp. of prehistoric antiquities; a discourse or treatise on antiquities; archæology

paleontographical.definition: Of or pertaining to the description of fossil remains

paleontology.definition: The science which treats of the ancient life of the earth, or of fossils which are the remains of such life

paleornithology.definition: The branch of paleontology which treats of fossil birds

paleosaurus.definition: A genus of fossil saurians found in the Permian formation

paleotechnic.definition: Belonging to, or connected with, ancient art

paleotherium.definition: An extinct genus of herbivorous Tertiary mammals, once supposed to have resembled the tapir in form, but now known to have had a more slender form, with a long neck like that of a llama

paleozoic.definition: Of or pertaining to, or designating, the older division of geological time during which life is known to have existed, including the Silurian, Devonian, and Carboniferous ages, and also to the life or rocks of those ages. See Chart of Geology

paleozoology.definition: The science of extinct animals, a branch of paleontology

palestra.definition: A wrestling school; hence, a gymnasium, or place for athletic exercise in general

palestrian.definition: Of or pertaining to the palestra, or to wrestling

palette.definition: A thin, oval or square board, or tablet, with a thumb hole at one end for holding it, on which a painter lays and mixes his pigments. Hence, any other object, usually one with a flat surface, used for the same purpose

The complete set of colors used by an artist or other person in creating an image, in any medium.  The meaning of this term has been extended in modern times to include the set of colors used in a particular computer application, or the complete set of of colors available in computer displays or printing techniques
The complete range of resources and techniques used in any art, such as music
One of the plates covering the points of junction at the bend of the shoulders and elbows
A breastplate for a breast drill

palewise.definition: In the manner of a pale or pales; by perpendicular lines or divisions; as, to divide an escutcheon palewise

palfrey.definition: A saddle horse for the road, or for state occasions, as distinguished from a war horse
A small saddle horse for ladies

pali.definition: A dialect descended from Sanskrit, and like that, a dead language, except when used as the sacred language of the Buddhist religion in Farther India, etc

palification.definition: The act or practice of driving piles or posts into the ground to make it firm

paliform.definition: Resembling a palus; as, the paliform lobes of the septa in corals

palilogy.definition: The repetition of a word, or part of a sentence, for the sake of greater emphasis; as, “The living, the living, he shall praise thee.”

palimony.definition: a form of alimony paid to a former partner in a romantic relationship after a period of living together, even though the two persons involved were not married to each other.  The absence of a formal marriage distinguishes it from alimony

palimpsest.definition: A parchment which has been written upon twice, the first writing having been erased to make place for the second.  The erasures of ancient writings were usually carried on in monasteries, to allow the production of ecclesiastical texts, such as copies of church services and lives of the saints.  The difficulty of recovering the original text varied with the process used to prepare the parchment for a fresh writing; the original texts on parchments which had been washed with lime-water and dried were easily recovered by a chemical process, but those erased by scraping the parchment and bleaching are difficult to interpret.  Most of the manuscripts underlying the palimpsests that have been revived are fragmentary, but some are of great historical value.  One Syriac version of the Four Gospels was discovered in 1895 in St. Catherine's Monastery at Mount Sinai by Mrs. Agnes Smith Lewis.  See also the notes below

palindrome.definition: A word, verse, or sentence, that is the same when read backward or forward; as, madam; Hannah; or Lewd did I live, & evil I did dwel

palindromic.definition: Of, pertaining to, or like, a palindrome

paling.definition: Pales, in general; a fence formed with pales or pickets; a limit; an inclosure
The act of placing pales or stripes on cloth; also, the stripes themselves

palingenesis.definition: A new birth; a re-creation; a regeneration; a continued existence in different manner or form
The passing over of the soul of one person or animal into the body of another person or animal, at the time of the death of the first; the transmigration of souls.  Called also metempsychosis

That form of development of an individual organism in which in which ancestral characteristics occurring during its evolution are conserved by heredity and reproduced,  sometimes transiently, in the course of individual development; original simple descent; -- distinguished from cenogenesis (kenogenesis or coenogenesis), in which the mode of individual development has been modified so that the evolutionary process had become obscured.  Sometimes, in Zoology, the term is applied to the abrupt metamorphosis of insects, crustaceans, etc.  See also the note under recapitulation

palingenetic.definition: Of or pertaining to palingenesis: as, a palingenetic process

palinode.definition: An ode recanting, or retracting, a former one; also, a repetition of an ode
A retraction; esp., a formal retraction

palinodial.definition: Of or pertaining to a palinode, or retraction

palinurus.definition: An instrument for obtaining directly, without calculation, the true bearing of the sun, and thence the variation of the compass

palisade.definition: A strong, long stake, one end of which is set firmly in the ground, and the other is sharpened; also, a fence formed of such stakes set in the ground as a means of defense
Any fence made of pales or sharp stakes
A line of bold cliffs, esp. one showing basaltic columns; -- usually in pl., and orig. used as the name of the cliffs on the west bank of the lower Hudson
To surround, inclose, or fortify, with palisades

palisading.definition: A row of palisades set in the ground

palissy.definition: Designating, or of the nature of, a kind of pottery made by Bernard Palissy, in France, in the 16th centry

pall.definition: An outer garment; a cloak mantle
A kind of rich stuff used for garments in the Middle Ages
A figure resembling the Roman Catholic pallium, or pall, and having the form of the letter Y
A large cloth, esp., a heavy black cloth, thrown over a coffin at a funeral; sometimes, also, over a tomb
A piece of cardboard, covered with linen and embroidered on one side; -- used to put over the chalice
To become vapid, tasteless, dull, or insipid; to lose strength, life, spirit, or taste; as, the liquor palls
To make vapid or insipid; to make lifeless or spiritless; to dull; to weaken
To satiate; to cloy; as, to pall the appetite

pall-mall.definition: A game formerly common in England, in which a wooden ball was driven with a mallet through an elevated hoop or ring of iron.  The name was also given to the mallet used, to the place where the game was played, and to the street, in London, still called Pall Mall

palla.definition: An oblong rectangular piece of cloth, worn by Roman ladies, and fastened with brooches

palladian.definition: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a variety of the revived classic style of architecture, founded on the works of Andrea Palladio, an Italian architect of the 16th century; as, a Palladian window
Of or pertaining to the Greek goddess Athena, also called Pallas
Pertaining to wisdom or knowledge; -- Athena being the goddess of wisdom
A follower of the architectural style of Andrea Palladio

palladic.definition: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, palladium; -- used specifically to designate those compounds in which the element has a higher valence as contrasted with palladious compounds

palladious.definition: Of, pertaining to, or containing, palladium; -- used specifically to designate those compounds in which palladium has a lower valence as compared with palladic compounds

palladium.definition: Any statue of the goddess Pallas; esp., the famous statue on the preservation of which depended the safety of ancient Troy
That which affords effectual protection or security; a safeguard; as, the trial by jury is the palladium of our civil rights

A rare metallic element of the light platinum group, found native, and also alloyed with platinum and gold.  It is a silver-white metal resembling platinum, and like it permanent and untarnished in the air, but is more easily fusible, with a melting point of 1555° C.  It can also be prepared as a finely divided black powder.  It is unique in its power of absorbing hydrogen, which it does to the extent of nearly a thousand volumes, forming the alloy Pd2H.  It is used for graduated circles and verniers, for plating certain silver goods, and somewhat in dentistry.  It was so named in 1804 by Wollaston from the asteroid Pallas, which was discovered in 1802.  Symbol Pd.  Atomic number, 46.  Atomic weight, 106.42.  Density 12.0

palladiumize.definition: To cover or coat with palladium

pallah.definition: A large South African antelope (Aepyceros melampus).  The male has long lyrate and annulated horns.  The general color is bay, with a black crescent on the croup.  Called also roodebok

pallas.definition: Pallas Athena, the Grecian goddess of wisdom, called also Athena, Pallas Athene or Athene, and identified, at a later period, with the Roman Minerva

pallbearer.definition: One of those who attend the coffin at a funeral; -- so called from the pall being formerly carried by them

pallet.definition: A small and mean bed; a bed of straw
A perpendicular band upon an escutcheon, one half the breadth of the pale
A wooden implement used by potters, crucible makers, etc., for forming, beating, and rounding their works.  It is oval, round, and of other forms
An instrument used to take up gold leaf from the pillow, and to apply it
A board on which a newly molded brick is conveyed to the hack
A click or pawl for driving a ratchet wheel
One of the pieces or levers connected with the pendulum of a clock, or the balance of a watch, which receive the immediate impulse of the scape-wheel, or balance wheel
In the organ, a valve between the wind chest and the mouth of a pipe or row of pipes
One of a pair of shelly plates that protect the siphon tubes of certain bivalves, as the Teredo.  See Illust. of Teredo
A cup containing three ounces, -- formerly used by surgeons

A low movable platform used for temporary storage of objects so that they can be conveniently moved; it is commonly made of wooden boards, about 4 inches high, and typically has openings in the side into which the blades of a fork-lift truck may be inserted so as to lift and move the pallet and the objects on it

pallial.definition: Of or pertaining to a mantle, especially to the mantle of mollusks; produced by the mantle; as, the pallial line, or impression, which marks the attachment of the mantle on the inner surface of a bivalve shell. See Illust. of Bivalve

palliate.definition: Covered with a mantle; cloaked; hidden; disguised
To cover with a mantle or cloak; to cover up; to hide
To cover with excuses; to conceal the enormity of, by excuses and apologies; to extenuate; as, to palliate faults
To reduce in violence; to lessen or abate; to mitigate; to ease without curing; as, to palliate a disease

palliation.definition: The act of palliating, or state of being palliated; extenuation; excuse; as, the palliation of faults, offenses, vices
Mitigation; alleviation, as of a disease
That which cloaks or covers; disguise; also, the state of being covered or disguised

palliative.definition: Serving to palliate; serving to extenuate, mitigate, or alleviate
That which palliates; a palliative agent

pallid.definition: Deficient in color; pale; wan; as, a pallid countenance; pallid blue

pallidness.definition: The quality or state of being pallid; paleness; pallor; wanness

palliobranchiate.definition: Having the pallium, or mantle, acting as a gill, as in brachiopods

pallium.definition: A large, square, woolen cloak which enveloped the whole person, worn by the Greeks and by certain Romans.  It is the Roman name of a Greek garment
A band of white wool, worn on the shoulders, with four purple crosses worked on it; a pall
The mantle of a bivalve. See Mantle

pallone.definition: An Italian game, played with a large leather ball

pallor.definition: Paleness; want of color; pallidity; as, pallor of the complexion

pally.definition: Having the relationship of friends or pals; -- used colloquially

palm.definition: The inner and somewhat concave part of the hand between the bases of the fingers and the wrist
A lineal measure equal either to the breadth of the hand or to its length from the wrist to the ends of the fingers; a hand; -- used in measuring a horse's height
A metallic disk, attached to a strap, and worn on the palm of the hand, -- used to push the needle through the canvas, in sewing sails, etc
The broad flattened part of an antler, as of a full-grown fallow deer; -- so called as resembling the palm of the hand with its protruding fingers
The flat inner face of an anchor fluke
Any endogenous tree of the order Palmæ or Palmaceæ; a palm tree
A branch or leaf of the palm, anciently borne or worn as a symbol of victory or rejoicing
Any symbol or token of superiority, success, or triumph; also, victory; triumph; supremacy
To manipulate with, or conceal in, the palm of the hand; to juggle
To take (something small) stealthily, especially by concealing it in the palm of the hand; as, he palmed one of the coins and walked out with it
To impose by fraud, as by sleight of hand; to put by unfair means; -- usually with on or upon; as, to palm a stolen coin on an unsuspecting dealer.  See also palm off

palm sunday.definition: The Sunday next before Easter; -- so called in commemoration of the triumphal entry of Jesus Christ into Jerusalem, when the multitude strewed palm branches in the way.  The event is commemorated in Christian churches by distribution of blessed palm leaves

palma christi.definition: A plant (Ricinus communis) with ornamental peltate and palmately cleft foliage, growing as a woody perennial in the tropics, and cultivated as an herbaceous annual in temperate regions; -- called also castor-oil plant

palmaceae.definition: A natural family of chiefly tropical trees and shrubs and vines usually having a tall columnar trunk bearing a crown of very large leaves; coextensive with the order Palmales
synonyms: Syn. -- Palmae, family Palmae, family Palmaceae, Arecaceae, family Arecaceae, palm family.

palmaceous.definition: Of or pertaining to palms; of the nature of, or resembling, palms

palmae.definition: A natural family of chiefly tropical trees and shrubs; same as Palmaceae; coextensive with the order Palmales
synonyms: Syn. -- family Palmae, Palmaceae, Arecaceae, family Arecaceae, palm family.

palmales.definition: A natural family of chiefly tropical trees and shrubs coextensive with the family Palmae; -- the palms

palmar.definition: Pertaining to, or corresponding with, the palm of the hand
Of or pertaining to the under side of the wings of birds

palmarium.definition: One of the bifurcations of the brachial plates of a crinoid

palmary.definition: Worthy of the palm; palmy; preëminent; superior; principal; chief; as, palmary work

palmate.definition: A salt of palmic acid; a ricinoleate
Having the shape of the hand; resembling a hand with the fingers spread
Spreading from the apex of a petiole, as the divisions of a leaf, or leaflets, so as to resemble the hand with outspread fingers
Having the anterior toes united by a web, as in most swimming birds; webbed. See Illust. (i) under Aves

palmatifid.definition: Palmate, with the divisions separated but little more than halfway to the common center

palmatilobed.definition: Palmate, with the divisions separated less than halfway to the common center

palmatisect.definition: Divided, as a palmate leaf, down to the midrib, so that the parenchyma is interrupted

palmcrist.definition: The palma Christi. (Jonah iv. 6, margin, and Douay version, note.)

palmed.definition: Having or bearing a palm or palms

palmer.definition: One who palms or cheats, as at cards or dice
A wandering religious votary; especially, one who bore a branch of palm as a token that he had visited the Holy Land and its sacred places

palmerworm.definition: Any hairy caterpillar which appears in great numbers, devouring herbage, and wandering about like a palmer.  The name is applied also to other voracious insects

palmette.definition: A floral ornament, common in Greek and other ancient architecture; -- often called the honeysuckle ornament

palmetto.definition: A name given to palms of several genera and species growing in the West Indies and the Southern United States.  In the United States, the name is applied especially to the Chamærops Palmetto, or Sabal Palmetto, the cabbage tree of Florida and the Carolinas.  See Cabbage tree, under Cabbage

palmetto flag.definition: Any of several flags adopted by South Carolina after its secession.  That adopted in November, 1860, had a green cabbage palmetto in the center of a white field; the final one, January, 1861, had a white palmetto in the center of a blue field and a white crescent in the upper left-hand corner

palmetto state.definition: South Carolina; -- a nickname alluding to the State Arms, which contain a representation of a palmetto tree

palmic.definition: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the castor-oil plant (Ricinus communis, or Palma Christi) and other species of the family Euphorbiaceae; -- formerly used to designate an acid now called ricinoleic acid (d-12-hydroxyoleic acid, C18H34O3)

palmidactyles.definition: A group of wading birds having the toes webbed, as the avocet

palmigrade.definition: Putting the whole foot upon the ground in walking, as some mammals

palmin.definition: A white waxy or fatty substance obtained from castor oil

palmistry.definition: The art or practice of divining or telling fortunes, or of judging of character, by the lines and marks in the palm of the hand; chiromancy
A dexterous use or trick of the hand

palmite.definition: A South African plant (Prionium Palmita) of the Rush family, having long serrated leaves.  The stems have been used for making brushes

palmitic.definition: Pertaining to, or obtained from, palmitin or palm oil; as, palmitic acid (C16H32O2), a white crystalline substance belonging to the fatty acid series.  It is readily soluble in hot alcohol, and melts to a liquid oil at 62° C

palmitin.definition: A solid crystallizable fat, found abundantly in animals and in vegetables.  It occurs mixed with stearin and olein in the fat of animal tissues, with olein and butyrin in butter, with olein in olive oil, etc.  Chemically, it is a glyceride of palmitic acid, three molecules of palmitic acid being united to one molecule of glyceryl, and hence it is technically called tripalmitin, or glyceryl tripalmitate

palmitolic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, an artificial acid of the oleic acid series, isomeric with linoleic acid

palmy.definition: Bearing palms; abounding in palms; derived from palms; as, a palmy shore
Worthy of the palm; flourishing; prosperous

palmyra.definition: A species of palm (Borassus flabelliformis) having a straight, black, upright trunk, with palmate leaves.  It is found native along the entire northern shores of the Indian Ocean, from the mouth of the Tigris to New Guinea.  More than eight hundred uses to which it is put are enumerated by native writers.  Its wood is largely used for building purposes; its fruit and roots serve for food, its sap for making toddy, and its leaves for thatching huts

palo.definition: A pole or timber of any kind; -- in the names of trees

palo blanco.definition: A western American hackberry (Celtis reticulata), having light-colored bark

palolo.definition: A polystome worm (Palolo viridis) that burrows in the coral reefs of certain of the Pacific Islands.  A little before the last quarter of the moon in October and November, they swarm in vast numbers at the surface of the sea for breeding, and are gathered and highly esteemed as food by the natives.  An allied species inhabits the tropical Atlantic and swarms in June or July

palometa.definition: A type of pompano (Palometa simillima) that is smaller than the Florida pompano; it is common in West Indies.  Called also the California pompano

palomino.definition: A horse of light tan or golden color with cream or white mane and tail, and often having white markings on the legs and face

palp.definition: To have a distinct touch or feeling of; to feel

palpability.definition: The quality of being palpable, or perceptible by the touch

palpable.definition: Capable of being touched and felt; perceptible by the touch; as, a palpable form
Easily perceptible; plain; distinct; obvious; readily perceived and detected; gross; as, palpable imposture; palpable absurdity; palpable errors

palpate.definition: To examine for medical purposes by touching, as of body parts; as, the nurse palpated the patient's stomach

palpation.definition: Examination of a patient by touch

palpator.definition: One of a family of clavicorn beetles, including those which have very long maxillary palpi

palpebral.definition: Of or pertaining to the eyelids

palpicorn.definition: One of a group of aquatic beetles (Palpicornia) having short club-shaped antennæ, and long maxillary palpi

palpiform.definition: Having the form of a palpus

palpiger.definition: That portion of the labium which bears the palpi in insects

palpitate.definition: To beat rapidly and more strongly than usual; to throb; to bound with emotion or exertion; to pulsate violently; to flutter; -- said specifically of the heart when its action is abnormal, as from excitement

palpitation.definition: A rapid pulsation; a throbbing; esp., an abnormal, rapid beating of the heart as when excited by violent exertion, strong emotion, or by disease

palpocil.definition: A minute soft filamentary process springing from the surface of certain hydroids and sponges

palpus.definition: A feeler; especially, one of the jointed sense organs attached to the mouth organs of insects, arachnids, crustaceans, and annelids; as, the mandibular palpi, maxillary palpi, and labial palpi. The palpi of male spiders serve as sexual organs. Called also palp. See Illust. of Arthrogastra and Orthoptera

palsgrave.definition: A count or earl who presided in the domestic court, and had the superintendence, of a royal household in Germany

palsgravine.definition: The consort or widow of a palsgrave

palstave.definition: A peculiar bronze adz, used in prehistoric Europe about the middle of the bronze age

palsy.definition: Paralysis, complete or partial. See Paralysis
To affect with palsy, or as with palsy; to deprive of action or energy; to paralyze

palsywort.definition: The cowslip (Primula veris); -- so called from its supposed remedial powers

palter.definition: To act in insincere or deceitful manner; to play false; to equivocate; to shift; to dodge; to trifle
To trifle with; to waste; to squander in paltry ways or on worthless things

paltock.definition: A kind of doublet; a jacket

paltriness.definition: The state or quality of being paltry

paltry.definition: Mean; vile; worthless; despicable; contemptible; pitiful; trifling; as, a paltry excuse; paltry gold

paludal.definition: Of or pertaining to marshes or fens; marshy

paludamentum.definition: A military cloak worn by a general and his principal officers

paludicolae.definition: A division of birds, including the cranes, rails, etc

paludina.definition: Any one of numerous species of freshwater pectinibranchiate mollusks, belonging to Paludina, Melantho, and allied genera.  They have an operculated shell which is usually green, often with brown bands.  See Illust. of Pond snail, under Pond

paludine.definition: Of or pertaining to a marsh

paludinous.definition: Of or pertaining to a marsh or fen

paludism.definition: The morbid phenomena produced by dwelling among marshes; malarial disease or disposition

paludose.definition: Growing or living in marshy places; marshy

palus.definition: One of several upright slender calcareous processes which surround the central part of the calicle of certain corals

palustral.definition: Of or pertaining to a bog or marsh; boggy

palustrine.definition: Of, pertaining to, or living in, a marsh or swamp; marshy

paly.definition: Divided into four or more equal parts by perpendicular lines, and of two different tinctures disposed alternately

pam.definition: A card game in which the jack of clubs is trump
A form of the female given name Pamela

pampas.definition: Vast grass-covered plains in the central and southern part of the Argentine Republic in South America.  The term is sometimes used in a wider sense for the plains east of the Andes extending from Bolivia to Southern Patagonia

pamper.definition: To feed to the full; to feed luxuriously; to glut; as, to pamper the body or the appetite
To gratify inordinately; to indulge to excess; as, to pamper pride; to pamper the imagination

pampered.definition: Fed luxuriously; indulged to the full; hence, luxuriant; as, pampered children

pamperer.definition: One who, or that which, pampers

pampero.definition: A violent wind from the west or southwest, which sweeps over the pampas of South America and the adjacent seas, often doing great damage

pamperos.definition: A tribe of Indians inhabiting the pampas of South America

pamphlet.definition: A small book consisting of a few sheets of printed paper, stitched together, often with a paper cover, but not bound; a short essay or written discussion, usually on a subject of current interest
To write a pamphlet or pamphlets

pamphleteer.definition: A writer of pamphlets; a scribbler

pampiniform.definition: In the form of tendrils; -- applied especially to the spermatic and ovarian veins

pampre.definition: An ornament, composed of vine leaves and bunches of grapes, used for decorating spiral columns

pamprodactylous.definition: Having all the toes turned forward, as the colies

pan.definition: The distance comprised between the angle of the epaule and the flanked angle
A leaf of gold or silver
To join or fit together; to unite
The betel leaf; also, the masticatory made of the betel leaf, etc.  See Betel

The god of shepherds, guardian of bees, and patron of fishing and hunting.  He is usually represented as having the head and trunk of a man, with the legs, horns, and tail of a goat, and as playing on the shepherd's pipe (also called the pipes of Pan), which he is said to have invented
A shallow, open dish or vessel, usually of metal, employed for many domestic uses, as for setting milk for cream, for frying or baking food, etc.; also employed for various uses in manufacturing
A closed vessel for boiling or evaporating. See Vacuum pan, under Vacuum
The part of a flintlock which holds the priming
The skull, considered as a vessel containing the brain; the upper part of the head; the brainpan; the cranium
A recess, or bed, for the leaf of a hinge
The hard stratum of earth that lies below the soil. See Hard pan, under Hard
A natural basin, containing salt or fresh water, or mud
To separate, as gold, from dirt or sand, by washing in a kind of pan
To criticise (a drama or literary work) harshly
To yield gold in, or as in, the process of panning; -- usually with out; as, the gravel panned out richly
To turn out (profitably or unprofitably); to result; to develop; as, the investigation, or the speculation, panned out poorly
To scan (a movie camera), usu. in a horizontal direction, to obtain a panoramic effect; also, to move the camera so as to keep the subject in view

pan out.definition: To succeed; as, the project didn't pan out
To turn out (profitably or unprofitably); to result; to develop; as, the investigation, or the speculation, panned out poorly

pan-.definition: Combining forms signifying all, every; as, panorama, pantheism, pantagraph, pantograph. Pan- becomes pam- before b or p, as pamprodactylous

pan-american.definition: Of or pertaining to both North and South America

pan-american congress.definition: Any of several meetings of delegates from various American states

pan-americanism.definition: The principle or advocacy of a political alliance or union of all the states of America

pan-anglican.definition: Belonging to, or representing, the whole Church of England; used less strictly, to include the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States; as, the Pan-Anglican Conference at Lambeth, in 1888

panacea.definition: A remedy for all diseases; a universal medicine; a cure-all; catholicon; hence, a relief or solace for affliction

panacean.definition: Having the properties of a panacea

panache.definition: A plume or bunch of feathers, esp. such a bunch worn on the helmet; any military plume, or ornamental group of feathers
A pleasingly flamboyant style or manner; flair{4}; verve

panada.definition: Bread boiled in water to the consistence of pulp, and sweetened or flavored

panama hat.definition: A fine plaited hat, made in Central America of the young leaves of a plant (Carludovica palmata)

panamica.definition: A low stingless nettle (Pilea involucrata) of Central and South America having velvety brownish-green toothed leaves and clusters of small green flowers
synonyms: Syn. -- friendship plant, panamiga, Pilea involucrata.
Syn. -- friendship plant, panamica, Pilea involucrata.

panary.definition: Of or pertaining to bread or to breadmaking

panathenaea.definition: The most ancient and important festival of Athens, celebrated in honor of Athena, the tutelary goddess of the city

panax.definition: A genus of perennial herbs of eastern North America and Asia having aromatic tuberous roots: ginseng

pancake.definition: A thin cake of batter fried in a pan or on a griddle; a griddlecake; a flapjack

pancarte.definition: A royal charter confirming to a subject all his possessions

panchway.definition: A Bengalese four-oared boat for passengers

pancratiast.definition: One who engaged in the contests of the pancratium

pancratiastic.definition: Of or pertaining to the pancratium

pancratic.definition: Having all or many degrees of power; having a great range of power; -- said of an eyepiece made adjustable so as to give a varying magnifying power
Of or pertaining to the pancratium; athletic

pancratium.definition: An athletic contest involving both boxing and wrestling
A genus of Old World amaryllideous bulbous plants, having a funnel-shaped perianth with six narrow spreading lobes. The American species are now placed in the related genus Hymenocallis

pancreas.definition: The sweetbread, a gland connected with the intestine of nearly all vertebrates. It is usually elongated and light-colored, and its secretion, called the pancreatic juice, is discharged, often together with the bile, into the upper part of the intestines, and is a powerful aid in digestion. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus

pancreatic.definition: Of or pertaining to the pancreas; as, the pancreatic secretion, digestion, ferments

pancreatin.definition: One of the digestive enzymes of the pancreatic juice
A preparation of pancreatic juice, usually obtained from the ox or hog, containing the three main digestive enzymes trypsin, amylase, and lipase, and used in medicine as an aid to digestion

panda.definition: A small Asiatic mammal (Ailurus fulgens) having fine soft fur, which inhabits the mountains of Northern India.  It was once thought to be related to the bears, but is now believed to be more closely related to raccoons.  It has reddish-brown fur on the back and sides, and black fur on the legs and underside.  Called also the lesser panda

The giant panda (Ailuropoda melanoleuca), a bearlike black-and white mammal now found wild only in the central forests of China, which lives mainly on on bamboo.  It is an endangered species, and is a popular attraction in the few zoos which have bveen able to obtain specimens

pandanaceae.definition: A natural family of woody plants including the pandanus tree (the screw pine) and freycinetia

pandanales.definition: An order of plants including the families Typhaceae; Sparganiaceae; and Pandanaceae

pandanus.definition: A genus of endogenous plants, native to tropical lands from Africa to Polynesia. See Screw pine
Fiber from leaves of the pandanus tree; used for woven articles (such as mats)
Any of various Old World tropical palmlike trees having huge prop roots and pineapplelike leaves and edible conelike fruits; also called the screw pine

pandean.definition: Of or relating to the god Pan

pandean pipes.definition: A primitive wind instrument, consisting of a series of short hollow reeds or pipes, graduated in length by the musical scale, and fastened together side by side; a syrinx; a mouth organ; -- said to have been invented by the god Pan.  Called also pipes of Pan, Pan's pipes and Panpipes

pandect.definition: A treatise which comprehends the whole of any science

The digest, or abridgment, in fifty books, of the decisions, writings, and opinions of the old Roman jurists, made in the sixth century by direction of the emperor Justinian, and forming the leading compilation of the Roman civil law

pandemic.definition: Affecting a whole people or a number of countries; everywhere epidemic

pandemonium.definition: The great hall or council chamber of demons or evil spirits
An utterly lawless, riotous place or assemblage
A condition of unrestrained disorder and chaotic, riotous uproar

pander.definition: A male bawd; a pimp; a procurer
Hence, one who ministers to the evil designs and passions of another
To act the part of a pander

panderism.definition: The employment, arts, or practices of a pander

panderly.definition: Having the quality of a pander

pandermite.definition: A hydrous borate of lime, near priceite

panderous.definition: Of or relating to a pander; characterizing a pander

pandiculation.definition: A stretching and stiffening of the trunk and extremities, as when fatigued and drowsy

pandora.definition: A beautiful woman (all-gifted), whom Jupiter caused Vulcan to make out of clay in order to punish the human race, because Prometheus had stolen the fire from heaven.  Jupiter gave Pandora a box containing all human ills, which, when the box was opened, escaped and spread over the earth.  Hope alone remained in the box.  Another version makes the box contain all the blessings of the gods, which were lost to men when Pandora opened it
A genus of marine bivalves, in which one valve is flat, the other convex

pandore.definition: An ancient musical instrument, of the lute kind; a bandore

pandour.definition: One of a class of Hungarian mountaineers serving in the Austrian army that served as local militia in Croatia; -- so called from Pandur, a principal town in the region from which they originally came.  They were noted for their ruthlessness

pandowdy.definition: A deep pie or pudding made of baked apples, or of sliced bread and apples baked together, with no bottom crust

pandurate.definition: Obovate, with a concavity in each side, like the body of a violin; fiddle-shaped; as, a panduriform leaf; panduriform color markings of an animal
Shaped like a fiddle; -- of a leaf

pane.definition: The narrow edge of a hammer head. See Peen
A division; a distinct piece, limited part, or compartment of any surface; a patch; hence, a square of a checkered or plaided pattern
One of the openings in a slashed garment, showing the bright colored silk, or the like, within; hence, the piece of colored or other stuff so shown
A compartment of a surface, or a flat space; hence, one side or face of a building; as, an octagonal tower is said to have eight panes
In irrigating, a subdivision of an irrigated surface between a feeder and an outlet drain
One of the flat surfaces, or facets, of any object having several sides

paned.definition: Having panes; provided with panes; also, having openings; as, a paned window; paned window sash
Having flat sides or surfaces; as, a six-paned nut

panegyric.definition: An oration or eulogy in praise of some person or achievement; a formal or elaborate encomium; a laudatory discourse; laudation. See Synonym of Eulogy
Containing praise or eulogy; encomiastic; laudatory

panegyrist.definition: One who delivers a panegyric; a eulogist; one who extols or praises, either by writing or speaking

panegyrize.definition: To praise highly; to extol in a public speech; to write or deliver a panegyric upon; to eulogize

panel.definition: A sunken compartment with raised margins, molded or otherwise, as in ceilings, wainscotings, etc
