One who encourages or helps a person, a cause, or a work; a furtherer; a promoter; as, a patron of art
One who has gift and disposition of a benefice
A guardian saint. -- called also patron saint
To be a patron of; to patronize; to favor
Doing the duty of a patron; giving aid or protection; tutelary

patronage.definition: Special countenance or support; favor, encouragement, or aid, afforded to a person or a work; as, the patronage of letters; patronage given to an author
Guardianship, as of a saint; tutelary care
The right of nomination to political office; also, the offices, contracts, honors, etc., which a public officer may bestow by favor
The right of presentation to church or ecclesiastical benefice; advowson
To act as a patron of; to maintain; to defend

patronate.definition: The right or duty of a patron; patronage

patronization.definition: The act of patronizing; patronage; support

patronize.definition: To act as patron toward; to support; to countenance; to favor; to aid
To trade with customarily; to frequent as a customer
To assume the air of a patron, or of a superior and protector, toward; -- used in an unfavorable sense; as, to patronize one's equals

patronizing.definition: Showing condescending favor; assuming the manner of airs of a superior toward another

patronomatology.definition: That branch of knowledge which deals with personal names and their origin; the study of patronymics

patronymic.definition: Derived from ancestors; as, a patronymic denomination

A modification of the father's name borne by the son; a name derived from that of a parent or ancestor; as, Pelides, the son of Peleus; Johnson, the son of John; Macdonald, the son of Donald; Paulowitz, the son of Paul; also, the surname of a family; the family name

patroon.definition: One of the proprietors of certain tracts of land with manorial privileges and right of entail, under the old Dutch governments of New York and New Jersey

patte.definition: Narrow at the inner, and very broad at the other, end, or having its arms of that shape; -- said of a cross. See Illust. (8) of Cross

patten.definition: A clog or sole of wood, usually supported by an iron ring, worn to raise the feet from the wet or the mud

patter.definition: To strike with a quick succession of slight, sharp sounds; as, pattering rain or hail; pattering feet
To mutter; to mumble; as, to patter with the lips
To talk glibly; to chatter; to harangue
A quick succession of slight sounds; as, the patter of rain; the patter of little feet
Glib and rapid speech; a voluble harangue
The cant of a class; patois; as, thieves's patter; gypsies' patter
The language or oratory of a street peddler, conjurer, or the like, hence, glib talk; a voluble harangue; mere talk; chatter; also, specif., rapid speech, esp. as sometimes introduced in songs

patterer.definition: One who patters, or talks glibly; specifically, a street peddler

pattern.definition: Anything proposed for imitation; an archetype; an exemplar; that which is to be, or is worthy to be, copied or imitated; as, a pattern of a machine
A part showing the figure or quality of the whole; a specimen; a sample; an example; an instance
Stuff sufficient for a garment; as, a dress pattern
Figure or style of decoration; design; as, wall paper of a beautiful pattern
Something made after a model; a copy
Anything cut or formed to serve as a guide to cutting or forming objects; as, a dressmaker's pattern
A full-sized model around which a mold of sand is made, to receive the melted metal. It is usually made of wood and in several parts, so as to be removed from the mold without injuring it

a recognizable characteristic relationship or set of relationships between the members of any set of objects or actions, or the properties of the members; also, the set having a definable relationship between its members
A diagram showing the distribution of the pellets of a shotgun on a vertical target perpendicular to the plane of fire
the recommended flight path for an airplane to follow as it approaches an airport for a landing.  Same as landing pattern

an image or diagram containing lines, usually horizontal, vertical, and diagonal, sometimes of varying widths, used to test the resolution of an optical instrument or the accuracy of reproduction of image copying or transmission equipment.  Same as test pattern
To make or design (anything) by, from, or after, something that serves as a pattern; to copy; to model; to imitate
To serve as an example for; also, to parallel

pattern matching.definition: A technique in automated data analysis, usually performed on a computer, by which a group of characteristic properties of an unknown object is compared with the comparable groups of characteristics of a set of known objects, to discover the idenity or proper classification of the unknown object

patterned.definition: Having describable patterns, especially patterns of colors

patternlike.definition: resembling a pattern or shape or outline

patternmaker.definition: Someone who makes patterns (as for sewing or carpentery or metalworking)

pattinson's process.definition: A process of desilverizing argentiferous lead by repeated meltings and skimmings, which concentrate the silver in the molten bath, the final skimmings being nearly pure lad. The processwas invented in 1833 by Hugh Lee Pattinson, an English metallurgist

patulous.definition: Open; expanded; slightly spreading; having the parts loose or dispersed; as, a patulous calyx; a patulous cluster of flowers

pauciloquent.definition: Uttering few words; brief in speech

paucispiral.definition: Having few spirals, or whorls; as, a paucispiral operculum or shell

paucity.definition: Fewness; smallness of number; scarcity; rarity
Smallness of quantity; exiguity; insufficiency; as, paucity of blood

paugie.definition: The scup. See Porgy, and Scup

paul.definition: An Italian silver coin. See Paolo

pauldron.definition: A piece of armor covering the shoulder at the junction of the body piece and arm piece

paulian.definition: A follower of Paul of Samosata, a bishop of Antioch in the third century, who was deposed for denying the divinity of Christ

paulician.definition: One of a sect of Christian dualists originating in Armenia in the seventh century.  They rejected the Old Testament and the part of the New

pauline.definition: Of or pertaining to the apostle Paul, or his writings; resembling, or conforming to, the writings of Paul; as, the Pauline epistles; Pauline doctrine

paulist.definition: A member of The Institute of the Missionary Priests of St. Paul the Apostle, founded in 1858 by the Rev. I. T. Hecker of New York.  The majority of the members were formerly Protestants

paulownia.definition: A genus of trees of the order Scrophulariaceæ, consisting of one species, Paulownia imperialis

paum.definition: To palm off by fraud; to cheat at cards

paunch.definition: The belly and its contents; the abdomen; also, the first stomach, or rumen, of ruminants. See Rumen
A paunch mat; -- called also panch
The thickened rim of a bell, struck by the clapper
A noticeably protruding belly; a potbelly
To pierce or rip the belly of; to eviscerate; to disembowel

paune.definition: A kind of bread. See Pone

pauper.definition: A very poor person; one without any means of support, especially one dependent on private or public charity.  Also used adjectively; as, pauper immigrants, pauper labor

pauperism.definition: The state of being a pauper; the state of indigent persons requiring support from the community

pauperization.definition: The act or process of reducing to pauperism

pauperize.definition: To reduce to pauperism; as, to pauperize the peasantry

pauropoda.definition: An order of small myriapods having only nine pairs of legs and destitute of tracheæ

pause.definition: A temporary stop or rest; an intermission of action; interruption; suspension; cessation
Temporary inaction or waiting; hesitation; suspence; doubt
In speaking or reading aloud, a brief arrest or suspension of voice, to indicate the limits and relations of sentences and their parts
In writing and printing, a mark indicating the place and nature of an arrest of voice in reading; a punctuation point; as, teach the pupil to mind the pauses
A break or paragraph in writing
To make a short stop; to cease for a time; to intermit speaking or acting; to stop; to wait; to rest
To be intermitted; to cease; as, the music pauses
To hesitate; to hold back; to delay
To stop in order to consider; hence, to consider; to reflect
To cause to stop or rest; -- used reflexively

pauxi.definition: A curassow (Ourax pauxi), which, in South America, is often domesticated

pavan.definition: A stately and formal Spanish dance for which full state costume is worn; -- so called from the resemblance of its movements to those of the peacock

pave.definition: To lay or cover with stone, brick, or other material, so as to make a firm, level, or convenient surface for vehicles, horses, carriages, or persons on foot, to travel on; to floor with brick, stone, or other solid material; as, to pave a street; to pave a court
Fig.: To make smooth, easy, and safe; to prepare, as a path or way; as, to pave the way to promotion; to pave the way for an enterprise

paved.definition: covered with a firm surface; -- of pathways or roadways

pavement.definition: That with which anything is paved; a floor or covering of solid material, laid so as to make a hard and convenient surface for travel; a paved road or sidewalk; a decorative interior floor of tiles or colored bricks
To furnish with a pavement; to pave

paver.definition: One who paves; one who lays a pavement

pavesade.definition: A canvas screen, formerly sometimes extended along the side of a vessel in a naval engagement, to conceal from the enemy the operations on board

paviage.definition: A contribution or a tax for paving streets or highways

paviin.definition: A glucoside found in species of the genus Pavia of the Horse-chestnut family

pavilion.definition: A temporary movable habitation; a large tent; a marquee; esp., a tent raised on posts

A single body or mass of building, contained within simple walls and a single roof, whether insulated, as in the park or garden of a larger edifice, or united with other parts, and forming an angle or central feature of a large pile
A flag, colors, ensign, or banner
That part of a brilliant which lies between the girdle and collet. See Illust. of Brilliant
The auricle of the ear; also, the fimbriated extremity of the Fallopian tube
A covering; a canopy; figuratively, the sky
To furnish or cover with, or shelter in, a tent or tents

paving.definition: The act or process of laying a pavement, or covering some place with a pavement

pavior.definition: A machine for laying pavement; a rammer for driving paving stones
A brick or slab used for paving

pavis.definition: A large heavy oblong shield covering the whole body, carried by a pavisor, who sometimes also screened an archer with it.  It was originally carried but sometimes set up in permanent position

pavisor.definition: A soldier who carried a pavise

pavlovian.definition: Of or pertaining to Ivan Pavlov, or the principles of conditioned responses that he investigated; as, a Pavlovian response

pavo.definition: A genus of birds, including the peacocks
The Peacock, a constellation of the southern hemisphere

pavon.definition: A small triangular flag, esp. one attached to a knight's lance; a pennon

pavonian.definition: Of or pertaining to a peacock

pavonine.definition: Like, or pertaining to, the genus Pavo
Characteristic of a peacock; resembling the tail of a peacock, as in colors; iridescent

paw.definition: The foot of a quadruped having claws, as the lion, dog, cat, etc
To draw the forefoot along the ground; to beat or scrape with the forefoot
To pass the paw over; to stroke or handle with the paws; hence, to handle fondly or rudely
To scrape or beat with the forefoot

pawl.definition: A pivoted tongue, or sliding bolt, on one part of a machine, adapted to fall into notches, or interdental spaces, on another part, as a ratchet wheel, in such a manner as to permit motion in one direction and prevent it in the reverse, as in a windlass; a catch, click, or detent. See Illust. of Ratchet Wheel
To stop with a pawl; to drop the pawls off

pawn.definition: A man or piece of the lowest rank
Anything delivered or deposited as security, as for the payment of money borrowed, or of a debt; a pledge. See Pledge, n., 1
State of being pledged; a pledge for the fulfillment of a promise
A stake hazarded in a wager
To give or deposit in pledge, or as security for the payment of money borrowed; to put in pawn; to pledge; as, to pawn one's watch
To pledge for the fulfillment of a promise; to stake; to risk; to wager; to hazard

pawnbroker.definition: One who makes a business of lending money on the security of personal property pledged or deposited in his keeping

pawnee.definition: One or two whom a pledge is delivered as security; one who takes anything in pawn

pawnees.definition: A tribe of Indians (called also Loups) who formerly occupied the region of the Platte river, but now (1890) live mostly in the Indian Territory (Oklahoma).  The term is often used in a wider sense to include also the related tribes of Rickarees and Wichitas.  Called also Pani

pawner.definition: One who pawns or pledges anything as security for the payment of borrowed money or of a debt

pax.definition: The kiss of peace; also, the embrace in the sanctuary now substituted for it at High Mass in Roman Catholic churches

A tablet or board, on which is a representation of Christ, of the Virgin Mary, or of some saint and which, in the Mass, was kissed by the priest and then by the people, in mediæval times; an osculatory.  It is still used in communities, confraternities, etc
Friendship, or a friend; -- esp. in the phrases to make pax with, to make friends with, to be good pax, to be good friends; also, truce; -- used esp. interjectionally

paxillus.definition: One of a peculiar kind of spines covering the surface of certain starfishes.  They are pillarlike, with a flattened summit which is covered with minute spinules or granules. See Illustration in Appendix

paxwax.definition: The strong ligament of the back of the neck in quadrupeds.  It connects the back of the skull with dorsal spines of the cervical vertebræ, and helps to support the head. Called also paxywaxy and packwax

pay.definition: To cover, as bottom of a vessel, a seam, a spar, etc., with tar or pitch, or waterproof composition of tallow, resin, etc.; to smear

To satisfy, or content; specifically, to satisfy (another person) for service rendered, property delivered, etc.; to discharge one's obligation to; to make due return to; to compensate; to remunerate; to recompense; to requite; as, to pay workmen or servants
Hence, figuratively: To compensate justly; to requite according to merit; to reward; to punish; to retort or retaliate upon

To discharge, as a debt, demand, or obligation, by giving or doing what is due or required; to deliver the amount or value of to the person to whom it is owing; to discharge a debt by delivering (money owed)
To discharge or fulfill, as a duy; to perform or render duty, as that which has been promised
To give or offer, without an implied obligation; as, to pay attention; to pay a visit
To give a recompense; to make payment, requital, or satisfaction; to discharge a debt

Hence, to make or secure suitable return for expense or trouble; to be remunerative or profitable; to be worth the effort or pains required; as, it will pay to ride; it will pay to wait; politeness always pays

An equivalent or return for money due, goods purchased, or services performed; salary or wages for work or service; compensation; recompense; payment; hire; as, the pay of a clerk; the pay of a soldier

pay cerps.definition: A staff corps in the United States navy, consisting of pay directors, pay inspectors, paymasters, passed assistant paymasters, and assistant paymasters, having relative rank from captain to ensign, respectively

pay dirt.definition: Earth, rock, etc., which yields a profit to the miner
a discovery, especially after an exploratory process, which yields a profit or sought-after benefit; -- used especially in the phrase “to hit pay dirt”

pay streak.definition: The zone, parallel to the walls of a vein, in which the ore is concentrated, or any narrow streak of paying ore in less valuable material
A stratum of oil sand thick enough to make a well pay

payable.definition: That may, can, or should be paid; suitable to be paid; justly due
That may be discharged or settled by delivery of value

payables.definition: money that a person or organization expects and is obligated to pay on notes and accounts

paye.definition: the British system of withholding tax

payee.definition: The person to whom money is to be, or has been, paid; the person named in a bill or note, to whom, or to whose order, the amount is promised or directed to be paid. See Bill of exchange, under Bill

payer.definition: One who pays; specifically, the person by whom a bill or note has been, or should be, paid

paying.definition: yielding material gain or profit; as, paying investments
providing a salary for work performed; as, a paying job
synonyms: Syn. -- compensable, remunerative, salaried, stipendiary, gainful.

payload.definition: The part of a missile or torpedo that carries the explosive charge
The goods carried by a large vehicle
synonyms: Syn. -- cargo, lading, freight, load, loading, shipment, consignment.

paymaster.definition: One who pays; one who compensates, rewards, or requites; specifically, an officer or agent of a government, a corporation, or an employer, whose duty it is to pay salaries, wages, etc., and keep account of the same

paymaster-general.definition: In the United States army, an officer of the rank of brigadier general, who commands the pay department, which is charged with the payment of the officers and men
In Great Britain, an officer of the Treasury who makes all payments and disbursements, civil as well as military. He is a member of the ministry, but not of the cabinet

payment.definition: The act of paying, or giving compensation; the discharge of a debt or an obligation
That which is paid; the thing given in discharge of a debt, or an obligation, or in fulfillment of a promise; reward; recompense; requital; return

payndemain.definition: The finest and whitest bread made in the Middle Ages; -- called also paynemain, payman

payne's process.definition: A process for preserving timber and rendering it incombustible by impregnating it successively with solutions of sulphate of iron and calcium chloride in vacuo

paynize.definition: To treat or preserve, as wood, by a process resembling kyanizing

payoff.definition: profit or gain from an action; -- used broadly; as, lots of effort with little payoff
The act of giving or receiving money or other valuable consideration as a bribe
The money or item given as a bribe
The climax or final result of an event or endeavor; the denoument of a narrative

paysheet.definition: the total amount of money paid in wages; as, the company had a large paysheet
a list of employees and their salaries; as, the company had a long paysheet

payslip.definition: a slip of paper included with a person's salary payment, that records how much money the person has earned and how much tax or insurance etc. has been taken out

paytine.definition: An alkaloid obtained from a white bark resembling that of the cinchona, first brought from Payta, in Peru

pbs.definition: Phosphate-buffered saline, a saline solution containing a phosphate buffer
Public Broadcasting System; a system of non-profit radio and television broadcasting stations

pc.definition: A personal computer; a computer{2} designed for use by one person at a time; -- contrasted with shared-time computers such as mainframes and minicomputers, which may be accessed by multiple users each operating from a different input device (in the 1990's, usually a terminal).  A personal computer typically uses a microprocessor for its CPU

pcp.definition: A drug originally taken in the form of powder ("dust") for its hallucinogenic effects

pct.definition: Percent; a fractional proportion, multiplied by 100

pd.definition: The chemical symbol for palladium, an element of the platinum group, of atomic number 46

pe.definition: The 17th letter of the Hebrew alphabet

pe-tsai.definition: A plant with an elongated celerylike head of broadstalked leaves used as a vegetable in east Asia
synonyms: Syn. -- Chinese cabbage, celery cabbage, napa, Brassica rapa pekinensis.

pea.definition: The sliding weight on a steelyard
A plant, and its fruit, of the genus Pisum, of many varieties, much cultivated for food.  It has a papilionaceous flower, and the pericarp is a legume, popularly called a pod

A name given, especially in the Southern States, to the seed of several leguminous plants (species of Dolichos, Cicer, Abrus, etc.) esp. those having a scar (hilum) of a different color from the rest of the seed

pea-jacket.definition: A thick loose double-breasted woolen jacket, or coat, commonly worn by sailors in cold weather
synonyms: Syn. -- pea coat, peacoat, pea jacket.

peabird.definition: The wryneck; -- so called from its note

peabody bird.definition: An American sparrow (Zonotrichia albicollis) having a conspicuous white throat. The name is imitative of its note. Called also White-throated sparrow

peace.definition: A state of quiet or tranquillity; freedom from disturbance or agitation; calm; repose
To make or become quiet; to be silent; to stop

peace-loving.definition: Inclined or disposed to peace; as, peace-loving citizens.  Opposed to warlike or belligerent

peaceable.definition: Begin in or at peace; tranquil; quiet; free from, or not disposed to, war, disorder, or excitement; not quarrelsome

peacebreaker.definition: One who disturbs the public peace

peaceful.definition: Possessing or enjoying peace; not disturbed by war, tumult, agitation, anxiety, or commotion; quiet; tranquil; as, a peaceful time; a peaceful country; a peaceful end
Not disposed or tending to war, tumult or agitation; pacific; mild; calm; peaceable; as, peaceful words

peacekeeper.definition: a member of a military force that is assigned (often with international sanction) to preserve peace in a trouble area
someone who keeps peace; as, she's the peacekeeper in that family
the pistol of a law officer in the old West

peacemaker.definition: One who makes peace by reconciling parties that are at variance

peacenik.definition: someone who prefers negotiations to armed conflict in the conduct of foreign relations

peacetime.definition: A period of time during which there is no war; as, civil liberties are valued more highly in peacetime than in war

peach.definition: To accuse of crime; to inform against
To turn informer; to betray one's accomplice
A well-known high-flavored juicy fruit, containing one or two seeds in a hard almond-like endocarp or stone.  In the wild stock the fruit is hard and inedible
The tree (Prunus Persica syn. Amygdalus Persica) which bears the peach fruit
The pale red color of the peach blossom, or the light pinkish yellow of the peach fruit

peach-colored.definition: Of the color of a peach blossom

peachblow.definition: Of the delicate purplish pink color likened to that of peach blooms; -- applied esp. to a Chinese porcelain, small specimens of which bring great prices in the Western countries

peachwood.definition: A tropical tree Caesalpinia echinata, having a prickly trunk; its heavy red wood yields a red dye and is used for cabinetry
The heavy red wood of the Caesalpinia echinata; brazilwood; pernambuco wood

peacoat.definition: A thick loose double-breasted woolen jacket, or coat, commonly worn by sailors in cold weather; a pea-jacket
synonyms: Syn. -- pea coat, peacoat, pea jacket, peajacket, pea-jacket.

peacock.definition: The male of any pheasant of the genus Pavo, of which at least two species are known, native of Southern Asia and the East Indies
In common usage, the species in general or collectively; a peafowl

peacock throne.definition: A famous throne formerly of the kings of Delhi, India, but since 1739, when it was carried off by Nadir Shah, held by the shahs of Persia (now Iran); -- so called from its bearing a fully expanded peacock's tail done in gems
The office or position of the Shah of Iran; as, to ascend the Peacock Throne

peafowl.definition: The peacock or peahen; any species of Pavo

peag.definition: A kind of aboriginal shell money, or wampum, of the Atlantic coast of the United States; -- originally applied only to polished white cylindrical beads.  See also wampum

peagrit.definition: A coarse pisolitic limestone. See Pisolite

peak.definition: A point; the sharp end or top of anything that terminates in a point; as, the peak, or front, of a cap
The top, or one of the tops, of a hill, mountain, or range, ending in a point; often, the whole hill or mountain, esp. when isolated; as, the Peak of Teneriffe
The upper aftermost corner of a fore-and-aft sail; -- used in many combinations; as, peak-halyards, peak-brails, etc
To rise or extend into a peak or point; to form, or appear as, a peak

To achieve a maximum of numerical value, intensity of activity, popularity, or other characteristic, followed by a decline; as, the stock market peaked in January; his performance as a pitcher peaked in 1990; sales of the XTX model peaked at 20,000 per year
To acquire sharpness of figure or features; hence, to look thin or sickly
To raise to a position perpendicular, or more nearly so; as, to peak oars, to hold them upright; to peak a gaff or yard, to set it nearer the perpendicular

peaked.definition: Pointed; ending in a point; as, a peaked roof

peakish.definition: Of or relating to a peak; or to peaks; belonging to a mountainous region
Having features thin or sharp, as from sickness; hence, sickly

peal.definition: A small salmon; a grilse; a sewin
A loud sound, or a succession of loud sounds, as of bells, thunder, cannon, shouts, of a multitude, etc
A set of bells tuned to each other according to the diatonic scale; also, the changes rung on a set of bells
To utter or give out loud sounds
To utter or give forth loudly; to cause to give out loud sounds; to noise abroad
To assail with noise or loud sounds

peal out.definition: To give off a loud pealing sound; to peal

To accelerate quickly from a stop in a vehicle, especially an automobile, so that the tires grind against the pavement and make a squealing noise while accelerating; -- sometimes performed by young drivers for showy display

pean.definition: One of the furs, the ground being sable, and the spots or tufts or
A song of praise and triumph. See Pæan

peanism.definition: The song or shout of praise, of battle, or of triumph

peanut.definition: The fruit of a trailing leguminous plant (Arachis hypogæa); also, the plant itself, which is widely cultivated for its fruit

peanut butter.definition: A paste made by mixing ground fresh roasted peanuts with a small quantity of water or oil, and used chiefly as a relish on sandwiches, etc

peanut gallery.definition: The cheapest seats in a theater, being typically those farthest from the stage, as in the uppermost balcony
In a television show for children, the section where visiting children sit as guests during the performance
Any group of children, or the chidren in a group of people; as, let's have no noise from the peanut gallery

pear.definition: The fleshy pome, or fruit, of a rosaceous tree (Pyrus communis), cultivated in many varieties in temperate climates; also, the tree which bears this fruit. See Pear family, below

pear-shaped.definition: Of the form of a pear

pearl.definition: A shelly concretion, usually rounded, and having a brilliant luster, with varying tints, found in the mantle, or between the mantle and shell, of certain bivalve mollusks, especially in the pearl oysters and river mussels, and sometimes in certain univalves.  It is usually due to a secretion of shelly substance around some irritating foreign particle.  Its substance is the same as nacre, or mother-of-pearl
Hence, figuratively, something resembling a pearl; something very precious
A fish allied to the turbot; the brill
One of the circle of tubercles which form the bur on a deer's antler
A whitish speck or film on the eye
A capsule of gelatin or similar substance containing some liquid for medicinal application, as ether
A size of type, between agate and diamond
Of or pertaining to pearl or pearls; made of pearls, or of mother-of-pearl
To set or adorn with pearls, or with mother-of-pearl. Used also figuratively
To cause to resemble pearls; to make into small round grains; as, to pearl barley
To dive or hunt for pearls; as, to go pearling

pearl-eyed.definition: Having a pearly speck in the eye; afflicted with a cataract or cataracts

pearlaceous.definition: Resembling pearl or mother-of-pearl; pearly in quality or appearance
synonyms: Syn. -- iridescent, nacreous, opalescent, opaline, pearlaceous.

pearlash.definition: A white amorphous or granular substance which consists principally of potassium carbonate, and has a strong alkaline reaction.  It is obtained by lixiviating wood ashes, and evaporating the lye, and has been an important source of potassium compounds.  It is used in making soap, glass, etc

pearler.definition: A diver who searches for molluscs containing pearls; a pearl diver

pearlescent.definition: Having an iridescent pearl-like surface, giving a play of lustrous rainbowlike colors; nacreous; pearlaceous
synonyms: Syn. -- iridescent, nacreous, opalescent, opaline, pearlaceous.

pearlfish.definition: Any fish whose scales yield a pearl-like pigment used in manufacturing artificial pearls, as the bleak, and whitebait

pearlins.definition: A kind of lace of silk or thread

pearlite.definition: A glassy volcanic rock of a grayish color and pearly luster, often having a spherulitic concretionary structure due to the curved cracks produced by contraction in cooling. See Illust. under Perlitic

pearlwort.definition: A name given to several species of Sagina, low and inconspicuous herbs of the Chickweed family

pearly.definition: Containing pearls; abounding with, or yielding, pearls; as, pearly shells
Resembling pearl or pearls; clear; pure; transparent; iridescent; as, the pearly dew or flood

pearly everlasting.definition: an American everlasting (Anaphalis margaritacea) having foliage with soft wooly hairs and corymbose heads with pearly-white scarious involucres

pearly-white.definition: White like a pearl; very white

pearmain.definition: The name of several kinds of apples; as, the blue pearmain, winter pearmain, and red pearmain

peart.definition: Active; lively; brisk; smart; -- often applied to convalescents; as, she is quite peart to-day

peasant.definition: A countryman; a rustic; especially, one of the lowest class of tillers of the soil in European countries

peasantry.definition: Peasants, collectively; the body of rustics

peascod.definition: The legume or pericarp, or the pod, of the pea

pease.definition: A plural form of Pea. See the Note under Pea

peat.definition: A small person; a pet; -- sometimes used contemptuously

A substance of vegetable origin, consisting of roots and fibers, moss, etc., in various stages of decomposition, and found, as a kind of turf or bog, usually in low situations, where it is always more or less saturated with water.  It is often dried and used for fuel

peaty.definition: Composed of peat; abounding in peat; resembling peat

peavey.definition: A cant hook having the end of its lever armed with a spike; it is used for handling logs

peba.definition: An armadillo (Tatusia novemcincta) which is found from Texas to Paraguay; -- called also tatouhou

pebble.definition: A small roundish piece of stone; especially, a stone worn and rounded by the action of water; a pebblestone
Transparent and colorless rock crystal; as, Brazilian pebble; -- so called by opticians
To grain (leather) so as to produce a surface covered with small rounded prominences

pebrine.definition: An epidemic disease of the silkworm, characterized by the presence of minute vibratory corpuscles in the blood

pecan.definition: A species of hickory (Carya olivæformis), growing in North America, chiefly in the Mississippi valley and in Texas, where it is one of the largest of forest trees; also, its fruit, a smooth, oblong nut, an inch or an inch and a half long, with a thin shell and well-flavored meat

peccability.definition: The state or quality of being peccable; liability to sin

peccable.definition: Liable to sin; subject to transgress the divine law

peccadillo.definition: A slight trespass or offense; a petty crime; a trifling fault

peccancy.definition: The quality or state of being peccant

peccant.definition: Sinning; guilty of transgression; criminal; as, peccant angels

peccary.definition: A pachyderm of the genus Dicotyles

peccavi.definition: I have sinned; -- used colloquially to express confession or acknowledgment of an offense; -- used rarely, superseded by the approximate equivalent mea culpa

peck.definition: The fourth part of a bushel; a dry measure of eight quarts; as, a peck of wheat
A great deal; a large or excessive quantity
To strike with the beak; to thrust the beak into; as, a bird pecks a tree
Hence: To strike, pick, thrust against, or dig into, with a pointed instrument; especially, to strike, pick, etc., with repeated quick movements
To seize and pick up with the beak, or as with the beak; to bite; to eat; -- often with up
To make, by striking with the beak or a pointed instrument; as, to peck a hole in a tree
To make strokes with the beak, or with a pointed instrument
To pick up food with the beak; hence, to eat
A quick, sharp stroke, as with the beak of a bird or a pointed instrument

pecker.definition: One who, or that which, pecks; specif., a bird that pecks holes in trees; a woodpecker
An instrument for pecking; a pick
The penis; -- an obscene term for the male sexual organ
synonyms: Syn. -- penis, cock, prick, tool, peter, dick, shaft [all but the first considered obscene].

pecopteris.definition: An extensive genus of fossil ferns; -- so named from the regular comblike arrangement of the leaflets

pecora.definition: An extensive division of ruminants, including the antelopes, deer, and cattle

pecs.definition: The pectoral muscles; -- a contraction used by body-building and health enthusiasts.   Used similarly to abs and delts

pecten.definition: A vascular pigmented membrane projecting into the vitreous humor within the globe of the eye in birds, and in many reptiles and fishes; -- also called marsupium
Any species of bivalve mollusks of the genus Pecten, and numerous allied genera (family Pectinidæ); a scallop. See Scallop
The comb of a scorpion. See Comb, 4 (b)

pectic.definition: Of or pertaining to pectin; specifically, designating an acid obtained from ordinary vegetable jelly (pectin) as an amorphous substance, tough and horny when dry, but gelatinous when moist

pectin.definition: One of a series of carbohydrates, commonly called vegetable jelly, found very widely distributed in the vegetable kingdom, especially in ripe fleshy fruits, as apples, cranberries, etc.  It is extracted as variously colored, translucent substances, which are soluble in hot water but become viscous on cooling.  It is commonly used in making fruit jelllies

pectinal.definition: Of or pertaining to a comb; resembling a comb
A fish whose bones resemble comb teeth

pectinate.definition: Resembling the teeth of a comb
Having very narrow, close divisions, in arrangement and regularity resembling those of a comb; comblike; as, a pectinate leaf; pectinated muscles.  See Illust. (e) of Antennæ

pectination.definition: The state of being pectinated; that which is pectinated
The act of combing; the combing of the head

pectineal.definition: Of or pertaining to the pecten

pectinibranch.definition: One of the Pectinibranchiata.  Also used adjectively

pectinibranchiata.definition: A division of Gastropoda, including those that have a comblike gill upon the neck

pectize.definition: To congeal; to change into a gelatinous mass

pectolite.definition: A whitish mineral occurring in radiated or fibrous crystalline masses.  It is a hydrous silicate of lime and soda

pectoral.definition: Of or pertaining to the breast, or chest; as, the pectoral muscles
Relating to, or good for, diseases of the chest or lungs; as, a pectoral remedy
Having the breast conspicuously colored; as, the pectoral sandpiper
A covering or protecting for the breast
A breastplate, esp. that worn by the Jewish high person
A medicine for diseases of the chest organs, especially the lungs

pectoriloquial.definition: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, pectoriloquy

pectoriloquy.definition: The distinct articulation of the sounds of a patient's voice, heard on applying the ear to the chest in auscultation.  It usually indicates some morbid change in the lungs or pleural cavity

pectose.definition: An amorphous carbohydrate found in the vegetable kingdom, esp. in unripe fruits.  It is associated with cellulose, and is converted into substances of the pectin group

pectosic.definition: Of, pertaining to, resembling, or derived from, pectose; specifically, designating an acid supposed to constitute largely ordinary pectin or vegetable jelly

pectostraca.definition: A degenerate order of Crustacea, including the Rhizocephala and Cirripedia

pectous.definition: Of, pertaining to, or consisting of, pectose

peculate.definition: To appropriate to one's own use the property of the public; to steal public moneys intrusted to one's care; to embezzle

peculation.definition: The act or practice of peculating, or of defrauding the public by appropriating to one's own use the money or goods intrusted to one's care for management or disbursement; embezzlement

peculiar.definition: One's own; belonging solely or especially to an individual; not possessed by others; of private, personal, or characteristic possession and use; not owned in common or in participation
Unusual; singular; rare; strange; as, the sky had a peculiar appearance
That which is peculiar; a sole or exclusive property; a prerogative; a characteristic
A particular parish or church which is exempt from the jurisdiction of the ordinary

peculiarity.definition: The quality or state of being peculiar; individuality; singularity
That which is peculiar; a special and distinctive characteristic or habit; particularity

peculiarize.definition: To make peculiar; to set apart or assign, as an exclusive possession

peculiarly.definition: In a peculiar manner; particularly; in a rare and striking degree; unusually

peculiarness.definition: The quality or state of being peculiar; peculiarity

peculium.definition: The saving of a son or a slave with the father's or master's consent; a little property or stock of one's own; any exclusive personal or separate property
A special fund for private and personal uses

pecuniarily.definition: In a pecuniary manner; as regards money

pecuniary.definition: Relating to money; monetary; as, a pecuniary penalty; a pecuniary reward

ped.definition: A basket; a hammer; a pannier

pedage.definition: A toll or tax paid by passengers, entitling them to safe-conduct and protection

pedagogic.definition: Of or pertaining to a pedagogue; suited to, or characteristic of, a pedagogue

pedagogics.definition: The science or art of teaching; the principles and rules of teaching; pedagogy

pedagogism.definition: The system, occupation, character, or manner of pedagogues

pedagogue.definition: A slave who led his master's children to school, and had the charge of them generally
A teacher of children; one whose occupation is to teach the young; a schoolmaster
One who by teaching has become formal, positive, or pedantic in his ways; one who has the manner of a schoolmaster; a pedant

pedal.definition: Of or pertaining to the foot, or to feet, literally or figuratively; specifically (Zool.), pertaining to the foot of a mollusk; as, the pedal ganglion
Of or pertaining to a pedal; having pedals
A lever or key acted on by the foot, as in the pianoforte to raise the dampers, or in the organ to open and close certain pipes; a treadle, as in a lathe or a bicycle

pedaler.definition: a person who rides a pedal-driven vehicle

pedalian.definition: Relating to the foot, or to a metrical foot; pedal

pedality.definition: The act of measuring by paces

pedaller.definition: a person who rides a pedal-driven vehicle; a pedaler

pedant.definition: One who puts on an air of learning; one who makes a vain display of learning; a pretender to superior knowledge

pedantic.definition: Of or pertaining to a pedant; characteristic of, or resembling, a pedant; ostentatious of learning; as, a pedantic writer; a pedantic description; a pedantical affectation

pedantism.definition: The office, disposition, or act of a pedant; pedantry

pedantize.definition: To play the pedant; to use pedantic expressions

pedantry.definition: The act, character, or manners of a pedant; vain ostentation of learning

pedanty.definition: An assembly or clique of pedants

pedarian.definition: One of a class eligible to the office of senator, but not yet chosen, who could sit and speak in the senate, but could not vote; -- so called because he might indicate his opinion by walking over to the side of the party he favored when a vote was taken

pedata.definition: An order of holothurians, including those that have ambulacral suckers, or feet, and an internal gill

pedate.definition: Palmate, with the lateral lobes cleft into two or more segments; -- said of a leaf

pedatifid.definition: Cleft in a pedate manner, but having the lobes distinctly connected at the base; -- said of a leaf

peddle.definition: To travel about with wares for sale; to go from place to place, or from house to house, for the purpose of retailing goods; as, to peddle without a license
To do a small business; to be busy about trifles; to piddle
To sell from place to place; to retail by carrying around from customer to customer; to hawk; hence, to retail in very small quantities; as, to peddle vegetables or tinware

peddler.definition: One who peddles; a traveling trader; one who travels about, retailing small wares; a hawker

peddlery.definition: The trade, or the goods, of a peddler; hawking; small retail business, like that of a peddler

peddling.definition: Petty; insignificant; trifling; paltry; piddling; -- now less common than piddling
synonyms: Syn. -- petty; insignificant; trifling; paltry; piddling.

pederast.definition: One guilty of pederasty; a sodomite

pederasty.definition: Sexual activity between two males; sodomy; the “crime against nature”; -- used especially when one partner is a boy

pederero.definition: A term formerly applied to a short piece of chambered ordnance

pedestal.definition: The base or foot of a column, statue, vase, lamp, or the like; the part on which an upright work stands.  It consists of three parts, the base, the die or dado, and the cornice or surbase molding. See Illust. of Column

A short free-standing column or column-like object designed to support a work of art or other object; a column serving the same function as the base of a statue.  It may be made of wood, marble, or other suitable material
A part of a desk which contains a frame and drawers, stands on the floor, and provides support for the desk surface.  There may be zero, one, or two such pedestals in a desk
A casting secured to the frame of a truck and forming a jaw for holding a journal box

pedestaled.definition: Placed on, or supported by, a pedestal; figuratively, exalted

pedestrial.definition: Of or pertaining to the feet; employing the foot or feet

pedestrian.definition: Going on foot; performed on foot; as, a pedestrian journey
Lacking in distinction or imaginativeness; ordinary; commonplace; dull; insipid; prosaic; as, pedestrian prose
A walker; one who journeys on foot; a foot traveler; specif., a professional walker or runner

pedestrianism.definition: The act, art, or practice of a pedestrian; walking or running; traveling or racing on foot

pedestrianize.definition: To practice walking; to travel on foot

pedetentous.definition: Proceeding step by step; advancing cautiously

pedi-.definition: Combining forms from L. pes, pedis, foot, as pedipalp, pedireme, pedometer

pedial.definition: Pertaining to the foot, or to any organ called a foot; pedal

pediatric.definition: Pertaining to the care and medical treatment of children

pediatrics.definition: That branch of medical science which treats of the hygiene and diseases of infants and children

pedicab.definition: a tricycle (usually propelled by pedalling); used in the Orient for transporting passengers for hire; as, boys who once pulled rickshaws now pedal pedicabs

pedicel.definition: A stalk which supports one flower or fruit, whether solitary or one of many ultimate divisions of a common peduncle. See Peduncle, and Illust. of Flower
A slender stem by which certain of the lower animals or their eggs are attached. See Illust. of Aphis lion
The ventral part of each side of the neural arch connecting with the centrum of a vertebra

pedicellaria.definition: A peculiar forcepslike organ which occurs in large numbers upon starfishes and echini. Those of starfishes have two movable jaws, or blades, and are usually nearly, or quite, sessile; those of echini usually have three jaws and a pedicel. See Illustration in Appendix

pedicellate.definition: Having a pedicel; supported by a pedicel

pedicellina.definition: A genus of Bryozoa, of the order Entoprocta, having a bell-shaped body supported on a slender pedicel. See Illust. under Entoprocta

pedicular.definition: Of or pertaining to lice; having the lousy distemper (phthiriasis); lousy

pediculate.definition: Of or pertaining to the Pediculati

pediculati.definition: An order of fishes including the anglers. See Illust. of Angler and Batfish

pediculina.definition: A division of parasitic hemipterous insects, including the true lice. See Illust. in Appendix

pediculus.definition: A genus of wingless parasitic Hemiptera, including the common lice of man. See Louse

pedicure.definition: Professional care of the feet, toes, and toenails
A single treatment of the feet, toes, and toenails
One who cares for the feet and nails; a chiropodist

pedigerous.definition: Bearing or having feet or legs

pedigree.definition: A line of ancestors; descent; lineage; genealogy; a register or record of a line of ancestors
A record of the lineage or strain of an animal, as of a horse

pedigree clause.definition: A clause sometimes inserted in contracts or specifications, requiring that a material of construction, as cement, must be of a brand that has stood the test of a specified number of years' use in an important public work

pediluvy.definition: The bathing of the feet, a bath for the feet

pedimana.definition: A division of marsupials, including the opossums

pedimanous.definition: Having feet resembling hands, or with the first toe opposable, as the opossums and monkeys

pediment.definition: Originally, in classical architecture, the triangular space forming the gable of a simple roof; hence, a similar form used as a decoration over porticoes, doors, windows, etc.; also, a rounded or broken frontal having a similar position and use. See Temple

pedimental.definition: Of or pertaining to a pediment

pedioecetes.definition: A genus of fowl including the sharp-tailed grouse (Pedioecetes phasianellus, also called the prairie chicken)

pedionomus.definition: A genus of birds including the plains wanderer (Pedionomus torquatus) of New South Wales as its only species.  It is the only genus of the family Pedionomidae of the order Passeriformes and the plains wanderer is the only species in the family.  The total world population (as of ca. 2000) is estimated to be 5 to 10 thousand

pedipalpi.definition: A division of Arachnida, including the whip scorpions (Thelyphonus) and allied forms.  Sometimes used in a wider sense to include also the true scorpions

pedipalpous.definition: Pertaining to, or resembling, the pedipalps

pedipalpus.definition: One of the second pair of mouth organs of arachnids.  In some they are leglike, but in others, as the scorpion, they terminate in a claw

pedireme.definition: A crustacean, some of whose feet serve as oars

pedobaptism.definition: The baptism of infants or of small children

pedobaptist.definition: One who advocates or practices infant baptism

pedograph.definition: An instrument carried by a pedestrian for automatically making a topographical record of the ground covered during a journey

pedomancy.definition: Divination by examining the soles of the feet

pedometer.definition: An instrument for including the number of steps in walking, and so ascertaining the distance passed over.  It is usually in the form of a watch; an oscillating weight by the motion of the body causes the index to advance a certain distance at each step

pedometric.definition: Pertaining to, or measured by, a pedometer

pedomotive.definition: Moved or worked by the action of the foot or feet on a pedal or treadle

pedophilia.definition: A sexual perversion in which children rather than adults most strongly excite sexual desire, and are used as sexual partners

pedotrophy.definition: The art of nourishing children properly

pedrail.definition: A device intended to replace the wheel of a self-propelled vehicle for use on rough roads and to approximate to the smoothness in running of a wheel on a metal track.  The tread consists of a number of rubber shod feet which are connected by ball-and-socket joints to the ends of sliding spokes.  Each spoke has attached to it a small roller which in its turn runs under a short pivoted rail controlled by a powerful set of springs. This arrangement permits the feet to accomodate themselves to obstacles even such as steps or stairs. The pedrail was invented by one B. J. Diplock of London, Eng

pedro.definition: The five of trumps in certain varieties of auction pitch

peduncle.definition: The stem or stalk that supports the flower or fruit of a plant, or a cluster of flowers or fruits
A sort of stem by which certain shells and barnacles are attached to other objects. See Illust. of Barnacle
A band of nervous or fibrous matter connecting different parts of the brain; as, the peduncles of the cerebellum; the peduncles of the pineal gland

peduncled.definition: Having a peduncle; supported on a peduncle; pedunculate

peduncular.definition: Of or pertaining to a peduncle; growing from a peduncle; as, a peduncular tendril

pedunculata.definition: A division of Cirripedia, including the stalked or goose barnacles

pedunculate.definition: Having a peduncle; growing on a peduncle; as, a pedunculate flower; a pedunculate eye, as in a lobster

pee.definition: Bill of an anchor. See Peak, 3 (c)
The act of urinating; -- used in the informal take a pee, meaning, to urinate

peeing.definition: Urination; -- an informal term; as, he doesn't like peeing out of doors

peek.definition: To look surreptitiously, or with the eyes half closed, or through a crevice; to peep

peel.definition: A small tower, fort, or castle; a keep

A spadelike implement, variously used, as for removing loaves of bread from a baker's oven; also, a T-shaped implement used by printers and bookbinders for hanging wet sheets of paper on lines or poles to dry. Also, the blade of an oar
To plunder; to pillage; to rob
To strip off the skin, bark, or rind of; to strip by drawing or tearing off the skin, bark, husks, etc.; to flay; to decorticate; as, to peel an orange
To strip or tear off; to remove by stripping, as the skin of an animal, the bark of a tree, etc
To lose the skin, bark, or rind; to come off, as the skin, bark, or rind does; -- often used with an adverb; as, the bark peels easily or readily
To strip naked; to disrobe.  Often used with down
The skin or rind; as, the peel of an orange

peele.definition: A graceful and swift South African antelope (Pelea capreola).  The hair is woolly, and ash-gray on the back and sides.  The horns are black, long, slender, straight, nearly smooth, and very sharp.  Called also rheeboc, rhebuck, rhebok, and rehboc

synonyms: Syn. -- bare-assed, bare-ass, in the altogether, in the buff, in the raw, raw, naked as a jaybird, stark naked.

peeler.definition: A nickname for a policeman; -- so called from Sir Robert Peel

peen.definition: A round-edged, or hemispherical, end to the head of a hammer or sledge, used to stretch or bend metal by indentation
To draw, bend, or straighten, as metal, by blows with the peen of a hammer or sledge

peep.definition: To cry, as a chicken hatching or newly hatched; to chirp; to cheep
To begin to appear; to look forth from concealment; to make the first appearance; as, the sun peeped over the eastern hills
To look cautiously or slyly; to peer, as through a crevice; to pry
The cry of a young chicken; a chirp
A sly look; a look as through a crevice, or from a place of concealment
Any small sandpiper, as the least sandpiper (Trigna minutilla)

peep sight.definition: An adjustable piece, pierced with a small hole to peep through in aiming, attached to a rifle or other firearm near the breech; -- distinguished from an open sight

peeper.definition: A chicken just breaking the shell; a young bird
One who peeps; a prying person; a spy
The eye; as, to close the peepers

peephole.definition: A hole, or crevice, through which one may peep without being discovered

peepul.definition: A sacred tree (Ficus religiosa) of the Buddhists, a kind of fig tree which attains great size and venerable age; it lacks the prop roots of the banyan.  See Bo tree
synonyms: Syn. -- pipal, peepul, peepul tree, pipal tree, pipul, sacred fig, bo tree, Ficus religiosa.

peer.definition: To come in sight; to appear
To look narrowly or curiously or intently; to peep; as, the peering day
One of the same rank, quality, endowments, character, etc.; an equal; a match; a mate
A comrade; a companion; a fellow; an associate
A nobleman; a member of one of the five degrees of the British nobility, namely, duke, marquis, earl, viscount, baron; as, a peer of the realm
To be, or to assume to be, equal

peerage.definition: The rank or dignity of a peer
The body of peers; the nobility, collectively

peeress.definition: The wife of a peer; a woman ennobled in her own right, or by right of marriage

peerless.definition: Having no peer or equal; matchless; superlative

peevish.definition: Habitually fretful; easily vexed or fretted; hard to please; apt to complain; querulous; petulant
Expressing fretfulness and discontent, or unjustifiable dissatisfaction; as, a peevish answer

peevishness.definition: The quality of being peevish; disposition to murmur; sourness of temper

peewit.definition: A large crested Old World plover having wattles and spurs; the pewit
synonyms: Syn. -- lapwing, green plover, pewit, peevit, peerwit.

peewit.definition: Any of several small olive-colored woodland flycatchers of eastern North America
synonyms: Syn. -- pewee, peewee, pewit, wood pewee, Contopus virens.

peg.definition: A small, pointed piece of wood, used in fastening boards together, in attaching the soles of boots or shoes, etc.; as, a shoe peg
A wooden pin, or nail, on which to hang things, as coats, etc.  Hence, colloquially and figuratively: A support; a reason; a pretext; as, a peg to hang a claim upon
One of the pins of a musical instrument, on which the strings are strained
One of the pins used for marking points on a cribbage board
A step; a degree; esp. in the slang phrase “To take one down a peg.”
A drink of spirits, usually whisky or brandy diluted with soda water
a hard throw, especially one made to put out a baserunner; as, the peg to the plate went wild
To put pegs into; to fasten the parts of with pegs; as, to peg shoes; to confine with pegs; to restrict or limit closely
To score with a peg, as points in the game; as, she pegged twelwe points
To identify; to recognize; as, she pegged him as a good carpenter; he was pegged as a blowhard as soon as he started speaking; he was pegged as a exceptional player even in high school
To throw (a ball); as, he pegged the runner out at second
To work diligently, as one who pegs shoes; -- usually with on, at, or away; as, to peg away at a task

pegador.definition: A species of remora (Echeneis naucrates). See Remora

pegasean.definition: Of or pertaining to Pegasus, or, figuratively, to poetry

pegasus.definition: A winged horse fabled to have sprung from the body of Medusa when she was slain.  He is noted for causing, with a blow of his hoof, Hippocrene, the inspiring fountain of the Muses, to spring from Mount Helicon.  On this account he is, in modern times, associated with the Muses, and with ideas of poetic inspiration
A northen constellation near the vernal equinoctial point.  Its three brightest stars, with the brightest star of Andromeda, form the square of Pegasus
A genus of small fishes, having large pectoral fins, and the body covered with hard, bony plates.  Several species are known from the East Indies and China

pegged.definition: Tapering toward teh bottom; as, pegged pants

pegging.definition: The act or process of fastening with pegs

pegm.definition: A sort of moving machine employed in the old pageants

pegmatitic.definition: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, pegmatite; as, the pegmatic structure of certain rocks resembling graphic granite

pehlevi.definition: An ancient Persian dialect in which words were partly represented by their Semitic equivalents.  It was in use from the 3d century (and perhaps earlier) to the middle of the 7th century, and later in religious writings

peignoir.definition: A woman's loose dressing sack; hence, a loose morning gown or wrapper

peirameter.definition: A dynamometer for measuring the force required to draw wheel carriages on roads of different constructions

peirastic.definition: Fitted for trial or test; experimental; tentative; treating of attempts

pejorative.definition: Implying or imputing evil; depreciatory; disparaging; unfavorable

pekinese.definition: a Chinese breed of small short-legged dogs with a long silky coat and broad flat muzzle

pelage.definition: The covering, or coat, of a mammal, whether of wool, fur, or hair

pelagian.definition: Of or pertaining to the sea; marine; pelagic; as, pelagian shells
A follower of Pelagius, a British monk, born in the later part of the 4th century, who denied the doctrines of hereditary sin, of the connection between sin and death, and of conversion through grace
Of or pertaining to Pelagius, or to his doctrines

pelagic.definition: Of or pertaining to the ocean; -- applied especially to animals that live at the surface of the ocean, away from the coast.  Compare benthic

pelargonic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid (called also nonoic acid) found in the leaves of the geranium (Pelargonium) and allied plants

pelargonium.definition: A large genus of plants of the order Geraniaceæ, differing from Geranium in having a spurred calyx and an irregular corolla

pelasgian.definition: Of or pertaining to the Pelasgians, an ancient people of Greece, of roving habits

pele's hair.definition: Glass threads or fibers formed by the wind from bits blown from frothy lava or from the tips of lava jets or from bits of liquid lava thrown into the air.  It often collects in thick masses resembling tow

pelecanidae.definition: A natural family of birds consisting of the pelicans

pelecaniformes.definition: Those birds that are related to the pelican; the Totipalmi

pelecoid.definition: A figure, somewhat hatched-shaped, bounded by a semicircle and two inverted quadrants, and equal in area to the square ABCD inclosed by the chords of the four quadrants

pelecypod.definition: A marine or freshwater mollusk having a soft body with platelike gills enclosed within two shells hinged together; a member of the Pelecypoda

pelerine.definition: A woman's cape; especially, a fur cape that is longer in front than behind

peleus.definition: A king of the Myrmidons and father of Achilles; he was the son of Aeachus

pelf.definition: Money; riches; lucre; gain; -- generally conveying the idea of something ill-gotten or worthless.  It has no plural

pelican.definition: Any large webfooted bird of the genus Pelecanus, of which about a dozen species are known.  They have an enormous bill, to the lower edge of which is attached a pouch in which captured fishes are temporarily stored
A retort or still having a curved tube or tubes leading back from the head to the body for continuous condensation and redistillation

pelicosauria.definition: A suborder of Theromorpha, including terrestrial reptiles from the Permian formation

peliom.definition: A variety of iolite, of a smoky blue color; pelioma

pelisse.definition: An outer garment for men or women, originally of fur, or lined with fur; a lady's or child's long outer garment, made of silk or other fabric

pell.definition: A skin or hide; a pelt
A roll of parchment; a parchment record

pellage.definition: A customs duty on skins of leather

pellagra.definition: An affection of the skin, characterized by redness, especially in exposed areas, scaling and shedding of the skin, and accompanied with severe gastrointestinal disturbance and nervous symptoms.  It is due to a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3; nicotinic acid) and protein in the diet, and may be caused by malnutrition, or, in some cases, by a heavy dependence on maize for food.  It was at one time (ca. 1890) endemic in Northern Italy, and was called Alpine scurvy.  It may also be caused by alcoholism or diease causing an impairment of nutrition.  It is also called St. Ignatius's itch, maidism, mal de la rosa, mal rosso, and psychoneurosis maidica. A variety of pellagra seen in children is called infantile pellagra or kwashiorkor

pellagrin.definition: One who is afficted with pellagra

pellagrous.definition: Pertaining to, or affected with, or attendant on, pellagra; as, pellagrous insanity

pellet.definition: A little ball; as, a pellet of wax on paper
A bullet; a ball for firearms
To form into small balls; to pelletize

pelleted.definition: Made of, or like, pellets; furnished with pellets

pelletise.definition: To form into small balls; as, to pelletize ore.  The spelling pelletise is mostly British

pellibranchiata.definition: A division of Nudibranchiata, in which the mantle itself serves as a gill

pellicle.definition: A thin film formed on the surface of an evaporating solution

pellicular.definition: Of or pertaining to a pellicle

pellile.definition: The redshank; -- so called from its note

pellitory.definition: The common name of the several species of the genus Parietaria, low, harmless weeds of the Nettle family; -- also called wall pellitory, and lichwort

A composite plant (Anacyclus Pyrethrum) of the Mediterranean region, having finely divided leaves and whitish flowers. The root is the officinal pellitory, and is used as an irritant and sialogogue. Called also bertram, and pellitory of Spain

pellmell.definition: In utter confusion; with confused violence

pellucid.definition: Transparent; clear; limpid; translucent; not opaque

pellucidity.definition: The quality or state of being pellucid; transparency; translucency; clearness; as, the pellucidity of the air

pelma.definition: The under surface of the foot

pelopium.definition: A supposed new metal found in columbite, afterwards shown to be identical with columbium, or niobium

peloponnesian.definition: Of or pertaining to the Peloponnesus, or southern peninsula of Greece

peloria.definition: Abnormal regularity; the state of certain flowers, which, being naturally irregular, have become regular through a symmetrical repetition of the special irregularity

pelorus.definition: An instrument similar to a mariner's compass, but without magnetic needles, and having two sight vanes by which bearings are taken, esp. such as cannot be taken by the compass

pelota.definition: A Basque, Spanish, and Spanish-American game played in a court, in which a ball is struck with a wickerwork racket

pelotage.definition: Packs or bales of Spanish wool

pelt.definition: The skin of a beast with the hair on; a raw or undressed hide; a skin preserved with the hairy or woolly covering on it. See 4th Fell
The body of any quarry killed by the hawk
To strike with something thrown or driven; to assail with pellets or missiles, as, to pelt with stones; pelted with hail
To throw; to use as a missile
A blow or stroke from something thrown

pelta.definition: A small shield, especially one of an approximately elliptic form, or crescent-shaped
A flat apothecium having no rim

peltate.definition: Shield-shaped; scutiform; (Bot.) having the stem or support attached to the lower surface, instead of at the base or margin; -- said of a leaf or other organ

pelter.definition: A pinchpenny; a mean, sordid person; a miser; a skinflint

peltier effect.definition: The production or absorption of heat at the junction of two metals on the passage of a current. Heat generated by the passage of the current in one direction will be absorbed if the current is reversed

peltier's cross.definition: A cross formed of two strips of different metals, to illustrate the Peltier effect

peltiform.definition: Shieldlike, with the outline nearly circular; peltate

pelton wheel.definition: A form of impulse turbine or water wheel, consisting of a row of double cup-shaped buckets arranged round the rim of a wheel and actuated by one or more jets of water playing into the cups at high velocity

peltry.definition: Pelts or skins, collectively; skins with the fur on them; furs

peludo.definition: The South American hairy armadillo (Dasypus villosus)

pelure.definition: A crisp, hard, thin paper, sometimes used for postage stamps

pelusiac.definition: Of or pertaining to Pelusium, an ancient city of Egypt; as, the Pelusiac (or former eastern) outlet of the Nile

pelvic.definition: Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the pelvis; as, pelvic cellulitis

pelvimeter.definition: An instrument for measuring the dimensions of the pelvis

pelvis.definition: The pelvic arch, or the pelvic arch together with the sacrum. See Pelvic arch, under Pelvic, and Sacrum

pelycosaur.definition: A large primitive reptile having a tall spinal sail; of the Permian or late Paleozoic in Europe and North America

pelycosauria.definition: An order of extinct reptiles including edaphosaurus and dimetrodon

pembroke.definition: A breed of dog, the smaller and straight-legged variety of Welsh corgi having pointed ears and a short tail

pembroke table.definition: A style of four-legged drop-leaf table in vogue in England, chiefly in the later Georgian period

pemmican.definition: Among the North American Indians, meat cut in thin slices, divested of fat, and dried in the sun

Meat, without the fat, cut in thin slices, dried in the sun, pounded, then mixed with melted fat and sometimes dried fruit, and compressed into cakes or in bags. It contains much nutriment in small compass, and is of great use in long voyages of exploration
A treatise of much thought in little compass

pemphigus.definition: A somewhat rare skin disease, characterized by the development of blebs upon different parts of the body

pen.definition: An instrument used for writing with ink, formerly made of a reed, or of the quill of a goose or other bird, but now also of other materials, as of steel, gold, etc. Also, originally, a stylus or other instrument for scratching or graving
Fig.: A writer, or his style; as, he has a sharp pen
The internal shell of a squid
A female swan; -- contrasted with cob, the male swan
To write; to compose and commit to paper; to indite; to compose; as, to pen a sonnet
To shut up, as in a pen or cage; to confine in a small inclosure or narrow space; to coop up, or shut in; to inclose
A small inclosure; as, a pen for sheep or for pigs

pen-and-ink.definition: A drawing executed with pen and ink

pen-friend.definition: A person one comes to know by by frequent friendly correspondence; a pen pal

penal.definition: Of or pertaining to punishment, to penalties, or to crimes and offenses; pertaining to criminal jurisprudence

penality.definition: The quality or state of being penal; liability to punishment

penalize.definition: To put a penalty on. See Penalty, 3

penalty.definition: Penal retribution; punishment for crime or offense; the suffering in person or property which is annexed by law or judicial decision to the commission of a crime, offense, or trespass
The suffering, or the sum to be forfeited, to which a person subjects himself by covenant or agreement, in case of nonfulfillment of stipulations; forfeiture; fine

penance.definition: A means of repairing a sin committed, and obtaining pardon for it, consisting partly in the performance of expiatory rites, partly in voluntary submission to a punishment corresponding to the transgression, imposed by a confessor or other ecclesiastical authority.  Penance is the fourth of seven sacraments in the Roman Catholic Church
Any act performed by a person to atone for an offense to another; an act of atonement

penang lawyer.definition: A kind of walking stick made from the stem of an East Asiatic palm (Licuala acutifida)

penannular.definition: Nearly annular; having nearly the form of a ring

penates.definition: The household gods of the ancient Romans. They presided over the home and the family hearth. See Lar

pencel.definition: A small, narrow flag or streamer borne at the top of a lance; -- called also pennoncel

penchant.definition: Inclination; decided taste; bias; as, a penchant for art
A game like bézique, or, in the game, any queen and jack of different suits held together

pencil.definition: A small, fine brush of hair or bristles used by painters for laying on colors

A slender cylinder or strip of black lead, graphite, colored chalk, slate etc., or such a cylinder or strip inserted in a small wooden rod intended to be pointed, or in a case, which forms a handle, -- used for drawing or writing. See Graphite
Hence, figuratively, an artist's ability or peculiar manner; also, in general, the act or occupation of the artist, descriptive writer, etc
An aggregate or collection of rays of light, especially when diverging from, or converging to, a point
A number of lines that intersect in one point, the point of intersection being called the pencil point
To write or mark with a pencil; to paint or to draw

penciled.definition: Painted, drawn, sketched, or marked with a pencil
Marked with parallel or radiating lines

penciling.definition: The work of the pencil or bruch; as, delicate penciling in a picture
Lines of white or black paint drawn along a mortar joint in a brick wall

pencraft.definition: The art of composing or writing; authorship

pend.definition: To be undecided, or in process of adjustment

pendant.definition: Something which hangs or depends; something suspended; a hanging appendage, especially one of an ornamental character, as to a chandelier or an eardrop; also, an appendix or addition, as to a book
An ornamental object or piece of jewelry with a hook so that it can be hung from a chain around the neck

A hanging ornament on roofs, ceilings, etc., much used in the later styles of Gothic architecture, where it is of stone, and an important part of the construction.  There are imitations in plaster and wood, which are mere decorative features
One of a pair; a counterpart; as, one vase is the pendant to the other vase
The stem and ring of a watch, by which it is suspended

pendency.definition: The quality or state of being pendent or suspended
The quality or state of being undecided, or in continuance; suspense; as, the pendency of a suit

pendent.definition: Supported from above; suspended; depending; pendulous; hanging; as, a pendent leaf

pendentive.definition: The portion of a vault by means of which the square space in the middle of a building is brought to an octagon or circle to receive a cupola

pendice.definition: A sloping roof; a lean-to; a penthouse

pendicle.definition: An appendage; something dependent on another; an appurtenance; a pendant

pendicler.definition: An inferior tenant; one who rents a pendicle or croft

pending.definition: Not yet decided; in continuance; in suspension; as, a pending suit
Until; awaiting; as, no decision will be taken pending his arrival

pendragon.definition: A chief leader or a king; a head; a dictator; -- a title assumed by the ancient British chiefs when called to lead other chiefs

penduline.definition: A European titmouse (Parus pendulinus, syn. Aegithalus pendulinus).  It is noted for its elegant pendulous purselike nest, made of the down of willow trees and lined with feathers

pendulosity.definition: The state or quality of being pendulous

pendulous.definition: Inclined or hanging downwards, as a flower on a recurved stalk, or an ovule which hangs from the upper part of the ovary

pendulousness.definition: The quality or state of being pendulous; the state of hanging loosely; pendulosity

pendulum.definition: A body so suspended from a fixed point as to swing freely to and fro by the alternate action of gravity and momentum.  It is used to regulate the movements of clockwork and other machinery

peneidae.definition: A natural family of tropical prawns

penelope.definition: A genus of curassows, including the guans

peneplain.definition: A land surface reduced by erosion to the general condition of a plain, but not wholly devoid of hills; a base-level plain

penetrability.definition: The quality of being penetrable; susceptibility of being penetrated, entered, or pierced

penetrable.definition: Capable of being penetrated, entered, or pierced. Used also figuratively

penetralia.definition: The recesses, or innermost parts, of any thing or place, especially of a temple or palace
Hidden things or secrets; privacy; sanctuary; as, the sacred penetralia of the home

penetrance.definition: The quality or state of being penetrant; power of entering or piercing; penetrating power or quality; as, the penetrancy of subtile effluvia

penetrant.definition: Having power to enter or pierce; penetrating; sharp; subtile; as, penetrant cold

penetrate.definition: To enter into; to make way into the interior of; to effect an entrance into; to pierce; as, light penetrates darkness
To affect profoundly through the senses or feelings; to touch with feeling; to make sensible; to move deeply; as, to penetrate one's heart with pity
To pierce into by the mind; to arrive at the inner contents or meaning of, as of a mysterious or difficult subject; to comprehend; to understand
To pass; to make way; to pierce. Also used figuratively

penetrating.definition: Having the power of entering, piercing, or pervading; sharp; subtile; penetrative; as, a penetrating odor
Acute; discerning; sagacious; quick to discover; as, a penetrating mind

penetration.definition: The act or process of penetrating, piercing, or entering; also, the act of mentally penetrating into, or comprehending, anything difficult
Acuteness; insight; sharp discoverment; sagacity; as, a person of singular penetration

penetrative.definition: Tending to penetrate; of a penetrating quality; piercing; as, the penetrative sun
Having the power to affect or impress the mind or heart; impressive; as, penetrative shame
Acute; discerning; sagacious; as, penetrative wisdom

penguin.definition: Any bird of the order Impennes, or Ptilopteri.  They are covered with short, thick feathers, almost scalelike on the wings, which are without true quills.  They are unable to fly, but use their wings to aid in diving, in which they are very expert.  See King penguin, under Jackass
The egg-shaped fleshy fruit of a West Indian plant (Bromelia Pinguin) of the Pineapple family; also, the plant itself, which has rigid, pointed, and spiny-toothed leaves, and is used for hedges

penguinery.definition: A breeding place, or rookery, of penguins

penicil.definition: A tent or pledget for wounds or ulcers

penicillamine.definition: A substance (C5H11NO2S) which is a degradation product of the penicillins.  Chemically it is 3-mercapto-D-valine.  It has chelating properties and is used in medicine as an antirheumatic and to chelate copper in cases of hepatolenticular degeneration (Wilson's disease)

penicillate.definition: Having the form of a pencil; furnished with a pencil of fine hairs; ending in a tuft of hairs like a camel's-hair brush, as the stigmas of some grasses

penicillin.definition: Any of a variety of substances having a structure containing a beta-lactam ring fused to a thiirane ring, to which a carboxyl group is attached, but most commonly interpreted as benzyl penicillin.  They are notable as powerful antibacterial agents of relatively low toxicity which have found extensive use in medicine for treating bacterial infections.  They are categorized as one of the classes of beta-lactam antibiotic.  They are produced naturally by some fungi and bacteria, and industrial production processes almost invariably start from some form of the penicillin nucleus produced by fermentation of microorganisms.  The fermentation products are then chemically modified to produce derivatives of enhanced potency, safety, or antibacterial spectrum.  The first penicillin to see extensive use clinically (during World War II) was penicillin G, also called benzypenicillin, and commonly simply “penicillin”

penicillinase.definition: An enzyme which destroys the antibacterial activity of penicillin by hydrolyzing the amide bond in the beta-lactam ring.  Many penicillinases are known, and are produced by a wide variety of bacteria.  The production of penicillinase is one of the mechanisms by which bacteria may become resistant to penicillins.  Penicillinase production in various bacterial species may be induced, i.e., it may occur only when stimulated by the presence of penicillin in the culture medium, or it may be constitutive, i.e., it may occur whenever the cells are producing protein.  Molecular weights of the various penicillinases tend to cluster near 50,000

peninsula.definition: A portion of land nearly surrounded by water, and connected with a larger body by a neck, or isthmus

peninsular.definition: Of or pertaining to a peninsula; as, a peninsular form; peninsular people; the peninsular war

penis.definition: The erectile external sexual organ of males, used in copulation, and in mammals, also for urination

penitence.definition: The quality or condition of being penitent; the disposition of a penitent; sorrow for sins or faults; repentance; contrition

penitencer.definition: A priest who heard confession and enjoined penance in extraordinary cases

penitent.definition: Feeling pain or sorrow on account of sins or offenses; repentant; contrite; sincerely affected by a sense of guilt, and resolved on amendment of life
One who repents of sin; one sorrowful on account of his transgressions
One under church censure, but admitted to penance; one undergoing penance
One under the direction of a confessor

penitential.definition: Of or pertaining to penitence, or to penance; expressing penitence; of the nature of penance; as, the penitential book; penitential tears
A book formerly used by priests hearing confessions, containing rules for the imposition of penances; -- called also penitential book
