penitentiary.definition: Relating to penance, or to the rules and measures of penance
Expressive of penitence; as, a penitentiary letter
Used for punishment, discipline, and reformation
One who prescribes the rules and measures of penance
A small building in a monastery where penitents confessed
That part of a church to which penitents were admitted

An office of the papal court which examines cases of conscience, confession, absolution from vows, etc., and delivers decisions, dispensations, etc.  Its chief is a cardinal, called the Grand Penitentiary, appointed by the pope

A house of correction, in which offenders are confined for punishment, discipline, and reformation, and in which they are generally compelled to labor; a prison; a jail.  Colloquially often shortened to pen

penitentiaryship.definition: The office or condition of a penitentiary of the papal court

penknife.definition: A small pocketknife; formerly, a knife used for making and mending quill pens

penlight.definition: A small flashlight resembling a fountain pen, often having a clip to permit firm attachment to a pocket

penman.definition: One who uses the pen; a writer; esp., one skilled in the use of the pen; a calligrapher; a writing master

penmanship.definition: The use of the pen in writing; the art of writing; style or manner of writing; chirography; as, good or bad penmanship

pennaceous.definition: Like or pertaining to a normal feather

pennach.definition: A bunch of feathers; a plume

pennant.definition: A small flag; a pennon.  The narrow pennant, or long pennant (called also whip or coach whip) is a long, narrow piece of bunting, carried at the masthead of a government vessel in commission.  The board pennant is an oblong, nearly square flag, carried at the masthead of a commodore's vessel

pennatula.definition: Any one of numerous species of Pennatula, Pteroides, and allied genera of Alcyonaria, having a featherlike form; a sea-pen.  The zooids are situated along one edge of the side branches

pennatulacea.definition: A division of alcyonoid corals, including the seapens and related kinds.  They are able to move about by means of the hollow muscular peduncle, which also serves to support them upright in the mud. See Pennatula, and Illust. under Alcyonaria

penned.definition: Enclosed in a pen; -- of animals

penniform.definition: Having the form of a feather or plume

pennipotent.definition: Strong of wing; strong on the wing

pennon.definition: A pennant; a flag or streamer

pennoncel.definition: A small pennon borne on a lance.  See Pencel

pennsylvanian.definition: The geological period from 280 million to 310 million years ago; -- it was characterized by a warm climate and abundance of swampy land
synonyms: Syn. -- Pennsylvanian period, Upper Carboniferous, Upper Carboniferous period.

pennsylvanian.definition: A resident of the state of Pennsylvania

penny.definition: Denoting the weight in pounds for one thousand; -- used in combination, with respect to nails; as, tenpenny nails, nails of which one thousand weight ten pounds

A former English coin, originally of copper, then of bronze, the twelfth part of an English shilling in account value, and equal to four farthings, or about two cents; -- usually indicated by the abbreviation d. (the initial of denarius)
Any small sum or coin; a groat; a stiver
Money, in general; as, to turn an honest penny
Worth or costing one penny; as, penny candy

penny-a-liner.definition: One who furnishes matter to public journals at so much a line; a poor writer for hire; a hack writer

penny-pinching.definition: Extreme care in spending money; reluctance to spend money unnecessarily
Scrimping; reluctant to spend money; stingy; miserly; same as cheesparing

penny-wise.definition: Thrifty in small matters only.  Used mostly in the phrase penny-wise and pound foolish

pennycress.definition: Any of several plants of the genus Thlaspi; see penny cress

pennyroyal.definition: An aromatic herb (Mentha Pulegium) of Europe; also, a North American plant (Hedeoma pulegioides) resembling it in flavor

pennyweight.definition: A troy weight containing twenty-four grains, or the twentieth part of a troy ounce; 1.555 grams; as, a pennyweight of gold or of arsenic.  It is abbreviated dwt or pwt.  It was anciently the weight of a silver penny, whence the name

pennywort.definition: A European trailing herb (Linaria Cymbalaria) with roundish, reniform leaves. It is often cultivated in hanging baskets

pennyworth.definition: A penny's worth; as much as may be bought for a penny
Hence: The full value of one's penny expended; due return for money laid out; a good bargain; a bargain

penologist.definition: One versed in, or a student of, penology

penology.definition: The science or art of punishment

penrack.definition: A rack for pens not in use

pensileness.definition: State or quality of being pensile; pendulousness

pension.definition: A payment; a tribute; something paid or given

A stated allowance to a person in consideration of past services; payment made to one retired from service, on account of age, disability, or other cause; also, a regular stipend paid by a government to retired public officers, disabled soldiers, the families of soldiers killed in service, or to meritorious authors, or the like
A certain sum of money paid to a clergyman in lieu of tithes
A boarding house or boarding school in France, Belgium, Switzerland, etc
To grant a pension to; to pay a regular stipend to; in consideration of service already performed; -- sometimes followed by off; as, to pension off a servant

pensionable.definition: Entitled to receive a pension; as, a pensionable employee

pensionary.definition: Maintained by a pension; receiving a pension; as, pensionary spies
Consisting of a pension; as, a pensionary provision for maintenance
One who receives a pension; a pensioner
One of the chief magistrates of towns in Holland

pensioner.definition: One in receipt of a pension; hence, figuratively, a dependent
One of an honorable band of gentlemen who attend the sovereign of England on state occasions, and receive an annual pension, or allowance, of £150 and two horses
In the university of Cambridge, England, one who pays for his living in commons; -- corresponding to commoner at Oxford

pensive.definition: Thoughtful, sober, or sad; employed in serious reflection; given to, or favorable to, earnest or melancholy musing
Expressing or suggesting thoughtfulness with sadness; as, pensive numbers

pensiveness.definition: The state of being pensive; serious thoughtfulness; seriousness

penstemon.definition: A large genus of subshrubs or herbs having showy blue or purple or red or yellow or white flowers; found mostly in Western North America

penstock.definition: A close conduit or pipe for conducting water, as, to a water wheel, or for emptying a pond, or for domestic uses
The barrel of a wooden pump

pent.definition: Penned or shut up; confined; -- often with up

penta-.definition: A combining form denoting five; as, pentacapsular; pentagon
Denoting the degree of five, either as regards quality, property, or composition; as, pentasulphide, containing five sulfur atoms; pentoxide, containing five oxygen atoms, etc.  Also used adjectively

pentabasic.definition: Capable of uniting with five molecules of a monacid base; having five acid hydrogen atoms capable of substitution by a basic radical; -- said of certain acids

pentachenium.definition: A dry fruit composed of five carpels, which are covered by an epigynous calyx and separate at maturity

pentachloride.definition: A chloride having five atoms of chlorine in each molecule; as, phosphorus pentachloride

pentachord.definition: An ancient instrument of music with five strings
An order or system of five sounds

pentacid.definition: Capable of neutralizing, or combining with, five molecules of a monobasic acid; having five hydrogen atoms capable of substitution by acid residues; -- said of certain complex bases

pentacle.definition: A five-pointed star, also called a pentagram or pentalpha.  See illustr. under pentalpha.  Sometimes referring to a similar figure, such as the figure composed of two equilateral triangles intersecting so as to form a six-pointed star.  It was used in early ornamental art, and also with superstitious import by the astrologers and mystics of the Middle Ages.  The six-pointed star is more comonly called a hexagram, or called Solomon's seal; it resembles the star of David (Magen David)

pentacoccous.definition: Composed of five united carpels with one seed in each, as certain fruits

pentacrinin.definition: A red and purple pigment found in certain crinoids of the genus Pentacrinus

pentacrinoid.definition: An immature comatula when it is still attached by a stem, and thus resembles a Pentacrinus

pentacrinus.definition: A genus of large, stalked crinoids, of which several species occur in deep water among the West Indies and elsewhere

pentacron.definition: A solid having five summits or angular points

pentacrostic.definition: A set of verses so disposed that the name forming the subject of the acrostic occurs five times -- the whole set of verses being divided into five different parts from top to bottom

pentad.definition: Any element, atom, or radical, having a valence of five, or which can be combined with, substituted for, or compared with, five atoms of hydrogen or other monad; as, nitrogen is a pentad in the ammonium compounds
Having the valence of a pentad

pentadactyl.definition: Having five digits to the hand or foot
Having five appendages resembling fingers or toes

pentadactyloid.definition: Having the form of, or a structure modified from, a pentadactyl limb

pentadecane.definition: A hydrocarbon of the paraffin series, (C15H32) found in petroleum, tar oil, etc., and obtained as a colorless liquid; -- so called from the fifteen carbon atoms in the molecule

pentadecatoic.definition: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, pentadecane, or designating an acid related to it

pentadelphous.definition: Having the stamens arranged in five clusters, those of each cluster having their filaments more or less united, as the flowers of the linden

pentafid.definition: Divided or cleft into five parts

pentaglot.definition: A work in five different tongues

pentagon.definition: A plane figure having five angles, and, consequently, five sides; any figure having five angles

pentagonally.definition: In the form of a pentagon; with five angles

pentagynia.definition: A Linnæan order of plants, having five styles or pistils

pentagynian.definition: Of or pertaining to plants of the order Pentagyna; having five styles

pentahedral.definition: Having five sides; as, a pentahedral figure

pentahedron.definition: A solid figure having five sides

pentail.definition: A peculiar insectivore (Ptilocercus Lowii) of Borneo; -- so called from its very long, quill-shaped tail, which is scaly at the base and plumose at the tip

pentalpha.definition: A five-pointed star, resembling five alphas joined at their bases; -- used as a symbol

pentamera.definition: An extensive division of Coleoptera, including those that normally have five-jointed tarsi. It embraces about half of all the known species of the Coleoptera

pentamerous.definition: Divided into, or consisting of, five parts; also, arranged in sets, with five parts in each set, as a flower with five sepals, five petals, five, or twice five, stamens, and five pistils

pentamerus.definition: A genus of extinct Paleozoic brachiopods, often very abundant in the Upper Silurian

pentamethylene.definition: A hypothetical hydrocarbon, C5H10, metameric with the amylenes, and the nucleus of a large number of derivatives; -- so named because regarded as composed of five methylene residues.  Cf. Trimethylene, and Tetramethylene

pentandria.definition: A Linnæan class of plants having five separate stamens

pentandrian.definition: Of or pertaining to the class Pentadria; having five stamens

pentane.definition: Any one of the three metameric hydrocarbons, C5H12, of the methane or paraffin series. They are colorless, volatile liquids, two of which occur in petroleum. So called because of the five carbon atoms in the molecule

pentapetalous.definition: Having five petals, or flower leaves

pentapody.definition: A measure or series consisting of five feet

pentaptych.definition: A picture, or combination of pictures, consisting of a centerpiece and double folding doors or wings, as for an altarpiece

pentarchy.definition: A government in the hands of five persons; five joint rulers

pentastich.definition: A composition consisting of five verses

pentastichous.definition: Having, or arranged in, five vertical ranks, as the leaves of an apple tree or a cherry tree

pentastyle.definition: Having five columns in front; -- said of a temple or portico in classical architecture

pentateuch.definition: The first five books of the Old Testament, collectively; -- called also the Law of Moses, Book of the Law of Moses, etc

pentateuchal.definition: Of or pertaining to the Pentateuch

pentathionic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of sulphur obtained by leading hydrogen sulphide into a solution of sulphur dioxide; -- so called because it contains five atoms of sulphur

pentathlon.definition: A fivefold athletic performance peculiar to the great national games of the Greeks, including leaping, foot racing, wrestling, throwing the discus, and throwing the spear
In the modern Olympic Games, a composite contest made up of a running broad jump, throwing the javelin, a 200-meter run, throwing the discus, and a 1500-meter run

pentatomic.definition: Having five atoms in the molecule

pentavalent.definition: Having a valence of five; -- said of certain atoms and radicals

penteconter.definition: A Grecian vessel with fifty oars

pentecost.definition: A solemn festival of the Jews; -- so called because celebrated on the fiftieth day (seven weeks) after the second day of the Passover (which fell on the sixteenth of the Jewish month Nisan); -- hence called, also, the Feast of Weeks. At this festival an offering of the first fruits of the harvest was made. By the Jews it was generally regarded as commemorative of the gift of the law on the fiftieth day after the departure from Egypt
A festival of the Roman Catholic and other churches in commemoration of the descent of the Holy Spirit on the apostles; which occurred on the day of Pentecost; -- called also Whitsunday

pentecostal.definition: Of or pertaining to Pentecost or to Whitsuntide

pentecostals.definition: Offerings formerly made to the parish priest, or to the mother church, at Pentecost

pentecoster.definition: An officer in the Spartan army commanding fifty men

pentecosty.definition: A troop of fifty soldiers in the Spartan army; -- called also pentecostys

pentelic.definition: Of or pertaining to Mount Pentelicus, near Athens, famous for its fine white marble quarries; obtained from Mount Pentelicus; as, the Pentelic marble of which the Parthenon is built

penthouse.definition: A shed or roof sloping from the main wall or building, as over a door or window; a lean-to. Also figuratively

pentine.definition: An unsaturated hydrocarbon, C5H8, of the acetylene series. Same as Valerylene

pentoic.definition: Pertaining to, or desingating, an acid (called also valeric acid) derived from pentane

pentosan.definition: One of a class of substances (complex carbohydrates widely distributed in plants, as in fruits, gums, woods, hay, etc.) which yield pentoses on hydrolysis

pentose.definition: Any of a group of sugars of the formula C5H10O5, such as as arabinose or ribose; -- so called from the five carbon atoms in the molecule. They are not fermented by yeast

pentoxide.definition: An oxide containing five atoms of oxygen in each molecule; as, phosphorus pentoxide, P2O5

pentremites.definition: A genus of crinoids belonging to the Blastoidea. They have five petal-like ambulacra

pentyl.definition: The hypothetical radical, C5H11, of pentane and certain of its derivatives. Same as Amyl

pentylic.definition: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, pentyl; as, pentylic alcohol

penuchle.definition: A game at cards, played with forty-eight cards, being all the cards above the eight spots in two packs

penult.definition: The last syllable but one of a word; the syllable preceding the final one

penultimate.definition: Last but one; as, the penultimate syllable, the last syllable but one of a word

penumbra.definition: The shadow cast, in an eclipse, where the light is partly, but not wholly, cut off by the intervening body; the space of partial illumination between the umbra, or perfect shadow, on all sides, and the full light
The part of a picture where the shade imperceptibly blends with the light

penumbrala.definition: Of or pertaining to a penumbra; resembling a penumbra; partially illuminated

penurious.definition: Excessively sparing in the use of money; sordid; stingy; miserly
Destitute of money; suffering extreme want

penury.definition: Absence of resources; want; privation; indigence; extreme poverty; destitution

penwiper.definition: A cloth, or other material, for wiping off or cleaning ink from a pen

peon.definition: A foot soldier; a policeman; also, an office attendant; a messenger
A day laborer; a servant; especially, in some of the Spanish American countries, debtor held by his creditor in a form of qualified servitude, to work out a debt

peony.definition: A plant, and its flower, of the ranunculaceous genus Pæonia.  Of the four or five species, one is a shrub; the rest are perennial herbs with showy flowers, often double in cultivation

people.definition: The body of persons who compose a community, tribe, nation, or race; an aggregate of individuals forming a whole; a community; a nation

Persons, generally; an indefinite number of men and women; folks; population, or part of population; as, country people; -- sometimes used as an indefinite subject or verb, like on in French, and man in German; as, people in adversity
The mass of community as distinguished from a special class; the commonalty; the populace; the vulgar; the common crowd; as, nobles and people
One's ancestors or family; kindred; relations; as, my people were English
To stock with people or inhabitants; to fill as with people; to populate

people's bank.definition: A form of cooperative bank, such as those of Germany; -- a term loosely used for various forms of cooperative financial institutions

people's party.definition: A party formed in 1891, advocating an increase of the currency, public ownership and operation of railroads, telegraphs, etc., an income tax, limitation in ownership of land, etc

peopled.definition: Stocked with, or as with, people; inhabited

peorias.definition: An Algonquin tribe of Indians who formerly inhabited a part of Illinois

peperine.definition: A volcanic rock, formed by the cementing together of sand, scoria, cinders, etc

peplis.definition: A genus of plants including water purslane

peplum.definition: A peplos. Hence: An overskirt hanging like an ancient peplos; also, a short fitted skirt attached to a waist or coat

peplus.definition: An upper garment worn by Grecian and Roman women
A kind of kerchief formerly worn by Englishwomen

pepo.definition: Any fleshy fruit with a firm rind, as a pumpkin, melon, or gourd. See Gourd

pepper.definition: A well-known, pungently aromatic condiment, the dried berry, either whole or powdered, of the Piper nigrum

The plant which yields pepper, an East Indian woody climber (Piper nigrum), with ovate leaves and apetalous flowers in spikes opposite the leaves. The berries are red when ripe. Also, by extension, any one of the several hundred species of the genus Piper, widely dispersed throughout the tropical and subtropical regions of the earth

Any plant of the genus Capsicum (of the Solanaceae family, which are unrelated to Piper), and its fruit; red pepper; chili pepper; as, the bell pepper and the jalapeno pepper (both Capsicum annuum) and the habanero pepper (Capsicum chinense); .  These contain varying levels of the substance capsaicin (C18H27O3N), which gives the peppers their hot taste.  The habanero is about 25-50 times hotter than the jalapeno according to a scale developed by Wilbur Scoville in 1912.  See also Capsicum and http://www.chili-pepper-plants.com/
To sprinkle or season with pepper
Figuratively: To shower shot or other missiles, or blows, upon; to pelt; to fill with shot, or cover with bruises or wounds; as, to pepper him with buckshot

pepper box.definition: A buttress on the left-hand wall of a fives court as the game is played at Eton College, England

pepper dulse.definition: A variety of edible seaweed (Laurencia pinnatifida) distinguished for its pungency

peppercorn.definition: A dried berry of the black pepper (Piper nigrum)

pepperer.definition: A grocer; -- formerly so called because he sold pepper

peppergrass.definition: Any herb of the cruciferous genus Lepidium, especially the garden peppergrass, or garden cress, Lepidium sativum; -- called also pepperwort. All the species have a pungent flavor

pepperidge.definition: A North American tree (Nyssa multiflora) with very tough wood, handsome oval polished leaves, and very acid berries, -- the sour gum, or common tupelo. See Tupelo

peppermint.definition: An aromatic and pungent plant of the genus Mentha (Mentha piperita), much used in medicine and confectionery
A volatile oil (oil of peppermint) distilled from the fresh herb; also, a well-known essence or spirit (essence of peppermint) obtained from it
A lozenge of sugar flavored with peppermint

pepperoni.definition: a hard sausage of beef and pork, highly seasoned

peppershaker.definition: A shaker with a perforated top for sprinkling ground pepper

pepperwood.definition: A Pacific coast tree (Umbellularia californica) having aromatic foliage and small umbellate flowers followed by olivelike fruit; yields a hard tough wood
synonyms: Syn. -- California laurel, California bay tree, Oregon myrtle, spice tree, sassafras laurel, California olive, mountain laurel, Umbellularia californica.

peppery.definition: Of or pertaining to pepper; having the qualities of pepper; hot; pungent

peppy.definition: Full of pep; spirited; bouncy{2}; as, the peppy and interesting talk

pepsi.definition: Pepsi Cola; -- a familiar contraction; as, I prefer Pepsi to Coke

pepsi cola.definition: A carbonated soft drink flavored by extract from the cola nut (kola nut).  The nut is found on trees of the species Cola acuminata and Cola nitida

pepsin.definition: A proteolytic enzyme (MW 34,500) contained in the secretory glands of the stomach.  In the gastric juice it is united with dilute hydrochloric acid (0.2 per cent, approximately) and the two together constitute the active portion of the digestive fluid.  It degrades proteins to proteoses and peptides, and is notable for having a very low pH optimum for its activity.  It is the active agent in the gastric juice of all animals

pepsinogen.definition: A proenzyme, the antecedent of the enzyme pepsin.  A substance contained in the form of granules in the peptic cells of the gastric glands.  It is readily convertible into pepsin. Also called propepsin

peptic.definition: Relating to digestion; promoting digestion; digestive; as, peptic sauces
Pertaining to pepsin; resembling pepsin in its power of digesting or dissolving albuminous matter; containing or yielding pepsin, or a body of like properties; as, the peptic glands

peptogenous.definition: Capable of yielding, or being converted into, peptone

peptohydrochloric.definition: Designating a hypothetical acid (called peptohydrochloric acid, pepsinhydrochloric acid, and chloropeptic acid) which is supposed to be formed when pepsin and dilute (0.1-0.4 per cent) hydrochloric acid are mixed together

peptone.definition: The soluble polypeptides produced by hydrolysis of protein; specifically the soluble peptides into which food is transformed by the action of the gastric and pancreatic juices. Peptones are also formed from protein matter by the action of boiling water and boiling dilute acids

peptonize.definition: To convert into peptone; to digest or dissolve by means of a proteolytic ferment; as, peptonized food

peptonuria.definition: The presence of peptone, or a peptonelike body, in the urine; now referred to as proteinuria

peptotoxine.definition: A toxic alkaloid found occasionally associated with the peptones formed from fibrin by pepsinhydrochloric acid

pequots.definition: A tribe of Indians who formerly inhabited Eastern Connecticut

per.definition: Through; by means of; through the agency of; by; for; for each; as, per annum; per capita, by heads, or according to individuals; per curiam, by the court; per se, by itself, of itself.  Per is also sometimes used with English words

per diem.definition: By the day; substantively (chiefly U. S.), an allowance or amount of so much by the day.  Also used adjectivally; as, a per diem allowance

per-.definition: A prefix used to signify through, throughout, by, for, or as an intensive as perhaps, by hap or chance; perennial, that lasts throughout the year; perforce, through or by force; perfoliate, perforate; perspicuous, evident throughout or very evident; perplex, literally, to entangle very much

Originally, denoting that the element to the name of which it is prefixed in the respective compounds exercised its highest valence; now, only that the element has a higher valence than in other similar compounds; thus, barium peroxide is the highest oxide of barium; while nitrogen and manganese peroxides, so-called, are not the highest oxides of those elements

peract.definition: To go through with; to perform

peracute.definition: Very sharp; very violent; as, a peracute fever

peradventure.definition: By chance; perhaps; it may be; if; supposing
Chance; hap; hence, doubt; question; as, proved beyond peradventure

peraeopod.definition: One of the thoracic legs of a crustacean. See Illust. of Crustacea

peragration.definition: The act or state of passing through any space; as, the peragration of the moon in her monthly revolution

perambulate.definition: To walk through or over; especially, to travel over for the purpose of surveying or examining; to inspect by traversing; specifically, to inspect officially the boundaries of, as of a town or parish, by walking over the whole line
To walk about; to ramble; to stroll; as, he perambulated in the park

perambulating.definition: Strolling or walking around; as, in the field we met some perambulating veterans

perambulation.definition: An annual survey of boundaries, as of town, a parish, a forest, etc
A district within which one is authorized to make a tour of inspection

perambulator.definition: A surveyor's instrument for measuring distances. It consists of a wheel arranged to roll along over the ground, with an apparatus of clockwork, and a dial plate upon which the distance traveled is shown by an index. See Odometer
A low carriage for a child, propelled by pushing; a baby carriage; -- called also pram, in Britain

perameles.definition: Any marsupial of the genus Perameles, which includes numerous species found in Australia. They somewhat resemble rabbits in size and form. See Illust. under Bandicoot

perbromic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, the highest oxygen acid, HBrO4, of bromine

perbromide.definition: A bromide having a higher proportion of bromine than any other bromide of the same substance or series

perca.definition: A genus of fishes, including the fresh-water perch

percale.definition: A fine cotton fabric, having a linen finish, and often printed on one side, -- used for women's and children's wear, and for bedsheets

percaline.definition: A fine kind of cotton goods, usually of one color, and with a glossy surface, -- much use for linings

percarbide.definition: A compound containing a relatively large amount of carbon

percarbureted.definition: Combined with a relatively large amount of carbon

perceive.definition: To obtain knowledge of through the senses; to receive impressions from by means of the bodily organs; to take cognizance of the existence, character, or identity of, by means of the senses; to see, hear, or feel; as, to perceive a distant ship; to perceive a discord
To take intellectual cognizance of; to apprehend by the mind; to be convinced of by direct intuition; to note; to remark; to discern; to see; to understand
To be affected of influented by

perceived.definition: Detected by instinct or inference rather than by recognized perceptual cues; as, a perceived threat
Detected by means of the senses; as, a perceived difference in temperature

perceiver.definition: One who perceives (in any of the senses of the verb)

percent.definition: A proportion multiplied by 100; as, he receives a percent of the proceeds; 3 is 75 percent of 4.  Often symbolized by the character “%”; as, at 6% interest

percentage.definition: A certain rate per cent; the allowance, duty, rate of interest, discount, or commission, on a hundred

percept.definition: That object or phenomenon which is perceived
The mental result of perceiving; the sensation of something perceived; that part of the mental state resulting from an act of perception

perceptibility.definition: The quality or state of being perceptible; as, the perceptibility of light or color

perceptible.definition: Capable of being perceived; cognizable; discernible; perceivable; large enough to be perceived; not so small as to be incapable of perception

perception.definition: The act of perceiving; cognizance by the senses or intellect; apprehension by the bodily organs, or by the mind, of what is presented to them; discernment; apprehension; cognition

The faculty of perceiving; the faculty, or peculiar part, of man's constitution by which he has knowledge through the medium or instrumentality of the bodily organs; the act of apperhending material objects or qualities through the senses; -- distinguished from conception
The quality, state, or capability, of being affected by something external; sensation; sensibility

perceptive.definition: Of or pertaining to the act or power of perceiving; having the faculty or power of perceiving; used in perception
Possesing or exhibiting a high degree of understanding, insight, intuition, or analytical skill; as, he gave a perceptive analysis of the situation

perceptivity.definition: The quality or state of being perceptive; power of perception

percesoces.definition: An order of fishes including the gray mullets (Mugil), the barracudas, the silversides, and other related fishes.  So called from their relation both to perches and to pikes

perch.definition: Any fresh-water fish of the genus Perca and of several other allied genera of the family Percidæ, as the common American or yellow perch (Perca flavescens syn. Perca Americana), and the European perch (Perca fluviatilis)
Any one of numerous species of spiny-finned fishes belonging to the Percidæ, Serranidæ, and related families, and resembling, more or less, the true perches
A pole; a long staff; a rod; esp., a pole or other support for fowls to roost on or to rest on; a roost; figuratively, any elevated resting place or seat
A measure of length containing five and a half yards; a rod, or pole
A pole connecting the fore gear and hind gear of a spring carriage; a reach
To alight or settle, as a bird; to sit or roost
To place or to set on, or as on, a perch

perchant.definition: A bird tied by the foot, to serve as decoy to other birds by its fluttering

percher.definition: One who, or that which, perches
A Paris candle anciently used in England; also, a large wax candle formerly set upon the altar

percheron.definition: One of a breed of draught horses originating in Perche, an old district of France; -- called also Percheron-Norman

perchloric.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, the highest oxygen acid (HClO4), of chlorine; -- called also hyperchloric

perchloride.definition: A chloride having a higher proportion of chlorine than any other chloride of the same substance or series

perchromic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, a certain one of the highly oxidized compounds of chromium, which has a deep blue color, and is produced by the action of hydrogen peroxide

perciformes.definition: An extensive order of fishes, including the true perches (Percidæ); the pondfishes (Centrarchidæ); the sciænoids (Sciænidæ); the sparoids (Sparidæ); the serranoids (Serranidæ), and some other related families

percipience.definition: The faculty, act or power of perceiving; perception

percipient.definition: Having the faculty of perception; perceiving; as, a percipient being

percoid.definition: Belonging to, or resembling, the perches, or family Percidæ

percoidean.definition: Any of numerous spiny-finned fishes of the order Perciformes

percolate.definition: To cause to pass through fine interstices, as a liquor; to filter; to strain
To pass through fine interstices; to filter; as, water percolates through porous stone

percolation.definition: The act or process of percolating, or filtering; filtration; straining. Specifically (Pharm.), the process of exhausting the virtues of a powdered drug by letting a liquid filter slowly through it

percolator.definition: One who, or that which, filters

A type of coffee pot in which the heated water is driven by its boiling action up above a porous canister of coffee held above the level of the water in the pot, and then filters (percolates) back through the coffee thus extracting its essence
An apparatus for producing an extract from a drug by percolation

percomorphi.definition: A division of fishes including the perches and related kinds

percursory.definition: Running over slightly or in haste; cursory

percuss.definition: To strike smartly; to strike upon or against; as, to percuss the chest in medical examination
To strike or tap in an examination by percussion. See Percussion, 3

percussion.definition: The act of percussing, or striking one body against another; forcible collision, esp. such as gives a sound or report
Hence: The effect of violent collision; vibratory shock; impression of sound on the ear

The act of tapping or striking the surface of the body in order to learn the condition of the parts beneath by the sound emitted or the sensation imparted to the fingers.  Percussion is said to be immediate if the blow is directly upon the body; if some intervening substance, as a pleximeter, is, used, it is called mediate

percussion instrument.definition: A musical instrument which is played by striking, as a drum, cymbal, or xylophone

percussionist.definition: A musician who plays percussion instruments

percussive.definition: Striking against; percutient; as, percussive force

percutient.definition: Striking; having the power of striking

perdicine.definition: Of or pertaining to the family Perdicidæ, or partridges

perdifoil.definition: A deciduous plant; -- opposed to evergreen

perdition.definition: Damnation; the utter loss of the soul, or of final happiness in a future state; future misery or eternal death
Hell; hades; as, on the path to perdition

perditionable.definition: Capable of being ruined; worthy of perdition

perdix.definition: A genus of birds including the common European partridge.  Formerly the word was used in a much wider sense to include many allied genera

perdu.definition: One placed on watch, or in ambush
A soldier sent on a forlorn hope
Lost to view; in concealment or ambush
Accustomed to, or employed in, desperate enterprises; hence, reckless; hopeless

perdurantism.definition: The philosophical view considering the fundamental objects of the real world as extended in the direction of time, so that the objects themselves do not change, though temporal parts may have different properties.  Contrasted to endurantism, a view considering objects to be wholly present at each instant of time

perdurantist.definition: A philosopher who considers the fundamental objects of the real world as extended in the direction of time, so that the objects themselves do not change, though temporal parts may have different properties.  Contrasted to endurantist, one who considers objects to be wholly present at each instant

perdure.definition: To last or endure for a long time; to be perdurable or lasting

pere.definition: Father; -- often used after French proper names to distinguish a father from his son; as, Dumas père

peregrinate.definition: To travel from place to place, or from one country to another; hence, to sojourn in foreign countries

peregrination.definition: A traveling from one country to another; a wandering; sojourn in foreign countries

peregrinator.definition: One who peregrinates; one who travels about

peregrine.definition: Foreign; not native; extrinsic or from without; exotic

peremptorily.definition: In a peremptory manner; absolutely; positively

peremptoriness.definition: The quality of being peremptory; positiveness

peremptory.definition: Precluding debate or expostulation; not admitting of question or appeal; positive; absolute; decisive; conclusive; final
Positive in opinion or judgment; decided; dictatorial; dogmatical

perennate.definition: To survive from season to season, of plants

perennial.definition: Lasting or continuing through the year; as, perennial fountains
Continuing without cessation or intermission; perpetual; unceasing; never failing
Continuing more than two years; as, a perennial steam, or root, or plant
A perennial plant; a plant which lives or continues more than two years, whether it retains its leaves in winter or not

perennibranchiata.definition: Those Batrachia which retain their gills through life, as the menobranchus

perennibranchiate.definition: Having branchæ, or gills, through life; -- said especially of certain Amphibia, like the menobranchus. Opposed to caducibranchiate

pererration.definition: A wandering, or rambling, through various places

perfect.definition: Brought to consummation or completeness; completed; not defective nor redundant; having all the properties or qualities requisite to its nature and kind; without flaw, fault, or blemish; without error; mature; whole; pure; sound; right; correct
Hermaphrodite; having both stamens and pistils; -- said of a flower
The perfect tense, or a form in that tense
To make perfect; to finish or complete, so as to leave nothing wanting; to give to anything all that is requisite to its nature and kind

perfected.definition: Brought into final form; completely formed; -- of plans, ideas, etc
Refined to a state of excellence; -- of e.g. skills or the products of skills

perfecter.definition: One who, or that which, makes perfect

perfectibility.definition: The capability of becoming perfect; as, he believes in the ultimate perfectability of man; -- usually spelled perfectibility
The quality or state of being perfectible

perfectible.definition: Capable of becoming, or being made, perfect

perfection.definition: The quality or state of being perfect or complete, so that nothing requisite is wanting; entire development; consummate culture, skill, or moral excellence; the highest attainable state or degree of excellence; maturity; as, perfection in an art, in a science, or in a system; perfection in form or degree; fruits in perfection
A quality, endowment, or acquirement completely excellent; an ideal faultlessness; especially, the divine attribute of complete excellence

perfectional.definition: Of or pertaining to perfection; characterized by perfection

perfectionism.definition: A personal attitude which demands perfection in the results of actions

perfectionist.definition: One pretending to perfection; esp., one pretending to moral perfection; one who believes that persons may and do attain to moral perfection and sinlessness in this life
A person who insists on perfect results from himself or from others, in any endeavor

perfectionment.definition: The act of bringing to perfection, or the state of having attained to perfection

perfective.definition: Tending or conducing to make perfect, or to bring to perfection; -- usually followed by of

Denoting an aspect of verbs which indicates completion of an action, and is sometimes explicitly marked in verbal inflection, as in the Russian language; as, the perfective form of a verb.  The use of a perfective form rather than the simple past indicates reference to a completed event, rather than to a process that took place in the past
A verb in the perfective case or aspect

perfectly.definition: In a perfect manner or degree; in or to perfection; completely; wholly; thoroughly; faultlessly

perfectness.definition: The quality or state of being perfect; perfection

perfervid.definition: Very fervid; too fervid; glowing; ardent

perficient.definition: Making or doing thoroughly; efficient; effectual
One who performs or perfects a work; especially, one who endows a charity

perfidious.definition: Guilty of perfidy; violating good faith or vows; false to trust or confidence reposed; treacherous; faithless; as, a perfidious friend

perfidiousness.definition: The quality of being perfidious; perfidy

perfidy.definition: The act of violating faith or allegiance; violation of a promise or vow, or of trust reposed; faithlessness; treachery

perfoliate.definition: Having the basal part produced around the stem; -- said of leaves which the stem apparently passes directory through
Surrounded by a circle of hairs, or projections of any kind

perforata.definition: A division of corals including those that have a porous texture, as Porites and Madrepora; -- opposed to Aporosa

perforate.definition: To bore through; to pierce through with a pointed instrument; to make a hole or holes through by boring or piercing; to pierce or penetrate the surface of
Pierced with a hole or holes, or with pores; having transparent dots resembling holes

perforation.definition: The act of perforating, or of boring or piercing through
A hole made by boring or piercing; an aperture

perforative.definition: Having power to perforate or pierce

perforator.definition: One who, or that which, perforates; esp., a cephalotome

perforce.definition: By force; of necessity; at any rate

perform.definition: To carry through; to bring to completion; to achieve; to accomplish; to execute; to do
To discharge; to fulfill; to act up to; as, to perform a duty; to perform a promise or a vow
To represent; to act; to play; as in drama

To do, execute, or accomplish something; to acquit one's self in any business; esp., to represent sometimes by action; to act a part; to play on a musical instrument; as, the players perform poorly; the musician performs on the organ

performable.definition: Admitting of being performed, done, or executed; practicable

performance.definition: The act of performing; the carrying into execution or action; execution; achievement; accomplishment; representation by action; as, the performance of an undertaking of a duty
That which is performed or accomplished; a thing done or carried through; an achievement; a deed; an act; a feat; esp., an action of an elaborate or public character

performer.definition: One who performs, accomplishes, or fulfills; as, a good promiser, but a bad performer; especially, one who shows skill and training in any art; as, a performer of the drama; a performer on the harp

perfume.definition: To fill or impregnate with a perfume; to scent
The scent, odor, or odoriferous particles emitted from a sweet-smelling substance; a pleasant odor; fragrance; aroma
A substance that emits an agreeable odor

perfumed.definition: Filled or impregnated with perfume; as, perfumed stationery; a perfumed boudoir
Having a natural fragrance; as, the perfumed air of June
synonyms: Syn. -- odoriferous, odorous, scented, sweet, sweet-scented, sweet-smelling.

perfumer.definition: One who, or that which, perfumes
One whose trade is to make or sell perfumes

perfunctorily.definition: In a perfunctory manner; formally; carelessly

perfunctoriness.definition: The quality or state of being perfunctory

perfunctory.definition: Done merely to get rid of a duty; performed mechanically and as a thing of rote; done in a careless and superficial manner; characterized by indifference; as, perfunctory admonitions; a perfunctory greeting

perfuncturate.definition: To perform in a perfunctory manner; to do negligently

perfuse.definition: To suffuse; to fill full or to excess
To pass a liquid through or over; as, the isolated kidney was perfused with saline solution
To pass (a liquid) through an organ

perfusive.definition: Of a nature to flow over, or to spread through

pergolo.definition: A continuous colonnade or arcade; -- applied to the decorative groups of windows, as in Venetian palazzi

perhaps.definition: Posibly; by chance; peradventure; perchance; it may be

peri.definition: An imaginary being, male or female, like an elf or fairy, represented as a descendant of fallen angels, excluded from paradise till penance is accomplished

peri-.definition: A prefix used to signify around, by, near, over, beyond, or to give an intensive sense; as, perimeter, the measure around; perigee, point near the earth; periergy, work beyond what is needed; perispherical, quite spherical

perianth.definition: The leaves of a flower generally, especially when the calyx and corolla are not readily distinguished

periapt.definition: A charm worn as a protection against disease or mischief; an amulet

periastron.definition: That point, in the real or apparent orbit of one star revolving around another, at which the former is nearest to the latter

periblast.definition: The protoplasmic matter which surrounds the entoblast, or cell nucleus, and undergoes segmentation

periblem.definition: Nascent cortex, or immature cellular bark

peribolos.definition: In ancient architecture, an inclosed court, esp., one surrounding a temple

peribranchial.definition: Surrounding the branchiæ; as, a peribranchial cavity

peribronchial.definition: Around the bronchi or bronchial tubes; as, the peribronchial lymphatics

pericambium.definition: A layer of thin-walled young cells in a growing stem, in which layer certain new vessels originate

pericardiac.definition: Of or pertaining to pericardium; situated around the heart

pericardium.definition: The double baglike fold of serous membrane which incloses the heart

pericarp.definition: The ripened ovary; the walls of the fruit. See Illusts. of Capsule, Drupe, and Legume

pericarpial.definition: Of or pertaining to a pericarp

pericellular.definition: Surrounding a cell; as, the pericellular lymph spaces surrounding ganglion cells

perichaeth.definition: The leafy involucre surrounding the fruit stalk of mosses; perichaetium; perichete

perichaetial.definition: Of or pertaining to the perichæth

perichaetous.definition: Surrounded by setæ; -- said of certain earthworms (genus Perichætus)

perichondrial.definition: Of or pertaining to the perichondrium; situated around cartilage

perichondrium.definition: The membrane of fibrous connective tissue which closely invests cartilage, except where covering articular surfaces

perichordal.definition: Around the notochord; as, a perichordal column. See Epichordal

periclase.definition: A grayish or dark green mineral, consisting essentially of magnesia (magnesium oxide), occurring in granular forms or in isometric crystals

periclinium.definition: The involucre which surrounds the common receptacle in composite flowers

periclitation.definition: The state of being in peril

pericope.definition: A selection or extract from a book; especially (Theol.), a selection from the Bible, appointed to be read in the churches or used as a text for a sermon

pericranial.definition: Of or pertaining to the pericranium

pericranium.definition: The periosteum which covers the cranium externally; the region around the cranium

periculum.definition: In a narrower, judicial sense: Accident or casus, as distinguished from dolus and culpa, and hence relieving one from the duty of performing an obligation

pericystitis.definition: Inflammation of the tissues surrounding the bladder

periderm.definition: The hard outer covering of hydroids and other marine animals; the perisarc

peridiastole.definition: The almost inappreciable time which elapses between the systole and the diastole of the heart

peridium.definition: The envelope or coat of certain fungi, such as the puffballs and earthstars

peridotite.definition: An eruptive rock characterized by the presence of chrysolite (peridot).  It also usually contains pyroxene, enstatite, chromite, etc.  It is often altered to serpentine

peridrome.definition: The space between the columns and the wall of the cella, in a Greek or a Roman temple

periganglionic.definition: Surrounding a ganglion; as, the periganglionic glands of the frog

perigastric.definition: Surrounding the stomach; -- applied to the body cavity of Bryozoa and various other Invertebrata

perigee.definition: That point, in the orbit of the moon or other body orbiting the earth, which is nearest to the earth; -- opposed to apogee.  It is sometimes, but rarely, used of the nearest points of bodies not orbiting the earth, such as of a comet, a planet, etc. Called also epigee, epigeum

perigenesis.definition: A theory which explains inheritance by the transmission of the type of growth force possessed by one generation to another

perigone.definition: Any organ inclosing the essential organs of a flower; a perianth
A sac which surrounds the generative bodies in the gonophore of a hydroid

perigord pie.definition: A pie made of truffles, much esteemed by epicures

perigraph.definition: A careless or inaccurate delineation of anything

perigynium.definition: Some unusual appendage about the pistil, as the bottle-shaped body in the sedges, and the bristles or scales in some other genera of the Sedge family, or Cyperaceæ

perigynous.definition: Having the ovary free, but the petals and stamens borne on the calyx; -- said of a flower such as that of the cherry or peach

perihelion.definition: That point of the orbit of a planet or comet which is nearest to the sun; -- opposed to aphelion

peril.definition: Danger; risk; hazard; jeopardy; exposure of person or property to injury, loss, or destruction
To expose to danger; to hazard; to risk; as, to peril one's life

perilla.definition: A genus of labiate herbs, of which one species (Perilla ocimoides, or Perilla Nankinensis) is often cultivated for its purple or variegated foliage

perilous.definition: Full of, attended with, or involving, peril; dangerous; hazardous; as, a perilous undertaking

perilymph.definition: The fluid which surrounds the membranous labyrinth of the internal ear, and separates it from the walls of the chambers in which the labyrinth lies

perilymphangial.definition: Around, or at the side of, a lymphatic vessel

perimeter.definition: The outer boundary of a body or figure, or the sum of all the sides
An instrument for determining the extent and shape of the field of vision

perimetric.definition: Of or pertaining to the perimeter, or to perimetry; as, a perimetric chart of the eye

perimetry.definition: The art of using the perimeter; measurement of the field of vision

perimorph.definition: A crystal of one species inclosing one of another species. See Endomorph

perimysium.definition: The connective tissue sheath which surrounds a muscle, and sends partitions inwards between the bundles of muscular fibers

perineal.definition: Of or pertaining to the perineum

perineoplasty.definition: The act or process of restoring an injured perineum

perineorrhaphy.definition: The operation of sewing up a ruptured perineum

perinephritis.definition: Inflammation of the cellular tissue around the kidney

perineum.definition: The region which is included within the outlet of the pelvis, and is traversed by the urinogenital canal and the rectum

perineurial.definition: Surrounding nerves or nerve fibers; of or pertaining to the perineurium

perineurium.definition: The connective tissue sheath which surrounds a bundle of nerve fibers. See Epineurium, and Neurilemma

perinuclear.definition: Of or pertaining to a nucleus; situated around a nucleus; as, the perinuclear protoplasm

period.definition: A portion of time as limited and determined by some recurring or cyclic phenomenon, as by the completion of a revolution of one of the heavenly bodies; a division of time, as a series of years, months, or days, in which something is completed, and ready to recommence and go on in the same order; as, the period of the sun, or the earth, or a comet; the period of an electromagnetic wave is the time interval between maxima

A stated and recurring interval of time; more generally, an interval of time specified or left indefinite; a certain series of years, months, days, or the like; a time; a cycle; an age; an epoch; as, the period of the Roman republic
One of the great divisions of geological time; as, the Tertiary period; the Glacial period.  See the Chart of Geology
The termination or completion of a revolution, cycle, series of events, single event, or act; hence, a limit; a bound; an end; a conclusion
A complete sentence, from one full stop to another; esp., a well-proportioned, harmonious sentence
The punctuation point [.] that marks the end of a complete sentence, or of an abbreviated word
One of several similar sets of figures or terms usually marked by points or commas placed at regular intervals, as in numeration, in the extraction of roots, and in circulating decimals
The time of the exacerbation and remission of a disease, or of the paroxysm and intermission
One of the specified time intervals into which a game is divided; as, there are three periods in a hockey game
One of the specified time intervals into which the academic day is divided; as, my calculus class is in the first period
The time interval during which a woman is menstruating, or the event of a single menstruation; as, her period was late this month
To come to a period; to conclude. [Obs.] “You may period upon this, that,” etc

periodic.definition: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, the highest oxygen acid (HIO4) of iodine
Of or pertaining to a period or periods, or to division by periods
Performed in a period, or regular revolution; proceeding in a series of successive circuits; as, the periodical motion of the planets round the sun
Happening, by revolution, at a stated time; returning regularly, after a certain period of time
Acting, happening, or appearing, at fixed or somewhat variable intervals; recurring; as, periodical epidemics
Of or pertaining to a period; constituting a complete sentence

periodical.definition: A magazine or other publication which appears at stated or regular intervals

periodicalist.definition: One who publishes, or writes for, a periodical

periodically.definition: In a periodical{4} manner; as, flooding occurs periodically in the valley

periodicity.definition: The quality or state of being periodical, or regularly recurrent; as, the periodicity in the vital phenomena of plants

periodide.definition: An iodide containing a higher proportion of iodine than any other iodide of the same substance or series

periodontitis.definition: A disease that attacks the gum and bone around the teeth

periodoscope.definition: A table or other means for calculating the periodical functions of women

perioeci.definition: Those who live on the same parallel of latitude but on opposite meridians, so that it is noon in one place when it is midnight in the other. Compare Antœci

periople.definition: The external smooth horny layer of the hoof of the horse and allied animals

perioplic.definition: Of or pertaining to the periople; connected with the periople

periosteal.definition: Situated around bone; of or pertaining to the periosteum

periosteum.definition: The membrane of fibrous connective tissue which closely invests all bones except at the articular surfaces

periostracum.definition: A chitinous membrane covering the exterior of many shells; -- called also epidermis

periotic.definition: Surrounding, or pertaining to the region surrounding, the internal ear; as, the periotic capsule

peripatetic.definition: Of or pertaining to the philosophy taught by Aristotle (who gave his instructions while walking in the Lyceum at Athens), or to his followers
One who walks about; a pedestrian; an itinerant
A disciple of Aristotle; an Aristotelian

peripateticism.definition: The doctrines or philosophical system of the peripatetics. See Peripatetic, n., 2

peripatopsis.definition: The type genus of Peripatopsidae, consisting of onychophorans (lowly organized invertebrates related evolutionarily to the arthropods, also called “walking worms” AND “velvet worms”) found chiefly in Asiatic and African tropical regions, in South Africa, Australia, New Zealand, and tropical America

peripetalous.definition: Surrounding, or situated about, the petals

peripheral.definition: Of or pertaining to a periphery; constituting a periphery; peripheric
External; away from the center; on or near the surface; as, the peripheral portion of the nervous system
Pertaining to minor, unimportant, superficial, or irrelevant aspects of the matter in question; as, peripheral isssues are dealt with in the appendix

periphery.definition: The outside or superficial portions of a body; the surface
The circumference of a circle, ellipse, or other figure

periphrase.definition: The use of more words than are necessary to express the idea; a roundabout, or indirect, way of speaking; circumlocution
To express by periphrase or circumlocution

periphrastic.definition: Expressing, or expressed, in more words than are necessary; characterized by periphrase; circumlocutory

periproct.definition: The region surrounding the anus, particularly of echinoderms

periproctitis.definition: Inflammation of the tissues about the rectum

peripteral.definition: Having columns on all sides; -- said of an edifice. See Apteral

periptery.definition: The region surrounding a moving body, such as the wing of a bird or a gliding aëroplane, within which cyclic or vortical motion of the air occur

perique.definition: A kind of tobacco with medium-sized leaf, small stem, tough and gummy fiber, raised in Louisiana, and cured in its own juices, so as to be very dark colored, usually black.  It is marketed in tightly wrapped rolls called carottes

perisarc.definition: The outer, hardened integument which covers most hydroids

periscian.definition: Having the shadow moving all around

periscians.definition: Those who live within a polar circle, whose shadows, during some summer days, will move entirely round, falling toward every point of the compass

periscope.definition: An optical instrument of tubular shape containing an arrangement of lenses and mirrors (or prisms), allowing a person to observe a field of view otherwise obstructed, as beyond an obstructing object or (as in submarines) above the surface of the water

periscopic.definition: Viewing all around, or on all sides
of or relating to a periscope{2}

perish.definition: To be destroyed; to pass away; to become nothing; to be lost; to die; hence, to wither; to waste away

perishable.definition: Liable to perish; subject to decay, destruction, or death; as, perishable goods; our perishable bodies

perishableness.definition: The quality or state of being perishable; liability to decay or destruction

perishably.definition: In a perishable degree or manner

perisome.definition: The entire covering of an invertebrate animal, as echinoderm or cœlenterate; the integument

perisperm.definition: The albumen of a seed, especially that portion which is formed outside of the embryo sac

perispomenon.definition: A word which has the circumflex accent on the last syllable

perispore.definition: The outer covering of a spore

perissad.definition: Odd; not even; -- said of elementary substances and of radicals whose valence is not divisible by two without a remainder.  Contrasted with artiad

perissodactyla.definition: A division of ungulate mammals, including those that have an odd number of toes, as the horse, tapir, and rhinoceros; -- opposed to Artiodactyla

peristaltic.definition: Pertaining to a wormlike wave motion of the intestines, and by analogy, of other flexible tubular structures.  In the body it is produced by a progressive contraction of the muscular fibers of their walls, forcing their contents onwards in the direction of the wave; as, peristaltic movement

peristeria.definition: A genus of orchidaceous plants. See Dove plant

peristerite.definition: A variety of albite, whitish and slightly iridescent like a pigeon's neck

peristeromorphous.definition: Like or pertaining to the pigeons or Columbæ

peristeropodous.definition: Having pigeonlike feet; -- said of those gallinaceous birds that rest on all four toes, as the curassows and megapods

peristole.definition: Peristaltic action, especially of the intestines

peristome.definition: The fringe of teeth around the orifice of the capsule of mosses. It consists of 4, 8, 16, 32, or 64 teeth, and may be either single or double
The lip, or edge of the aperture, of a spiral shell

peristomial.definition: Of or pertaining to a peristome

peristrephic.definition: Turning around; rotatory; revolving; as, a peristrephic painting (of a panorama)

peristyle.definition: A range of columns with their entablature, etc.; specifically, a complete system of columns, whether on all sides of a court, or surrounding a building, such as the cella of a temple.  Used in the former sense, it gives name to the larger and inner court of a Roman dwelling, the peristyle. See Colonnade

perisystole.definition: The interval between the diastole and systole of the heart.  It is perceptible only in the dying

perithecium.definition: An organ in certain fungi and lichens, surrounding and enveloping the masses of fructification

peritomous.definition: Cleaving in more directions than one, parallel to the axis

peritoneal.definition: Of or pertaining to the peritoneum

peritoneum.definition: The smooth serous membrane which lines the cavity of the abdomen, or the whole body cavity when there is no diaphragm, and, turning back, surrounds the viscera, forming a closed, or nearly closed, sac

peritreme.definition: That part of the integument of an insect which surrounds the spiracles

peritricha.definition: A division of ciliated Infusoria having a circle of cilia around the oral disk and sometimes another around the body.  It includes the vorticellas.  See Vorticella

peritrochium.definition: The wheel which, together with the axle, forms the axis in peritrochio, which see under Axis

peritropal.definition: Having the axis of the seed perpendicular to the axis of the pericarp to which it is attached

perityphlitis.definition: Inflammation of the connective tissue about the cæcum

perivascular.definition: Around the blood vessels; as, perivascular lymphatics

perivisceral.definition: Around the viscera; as, the perivisceral cavity

perivitelline.definition: Situated around the vitellus, or between the vitellus and zona pellucida of an ovum

periwig.definition: A headdress of false hair, usually covering the whole head, and representing the natural hair; a wig
To dress with a periwig, or with false hair

periwigged.definition: Wearing a peruke (a style of wig popular for men in the 17th and 18th centuries)

periwinkle.definition: Any small marine gastropod shell of the genus Littorina.  The common European species (Littorina littorea), in Europe extensively used as food, has recently become naturalized abundantly on the American coast.  See Littorina
A trailing herb of the genus Vinca

perjure.definition: To cause to violate an oath or a vow; to cause to make oath knowingly to what is untrue; to make guilty of perjury; to forswear; to corrupt; -- often used reflexively; as, he perjured himself
To make a false oath to; to deceive by oaths and protestations

perjured.definition: Guilty of perjury; having sworn falsely; forsworn

perjurer.definition: One who is guilty of perjury; one who perjures or forswears, in any sense

perjury.definition: At common law, a willfully false statement in a fact material to the issue, made by a witness under oath in a competent judicial proceeding.  By statute the penalties of perjury are imposed on the making of willfully false affirmations

perk.definition: To make trim or smart; to straighten up; to erect; to make a jaunty or saucy display of; as, to perk the ears; to perk up one's head
To exalt one's self; to bear one's self loftily
To act in a jaunty or presumptuous manner

perkinism.definition: A remedial treatment, by drawing the pointed extremities of two rods, each of a different metal, over the affected part; tractoration, -- first employed by Dr. Elisha Perkins of Norwich, Conn.  See Metallotherapy

perlid.definition: Any insect of the genus Perla, or family Perlidæ. See Stone fly, under Stone

perlitic.definition: Relating to or resembling perlite, or pearlstone; as, the perlitic structure of certain rocks. See Pearlite

perlustration.definition: The act of viewing all over

permanence.definition: The quality or state of being permanent; continuance in the same state or place; duration; fixedness; as, the permanence of institutions; the permanence of nature

permanent.definition: Continuing in the same state, or without any change that destroys form or character; remaining unaltered or unremoved; abiding; durable; fixed; stable; lasting; as, a permanent impression
A wave or curl in the hair that lasts for months and is made durable by treating the hair with chemicals when it is curled

permanent wave.definition: A wave or curl in the hair that lasts for months and is made durable by treating the hair with chemicals when it is curled
The process of treating the hair with chemicals to create a permanent wave{1}

permanent-press.definition: aAfabric that has been chemically processed to resist wrinkles and hold its shape
synonyms: Syn. -- permanent press, permanent-press fabric, durable press, durable-press fabric.

permanent-press.definition: Having a permanent crease, or remaining unwrinkled without pressing; -- used of fabrics that do not require ironing

permanganic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, one of the higher acids of manganese, HMnO4, which forms salts called permanganates

permeability.definition: The quality or state of being permeable

permeable.definition: Capable of being permeated, or passed through; yielding passage; passable; penetrable; -- used especially of substances which allow the passage of fluids; as, wood is permeable to oil; glass is permeable to light

permeate.definition: To pass through the pores or interstices of; to penetrate and pass through without causing rupture or displacement; -- applied especially to fluids which pass through substances of loose texture; as, water permeates sand
To enter and spread through; to pervade; as, after the first setback, the team became permeated with pessimism

permeated.definition: p. p. of permeate; as, Her poems are permeated with sorrow

permeation.definition: The act of permeating, passing through, or spreading throughout, the pores or interstices of any substance

permed.definition: Treated with chemicals to make it curly; having been given a permanent wave; -- of hair; as, permed hair

permian.definition: Belonging or relating to the period, and also to the formation, next following the Carboniferous, and regarded as closing the Carboniferous age and Paleozoic era

permians.definition: A tribe belonging to the Finnic race, and inhabiting a portion of Russia

permiss.definition: A permitted choice; a rhetorical figure in which a thing is committed to the decision of one's opponent

permissibility.definition: The quality of being permissible; permissibleness; allowableness

permissible.definition: That may be permitted; allowable; admissible

permission.definition: The act of permitting or allowing; formal consent; authorization; leave; license or liberty granted

permistion.definition: The act of mixing; the state of being mingled; mixture

permit.definition: To consent to; to allow or suffer to be done; to tolerate; to put up with
To grant (one) express license or liberty to do an act; to authorize; to give leave; -- followed by an infinitive
To give over; to resign; to leave; to commit
Warrant; license; leave; permission; specifically, a written license or permission given to a person or persons having authority; as, a permit to land goods subject to duty
A large pompano (Trachinotus goodei) of the West Indies, Florida, etc.  It becomes about three feet long

permittance.definition: The act of permitting; allowance; permission; leave

permittee.definition: One to whom a permission or permit is given

permulator.definition: A special form of rotary converter with stationary commutator and rotating brushes, in which the exciting field is induced by the alternating current in a short-circuited magnetic core instead of being produced by an external magnet

permutation.definition: The act of permuting; exchange of the thing for another; mutual transference; interchange
The arrangement of any determinate number of things, as units, objects, letters, etc., in all possible orders, one after the other; -- called also alternation.  Cf. Combination, n., 4

permute.definition: To exchange; to barter; to traffic

pern.definition: To take profit of; to make profitable

pernancy.definition: A taking or reception, as the receiving of rents or tithes in kind, the receiving of profits

pernicious.definition: Having the quality of injuring or killing; destructive; very mischievous; baleful; malicious; wicked

pernickety.definition: Finical or fussy; full of petty details
synonyms: Syn. -- finical, finicky, fussy, meticulous, painstaking, persnickety, punctilious.

pernoctalian.definition: One who watches or keeps awake all night

pernoctation.definition: The act or state of passing the whole night; a remaining all night

pernor.definition: One who receives the profits, as of an estate

pernot furnace.definition: A reverberatory furnace with a circular revolving hearth, -- used in making steel

pernyi moth.definition: A silk-producing moth (Attacus Pernyi) which feeds upon the oak.  It has been introduced into Europe and America from China

peromyscus.definition: A genus of New World wood mice

peronate.definition: A term applied to the stipes or stalks of certain fungi which are covered with a woolly substance which at length becomes powdery

peroneal.definition: Of or pertaining to the fibula; in the region of the fibula

peronospora.definition: A genus of destructive downy mildews

peronosporaceae.definition: A natural family of parasitic fungi; the downy mildews

peronosporales.definition: An order of chiefly parasitic lower fungi, including the Albuginaceae and Peronosporaceae and Pythiaceae

perorate.definition: To make a peroration; to harangue

peroration.definition: The concluding part of an oration; especially, a final summing up and enforcement of an argument

perovskite.definition: A titanate of lime occurring in octahedral or cubic crystals

peroxidation.definition: Act, process, or result of peroxidizing; oxidation to a peroxide

peroxide.definition: An oxide containing more oxygen than some other oxide of the same element. Formerly peroxides were regarded as the highest oxides.  Cf. Per-, 2

peroxidize.definition: To oxidize to the utmost degree, so as to form a peroxide

perpend.definition: To weight carefully in the mind

perpender.definition: A large stone reaching through a wall so as to appear on both sides of it, and acting as a binder; -- called also perbend, perpend stone, and perpent stone

perpendicle.definition: Something hanging straight down; a plumb line

perpendicular.definition: Exactly upright or vertical; pointing to the zenith; at right angles to the plane of the horizon; extending in a right line from any point toward the center of the earth
At right angles to a given line or surface; as, the line ad is perpendicular to the line bc
A line at right angles to the plane of the horizon; a vertical line or direction
A line or plane falling at right angles on another line or surface, or making equal angles with it on each side

perpendicularity.definition: The quality or state of being perpendicular

perpetrate.definition: To do or perform; to carry through; to execute, commonly in a bad sense; to commit (as a crime, an offense); to be guilty of; as, to perpetrate a foul deed

perpetration.definition: The act of perpetrating; a doing; -- commonly used of doing something wrong, as a crime
The thing perpetrated; an evil action

perpetrator.definition: One who perpetrates; esp., one who commits an offense or crime

perpetuable.definition: Capable of being perpetuated or continued

perpetual.definition: Neverceasing; continuing forever or for an unlimited time; unfailing; everlasting; continuous

perpetual calendar.definition: A calendar that can be used perpetually or over a wide range of years. That of Capt. Herschel covers, as given below, dates from 1750 to 1961 only, but is capable of indefinite extension

perpetually.definition: In a perpetual manner; constantly; continually

perpetualty.definition: The state or condition of being perpetual

perpetuate.definition: To make perpetual; to cause to endure, or to be continued, indefinitely; to preserve from extinction or oblivion; to eternize

perpetuation.definition: The act of making perpetual, or of preserving from extinction through an endless existence, or for an indefinite period of time; continuance

perpetuity.definition: The quality or state of being perpetual; as, the perpetuity of laws
The number of years in which the simple interest of any sum becomes equal to the principal
Duration without limitations as to time

perplex.definition: To involve; to entangle; to make intricate or complicated, and difficult to be unraveled or understood; as, to perplex one with doubts
To embarrass; to puzzle; to distract; to bewilder; to confuse; to trouble with ambiguity, suspense, or anxiety
To plague; to vex; to torment

perplexed.definition: Entangled, involved, or confused; hence, embarrassd; puzzled; doubtful; anxious

perplexity.definition: The quality or state of being perplexed or puzzled; complication; intricacy; entanglement; distraction of mind through doubt or difficulty; embarrassment; bewilderment; doubt

perplexiveness.definition: The quality of being perplexing; tendency to perplex

perpotation.definition: The act of drinking excessively; a drinking bout

perquisite.definition: Something gained from a place or employment over and above the ordinary salary or fixed wages for services rendered; -- examples are, a fee allowed by law to an officer for a specific service; the use of a company automobile or other company property
Things gotten by a man's own industry, or purchased with his own money, as opposed to things which come to him by descent

perradial.definition: Situated around the radii, or radial tubes, of a radiate

perrier.definition: A short mortar used formerly for throwing stone shot
The name of a brand of bottled mineral water; a glass or bottle of such water; as, I'll have a Perrier

perron.definition: An out-of-door flight of steps, as in a garden, leading to a terrace or to an upper story; -- usually applied to mediævel or later structures of some architectural pretensions

perruquier.definition: A maker of perukes or wigs

perry.definition: A fermented liquor made from pears; pear cider

pers.definition: Light blue; grayish blue; -- a term applied to different shades at different periods

persalt.definition: A term formerly given to the salts supposed to be formed respectively by neutralizing acids with certain peroxides

perscrutation.definition: A thorough searching; a minute inquiry or scrutiny

persecute.definition: To pursue in a manner to injure, grieve, or afflict; to beset with cruelty or malignity; to harass; especially, to afflict, harass, punish, or put to death, for adherence to a particular religious creed or mode of worship
To harass with importunity; to pursue with persistent solicitations; to annoy

persecution.definition: The act or practice of persecuting; especially, the infliction of loss, pain, or death for adherence to a particular creed or mode of worship
The state or condition of being persecuted

perseid.definition: One of a group of shooting stars which appear yearly about the 10th of August, and cross the heavens in paths apparently radiating from the constellation Perseus.  They are probably fragments of Swift's comet of 1862 (III)

perseus.definition: A Grecian legendary hero, son of Jupiter and Danaë, who slew the Gorgon Medusa
A consellation of the northern hemisphere, near Taurus and Cassiopea. It contains a star cluster visible to the naked eye as a nebula

perseverance.definition: The act of persevering; persistence in anything undertaken; continued pursuit or prosecution of any business, or enterprise begun
Continuance in a state of grace until it is succeeded by a state of glory; sometimes called final perseverance, and the perseverance of the saints. See Calvinism

persevere.definition: To persist in any business or enterprise undertaken; to pursue steadily any project or course begun; to maintain a purpose in spite of counter influences, opposition, or discouragement; not to give or abandon what is undertaken

persian.definition: Of or pertaining to Persia, to the Persians, or to their language
A native or inhabitant of Persia
The language spoken in Persia.  Ancient Persian of the 3rd to 10th centuries is also called Pahlavi, and modern Persian is also called Farsi
A thin silk fabric, used formerly for linings

persicot.definition: A cordial made of the kernels of apricots, nectarines, etc., with refined spirit

persienne.definition: Properly, printed calico, whether Oriental or of fanciful design with flowers, etc., in Western work.  Hence, as extended in English, material of a similar character

persiennes.definition: Window blinds having movable slats, similar to Venetian blinds

persiflage.definition: Frivolous or bantering talk; a frivolous manner of treating any subject, whether serious or otherwise; light raillery

persifleur.definition: One who indulges in persiflage; a banterer; a quiz

persimmon.definition: An American tree (Diospyros Virginiana) and its fruit, found from New York southward.  The fruit is like a plum in appearance, but is very harsh and astringent until it has been exposed to frost, when it becomes palatable and nutritious

persis.definition: A kind of coloring matter obtained from lichens

persism.definition: An ancient Persian religion, esp. as represented by the Magi; a form of Zoroastrianism

persist.definition: To stand firm; to be fixed and unmoved; to stay; to continue steadfastly; especially, to continue fixed in a course of conduct against opposing motives; to persevere; -- sometimes conveying an unfavorable notion, as of doggedness or obstinacy

persistence.definition: The quality or state of being persistent; staying or continuing quality; hence, in an unfavorable sense, doggedness; obstinacy
The continuance of an effect after the cause which first gave rise to it is removed

persistent.definition: Inclined to persist; having staying qualities; tenacious of position or purpose
