Remaining beyond the period when parts of the same kind sometimes fall off or are absorbed; permanent; as, persistent teeth or gills; a persistent calyx; -- opposed to deciduous, and caducous

persisting.definition: Inclined to persist; tenacious of purpose; persistent

persnickety.definition: Finicky or fussy; demanding excessive attention to petty details or niceties; unduly particular; fastidious; -- of people
synonyms: Syn. -- finical, finicky, fussy, meticulous, painstaking, pernickety, pernicketty, punctilious.

person.definition: A character or part, as in a play; a specific kind or manifestation of individual character, whether in real life, or in literary or dramatic representation; an assumed character
The bodily form of a human being; body; outward appearance; as, of comely person
A living, self-conscious being, as distinct from an animal or a thing; a moral agent; a human being; a man, woman, or child
A human being spoken of indefinitely; one; a man; as, any person present
Among Trinitarians, one of the three subdivisions of the Godhead (the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost); an hypostasis

One of three relations or conditions (that of speaking, that of being spoken to, and that of being spoken of) pertaining to a noun or a pronoun, and thence also to the verb of which it may be the subject
A shoot or bud of a plant; a polyp or zooid of the compound Hydrozoa, Anthozoa, etc.; also, an individual, in the narrowest sense, among the higher animals
To represent as a person; to personify; to impersonate

personable.definition: Having a well-formed body, or person; graceful; comely; of good appearance; presentable; as, a personable man or woman
Enabled to maintain pleas in court

personableness.definition: The complex of attributes that make a person socially attractive

personage.definition: Form, appearance, or belongings of a person; the external appearance, stature, figure, air, and the like, of a person
A notable or distinguished person; a conspicuous or peculiar character; as, an illustrious personage; a comely personage of stature tall

personal.definition: Pertaining to human beings as distinct from things

Of or pertaining to a particular person; relating to, or affecting, an individual, or each of many individuals; peculiar or proper to private concerns; not public or general; as, personal comfort; personal desire
Pertaining to the external or bodily appearance; corporeal; as, personal charms
Done in person; without the intervention of another
Relating to an individual, his character, conduct, motives, or private affairs, in an invidious and offensive manner; as, personal reflections or remarks
Denoting person; as, a personal pronoun

personal computer.definition: A computer{2} designed for use by one person at a time; -- contrasted with shared-time computers such as a mainframe, server or minicomputer, which may be accessed by multiple users each operating from a different input device (in the 1990's, usually a terminal or personal computer).   A personal computer typically uses a microprocessor for its CPU

personalism.definition: The quality or state of being personal; personality

personality.definition: That which constitutes distinction of person; the externally evident aspects of the character or behavior of a person; individuality
Something said or written which refers to the person, conduct, etc., of some individual, especially something of a disparaging or offensive nature; personal remarks; as, indulgence in personalities
That quality of a law which concerns the condition, state, and capacity of persons
A person who is famous or notable; a celebrity

personalized.definition: Made for or directed or adjusted to a particular individual; modified for a particular person; as, personalized luggage; personalized advice
Pointedly referring to or concerning a person's individual personality or intimate affairs, especially offensively; as, personalized criticism

personally.definition: In a personal manner; by bodily presence; in person; not by representative or substitute; as, to deliver a letter personally
With respect to an individual; as regards the person; individually; particularly
With respect to one's individuality; as regards one's self; as, personally I have no feeling in the matter

personalty.definition: The state of being a person; personality
Personal property, as distinguished from realty or real property

personate.definition: To celebrate loudly; to extol; to praise

To assume the character of; to represent by a fictitious appearance; to act the part of; to impersonate{3}; hence, to counterfeit; to feign; as, he tried to personate his brother; a personated devotion
To set forth in an unreal character; to disguise; to mask
To personify; to typify; to describe
To play or assume a character
Having the throat of a bilabiate corolla nearly closed by a projection of the base of the lower lip; masked, as in the flower of the snapdragon

personation.definition: The act of personating, or conterfeiting the person or character of another; impersonation

personification.definition: The act of personifying; impersonation; embodiment
A figure of speech in which an inanimate object or abstract idea is represented as animated, or endowed with personality; prosopopœia; as, the floods clap their hands

personify.definition: To regard, treat, or represent as a person; to represent as a rational being
To be the embodiment or personification of; to impersonate; as, he personifies the law

personnel.definition: The body of persons employed in some public service, as the army, navy, etc.; -- distinguished from materiel

persoonia.definition: A genus of Australian undershrubs to small trees; the geebungs

perspective.definition: Of or pertaining to the science of vision; optical
Pertaining to the art, or in accordance with the laws, of perspective
A glass through which objects are viewed
That which is seen through an opening; a view; a vista

The effect of distance upon the appearance of objects, by means of which the eye recognizes them as being at a more or less measurable distance. Hence, aërial perspective, the assumed greater vagueness or uncertainty of outline in distant objects
The art and the science of so delineating objects that they shall seem to grow smaller as they recede from the eye; -- called also linear perspective

perspectively.definition: According to the rules of perspective

perspectograph.definition: An instrument for obtaining, and transferring to a picture, the points and outlines of objects, so as to represent them in their proper geometrical relations as viewed from some one point

perspectography.definition: The science or art of delineating objects according to the laws of perspective; the theory of perspective

perspicacious.definition: Having the power of seeing clearly; quick-sighted; sharp of sight

perspicacity.definition: The state of being perspicacious; acuteness of sight or of intelligence; acute discernment

perspicuity.definition: The quality or state of being transparent or translucent
The quality of being perspicuous to the understanding; clearness of expression or thought

perspicuous.definition: Capable of being through; transparent; translucent; not opaque
Clear to the understanding; capable of being clearly understood; clear in thought or in expression; not obscure or ambiguous; as, a perspicuous writer; perspicuous statements

perspirability.definition: The quality or state of being perspirable

perspiration.definition: The act or process of perspiring
That which is excreted through the skin; sweat

perspirative.definition: Performing the act of perspiration; perspiratory

perspiratory.definition: Of, pertaining to, or producing, perspiration; as, the perspiratory ducts

perspire.definition: To excrete matter through the skin; esp., to excrete fluids through the pores of the skin; to sweat
To be evacuated or excreted, or to exude, through the pores of the skin; as, a fluid perspires
To emit or evacuate through the pores of the skin; to sweat; to excrete through pores

perstringe.definition: To touch; to graze; to glance on

persuade.definition: To influence or gain over by argument, advice, entreaty, expostulation, etc.; to draw or incline to a determination by presenting sufficient motives
To convince by argument, or by reasons offered or suggested from reflection, etc.; to cause to believe
To inculcate by argument or expostulation; to advise; to recommend
To use persuasion; to plead; to prevail by persuasion

persuaded.definition: Prevailed upon; influenced by argument or entreaty; convinced

persuader.definition: One who, or that which, persuades or influences

persuasion.definition: The act of persuading; the act of influencing the mind by arguments or reasons offered, or by anything that moves the mind or passions, or inclines the will to a determination
The state of being persuaded or convinced; settled opinion or conviction, which has been induced
A creed or belief; a sect or party adhering to a certain creed or system of opinions; as, of the same persuasion; all persuasions are agreed
The power or quality of persuading; persuasiveness

persuasive.definition: Tending to persuade; having the power of persuading; as, persuasive eloquence
That which persuades; an inducement; an incitement; an exhortation

persulphate.definition: A sulphate of the peroxide of any base

persulphide.definition: A sulphide containing more sulphur than some other compound of the same elements; as, iron pyrites is a persulphide; -- formerly called persulphuret

persulphocyanic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, a yellow crystalline substance (called also perthiocyanic acid), analogous to sulphocyanic acid, but containing more sulphur

persulphocyanogen.definition: An orange-yellow substance, produced by the action of chlorine or boiling dilute nitric acid and sulphocyanate of potassium; -- called also pseudosulphocyanogen, perthiocyanogen, and formerly sulphocyanogen

pert.definition: Indecorously free, or presuming; saucy; bold; impertinent

pertain.definition: To belong; to have connection with, or dependence on, something, as an appurtenance, attribute, etc.; to appertain; as, saltness pertains to the ocean; flowers pertain to plant life
To have relation or reference to something

perthite.definition: A kind of feldspar consisting of a laminated intertexture of albite and orthoclase, usually of different colors

pertinacious.definition: Holding or adhering to any opinion, purpose, or design, with obstinacy; perversely persistent; obstinate; as, pertinacious plotters; a pertinacious beggar

pertinacity.definition: The quality or state of being pertinacious; obstinacy; perseverance; persistency

pertinacy.definition: The quality or state of being pertinent; pertinence

pertinence.definition: The quality or state of being pertinent; justness of relation to the subject or matter in hand; fitness; appositeness; relevancy; suitableness

pertinent.definition: Belonging or related to the subject or matter in hand; fit or appropriate in any way; adapted to the end proposed; apposite; material; relevant; as, pertinent illustrations or arguments; pertinent evidence

pertness.definition: The quality or state of being pert

perturb.definition: To disturb; to agitate; to vex; to trouble; to disquiet

perturbability.definition: The quality or state of being perturbable

perturbable.definition: Liable to be perturbed or agitated; liable to be disturbed or disquieted

perturbation.definition: The act of perturbing, or the state of being perturbed; esp., agitation of mind

A disturbance in the regular elliptic or other motion of a heavenly body, produced by some force additional to that which causes its regular motion; as, the perturbations of the planets are caused by their attraction on each other

perturbational.definition: Of or pertaining to perturbation, esp. to the perturbations of the planets

perturber.definition: One who, or that which, perturbs, or cause perturbation

pertuse.definition: Punched; pierced with, or having, holes

pertusion.definition: The act of punching or piercing with a pointed instrument; as, pertusion of a vein

perula.definition: One of the scales of a leaf bud
A pouchlike portion of the perianth in certain orchides

perusal.definition: The act of carefully viewing or examining
The act of reading, especially of reading through or with care

peruse.definition: To observe; to examine with care
To read through; to read carefully

peruvian.definition: Of or pertaining to Peru, in South America

pervade.definition: To pass or flow through, as an aperture, pore, or interstice; to permeate
To pass or spread through the whole extent of; to be diffused throughout

pervaporation.definition: The concentration of a colloidal solution whose colloid will not pass through a semipermeable membrane; the solution is placed in a bag of the membrane and the solvent is evaporated off

pervasion.definition: The act of pervading, passing, or spreading through the whole extent of a thing

pervasive.definition: Tending to pervade, or having power to spread throughout; of a pervading quality

pervasiveness.definition: The quality of filling or spreading throughout; as, the pervasiveness of the odor of cabbage in tenement hallways

perverse.definition: Turned aside; hence, specifically, turned away from the right; willfully erring; wicked; perverted
Obstinate in the wrong; stubborn; intractable; hence, wayward; vexing; contrary

perverseness.definition: The quality or state of being perverse

perversion.definition: The act of perverting, or the state of being perverted; a turning from truth or right; a diverting from the true intent or object; a change to something worse; a turning or applying to a wrong end or use

perversity.definition: The quality or state of being perverse; perverseness

pervert.definition: To turn another way; to divert
To turn from truth, rectitude, or propriety; to divert from a right use, end, or way; to lead astray; to corrupt; also, to misapply; to misinterpret intentionally; as, to pervert one's words
To become perverted; to take the wrong course
One who has been perverted; one who has turned to error, especially in religion; -- opposed to convert. See the Synonym of Convert

perverter.definition: One who perverts (a person or thing)

pervious.definition: Admitting passage; capable of being penetrated by another body or substance; permeable; as, a pervious soil
Capable of being penetrated, or seen through, by physical or mental vision
Open; -- used synonymously with perforate, as applied to the nostrils or birds

perviousness.definition: The quality or state of being pervious; as, the perviousness of glass

pes.definition: The distal segment of the hind limb of vertebrates, including the tarsus and foot

pesade.definition: The motion of a horse when, raising his fore quarters, he keeps his hind feet on the ground without advancing; rearing

pesage.definition: A fee, or toll, paid for the weighing of merchandise

peseta.definition: A Spanish silver coin, and money of account, equal to about nineteen cents (ca. 1900), and divided into 100 centesimos.  Now replaced by the euro

peshito.definition: The earliest Syriac version of the Old Testament, translated from Hebrew; also, the incomplete Syriac version of the New Testament

pesky.definition: Pestering; vexatious; troublesome. Used also as an intensive

peso.definition: A Spanish dollar; also, an Argentine, Chilian, Colombian, etc., coin, equal to from 75 cents to a dollar; also, a pound weight

pessary.definition: An instrument or device to be introduced into and worn in the vagina, to support the uterus, or remedy a malposition

pessimal.definition: Least favorable for survival; -- of an organism's environment

pessimism.definition: The opinion or doctrine that everything in nature is ordered for or tends to the worst, or that the world is wholly evil; -- opposed to optimism
A disposition to take the least hopeful view of a situation

pessimist.definition: One who advocates the doctrine of pessimism; -- opposed to optimist
One who looks on the dark side of things
Of or pertaining to pessimism; characterized by pessimism; gloomy; foreboding

pessimize.definition: To hold or advocate the doctrine of pessimism

pessulus.definition: A delicate bar of cartilage connecting the dorsal and ventral extremities of the first pair of bronchial cartilages in the syrinx of birds

pest.definition: A fatal epidemic disease; a pestilence; specif., the plague
Anything which resembles a pest; one who, or that which, is troublesome, noxious, mischievous, or destructive; a nuisance

pestalozzian.definition: Belonging to, or characteristic of, a system of elementary education which combined manual training with other instruction, advocated and practiced by Jean Henri Pestalozzi (1746-1827), a Swiss teacher

pestalozzianism.definition: The system of education introduced by Pestalozzi

pester.definition: To trouble; to disturb; to annoy; to harass with petty vexations
To crowd together in an annoying way; to overcrowd; to infest

pestered.definition: Troubled persistently especially with petty annoyances; as, the exasperation of a pestered animal

pesterment.definition: The act of pestering, or the state of being pestered; vexation; worry

pesterous.definition: Inclined to pester. Also, vexatious; encumbering; burdensome

pesthouse.definition: A house or hospital for persons who are infected with any pestilential disease

pestiduct.definition: That which conveys contagion or infection

pestiferous.definition: Pest-bearing; pestilential; noxious to health; malignant; infectious; contagious; as, pestiferous bodies
Noxious to peace, to morals, or to society; vicious; hurtful; destructive; as, a pestiferous demagogue

pestilence.definition: Specifically, the disease known as the plague; hence, any contagious or infectious epidemic disease that is virulent and devastating
Fig.: That which is pestilent, noxious, or pernicious to the moral character of great numbers

pestilential.definition: Having the nature or qualities of a pestilence
Hence: Mischievous; noxious; pernicious; morally destructive

pestilently.definition: In a pestilent manner; mischievously; destructively

pestillation.definition: The act of pounding and bruising with a pestle in a mortar

pestle.definition: An implement for pounding and breaking or braying substances in a mortar; as, to grind with a mortar and pestle
A constable's or bailiff's staff; -- so called from its shape
The leg and leg bone of an animal, especially of a pig; as, a pestle of pork
To pound, pulverize, bray, or mix with a pestle, or as with a pestle; to use a pestle

pesto.definition: A sauce used in Italian cuisine, typically made by blending olive oil, basil, garlic, pine nuts, and grated parmesan cheese; it is served hot or cold over pasta, meat, or fish.  Where pine nuts are expensive, sunflower seeds are sometimes substituted

pet.definition: A cade lamb; a lamb brought up by hand
Any person especially cherished and indulged; a fondling; a darling; often, a favorite child; as, a teacher's pet
A slight fit of peevishness or fretfulness

Any animal kept as a companion, usually in or around one's home, typically domesticated and cared for attentively and often affectionately.  Distinguished from animals raised for food or to perform useful tasks, as a draft animal or a farm animal
Petted; indulged; favorite; admired; cherished; as, a pet child; a pet lamb; a pet theory; a pet animal
To treat as a pet; to fondle; to indulge; as, she was petted and spoiled

petal.definition: One of the leaves of the corolla, or the colored leaves of a flower. See Corolla, and Illust. of Flower
One of the expanded ambulacra which form a rosette on the black of certain Echini

petaled.definition: Having petals; as, a petaled flower; -- opposed to apetalous, and much used in compounds; as, one-petaled, three-petaled, etc

petaliform.definition: Having the form of a petal; petaloid; petal-shaped

petaline.definition: Pertaining to a petal; attached to, or resembling, a petal

petalism.definition: A form of sentence among the ancient Syracusans by which they banished for five years a citizen suspected of having dangerous influence or ambition.  It was similar to the ostracism in Athens; but olive leaves were used instead of shells for ballots

petalite.definition: A rare mineral, occurring crystallized and in cleavable masses, usually white, or nearly so, in color.  It is a silicate of aluminum and lithium

petalody.definition: The metamorphosis of various floral organs, usually stamens, into petals

petaloideous.definition: Having the whole or part of the perianth petaline

petalosticha.definition: An order of Echini, including the irregular sea urchins, as the spatangoids. See Spatangoid

petalous.definition: Having petals; petaled; -- opposed to apetalous

petard.definition: A case containing powder to be exploded, esp. a conical or cylindrical case of metal filled with powder and attached to a plank, to be exploded against and break down gates, barricades, drawbridges, etc.  It has been superseded

petasus.definition: The winged cap of Mercury; also, a broad-brimmed, low-crowned hat worn by Greeks and Romans

petaurist.definition: Any flying marsupial of the genera Petaurus, Phalangista, Acrobata, and allied genera.  See Flying mouse, under Flying, and Phalangister

petaurista.definition: A genus of very large Asiatic flying squirrels

petauristidae.definition: A natural family of Old World flying squirrels

petcock.definition: A small cock or faucet or valve for letting out air or releasing compression, or for draining a vessel

petechiae.definition: Small crimson, purple, or livid spots, like flea-bites, due to extravasation of blood, which appear on the skin in malignant fevers, etc

petechial.definition: Characterized by, or pertaining to, petechiæ; spotted

peter.definition: A common baptismal name for a man.  The name of one of the twelve apostles of Christ
To become depleted; to run out; to fail; -- used generally with out; as, that mine has petered out

peterman.definition: A fisherman; -- so called after the apostle Peter

petersham.definition: A rough, knotted woolen cloth, used chiefly for men's overcoats; also, a coat of that material

petiolar.definition: Of or pertaining to petiole, or proceeding from it; as, a petiolar tendril; growing or supported upon a petiole; as, a petiolar gland; a petiolar bud

petiolate.definition: Having a stalk or petiole; as, a petioleate leaf; the petiolated abdomen of certain Hymenoptera

petiole.definition: A leafstalk; the footstalk of a leaf, connecting the blade with the stem. See Illust. of Leaf

petiolule.definition: A small petiole, or the petiole of a leaflet

petit.definition: Small; little; insignificant; mean; -- Same as Petty

petit mal.definition: The mildest form of epilepsy, with momentary faintness or unconsciousness, but without convulsions; -- opposed to grand mal

petite.definition: Small, little; -- used especially of a woman or girl, of small size and trim figure; as, her petite figure
synonyms: Syn. -- bantam, diminutive, lilliputian, midget, tiny.

petite.definition: A size category of women's clothing, for women with less than average height
An aricle of women's clothing classified in the petite{1} size category
A girl or woman whose figure is best fit by a petite{1} garment

petitio.definition: The fallacy of assuming the conclusion in the premises; begging the question

petition.definition: A prayer; a supplication; an imploration; an entreaty; especially, a request of a solemn or formal kind; a prayer to the Supreme Being, or to a person of superior power, rank, or authority; also, a single clause in such a prayer
A formal written request addressed to an official person, or to an organized body, having power to grant it

A request to government, in either of its branches, for the granting of a particular grace or right, or for the legislature to take a specific action; -- in distinction from a memorial, which calls certain facts to mind.  The petition may be signed by one or any number of persons
The written document containing a petition (senses 1 or 2)

To make a prayer or request to; to ask from; to solicit; to entreat; especially, to make a formal written supplication, or application to, as to any branch of the government; as, to petition the court; to petition the governor
To make a petition or solicitation

petitionarily.definition: By way of begging the question; by an assumption

petitionary.definition: Containing a petition; of the nature of a petition; as, a petitionary epistle

petitionee.definition: A person cited to answer, or defend against, a petition

petitioning.definition: The act of presenting apetition; a supplication

petitor.definition: One who seeks or asks; a seeker; an applicant

petrary.definition: An ancient war engine for hurling stones

petrel.definition: Any one of numerous species of longwinged sea birds belonging to the family Procellaridæ.  The small petrels, or Mother Carey's chickens, belong to Oceanites, Oceanodroma, Procellaria, and several allied genera

petrescence.definition: The process of changing into stone; petrification

petrescent.definition: Petrifying; converting into stone; as, petrescent water

petrifaction.definition: The process of petrifying, or changing into stone; conversion of any organic matter (animal or vegetable) into stone, or a substance of stony hardness
The state or condition of being petrified
That which is petrified; popularly, a body incrusted with stony matter; an incrustation

petrifactive.definition: Having the quality of converting organic matter into stone; petrifying
Pertaining to, or characterized by, petrifaction

petrified.definition: Converted into a mineral; as, petrified wood

synonyms: Syn. -- panicky, panic-stricken, panic-struck, terrified, frightened.

petrified.definition: rendered unable to act due to intense fear
Rendered lifeless or inactive; as, an imagination petrified by habitual television viewing

petrify.definition: To convert, as any animal or vegetable matter, into stone or stony substance; as, petrified wood
To make callous or obdurate; to transform, as by petrifaction; as, to petrify the heart. Young
To paralyze, especially with fear; to stupefy; as, she was petrified by the sight of the bear in her tent
To become stone, or of a stony hardness, as organic matter by calcareous deposits
Fig.: To become stony, callous, or obdurate

petrine.definition: Of or pertaining to St. Peter; as, the Petrine Epistles

petro-.definition: A combining form from Gr. pe`tra a rock, pe`tros a stone; as, petrology, petroglyphic

petrocoptis.definition: A genus of perennial tussock-forming rock plants; native to the Pyrenees and mountains of Northern Spain; it is similar to and sometimes placed in the genus Lychnis

petrogale.definition: Any Australian kangaroo of the genus Petrogale, as the rock wallaby (Petrogale penicillata)

petroglyph.definition: A carving or drawing on rock, especially one made by prehistoric humans; called also a petrograph

petroglyphic.definition: Of or pertaining to petroglyphs or petroglyphy

petroglyphy.definition: The art or operation of carving figures or inscriptions on rock or stone

petrograph.definition: A carving or drawing on rock, especially one made by prehistoric humans; called also a petrograph

petrography.definition: The art of writing on stone
The scientific description of rocks; that department of science which investigates the constitution of rocks; petrology

petrohyoid.definition: Pertaining to the petrous, or periotic, portion of the skull and the hyoid arch; as, the petrohyoid muscles of the frog

petrolatum.definition: A semisolid unctuous substance, neutral, and without taste or odor, derived from petroleum by distilling off the lighter portions and purifying the residue.  It is a yellowish, fatlike mass, transparent in thin layers, and somewhat fluorescent.  It is used as a bland protective dressing, and as a substitute for fatty materials in ointments

petroleum.definition: Rock oil, mineral oil, or natural oil, a dark brown or greenish inflammable liquid, which, at certain points, exists in the upper strata of the earth, from whence it is pumped, or forced by pressure of the gas attending it.  It consists of a complex mixture of various hydrocarbons, largely of the methane series, but may vary much in appearance, composition, and properties.  It is refined by distillation, and the products include kerosene, benzine, gasoline, paraffin, etc

petroleur.definition: One who makes use of petroleum for incendiary purposes

petroline.definition: A paraffin obtained from petroleum from Rangoon in India, and practically identical with ordinary paraffin

petrologist.definition: One who is versed in petrology

petrology.definition: The department of science which is concerned with the mineralogical and chemical composition of rocks, and with their classification: lithology

petromastoid.definition: Of or pertaining to the petrous and mastoid parts of the temporal bone; periotic

petronel.definition: A sort of hand cannon, or portable firearm, used in France in the 15th century

petrosal.definition: Hard; stony; petrous; as, the petrosal bone; petrosal part of the temporal bone

petrostearine.definition: A solid unctuous material, of which candles are made

petrous.definition: Like stone; hard; stony; rocky; as, the petrous part of the temporal bone

petticoat.definition: A loose under-garment worn by women, and covering the body below the waist

petticoated.definition: wearing or furnished with a petticoat; as, petticoated ladies; a petticoated table

pettifog.definition: To do a petty business as a lawyer; also, to do law business in a petty or tricky way
To debate or quarrel over unimportant, trifling matters
To use subterfuge, deception, or flattery for any purpose; to practice chicanery
To advocate like a pettifogger; to argue trickily; as, to pettifog a claim

pettifogger.definition: A lawyer who deals in petty cases; an attorney whose methods are mean and tricky; an inferior lawyer

pettifoggery.definition: The practice or arts of a pettifogger; disreputable tricks; quibbles; chicanery

pettifogulize.definition: To act as a pettifogger; to use contemptible tricks

pettiness.definition: The quality or state of being petty or paltry; littleness; meanness

petting.definition: Sexually titillating foreplay without contact with the genital organs
synonyms: Syn. -- caressing, cuddling, fondling, hugging, kissing, necking, smooching, snuggling.

pettish.definition: Fretful; peevish; moody; capricious; inclined to ill temper

pettitoes.definition: The toes or feet of a pig, -- often used as food; sometimes, in contempt, the human feet

petty.definition: Little; trifling; inconsiderable; unimportant; also, inferior; subordinate; as, a petty fault; petty complaints; a petty prince

pettychaps.definition: Any one of several species of small European singing birds of the subfamily Sylviinæ, as the willow warbler, the chiff-chaff, and the golden warbler (Sylvia hortensis)

pettywhin.definition: The needle furze. See under Needle

petulance.definition: The quality or state of being petulant; temporary peevishness; pettishness; capricious ill humor

petulant.definition: Capriciously fretful; characterized by ill-natured freakishness; irritable

petune.definition: To spray (tobacco) with a liquid intended to produce flavor or aroma

petunia.definition: A genus of solanaceous herbs with funnel-form or salver-shaped corollas.  Two species are common in cultivation, Petunia violacea, with reddish purple flowers, and Petunia nyctaginiflora, with white flowers. There are also many hybrid forms with variegated corollas

petunse.definition: Powdered fledspar, kaolin, or quartz, used in the manufacture of porcelain

petworth marble.definition: A kind of shell marble occurring in the Wealden clay at Petworth, in Sussex, England; -- called also Sussex marble

petzite.definition: A telluride of silver and gold, related to hessite

peucedanin.definition: A tasteless white crystalline substance, extracted from the roots of the sulphurwort (Peucedanum), masterwort (Imperatoria), and other related plants; -- called also imperatorin

peucil.definition: A liquid resembling camphene, obtained by treating turpentine hydrochloride with lime

pew.definition: One of the compartments in a church which are separated by low partitions, and have long seats upon which several persons may sit; -- sometimes called slip.  Pews were originally made square, but are now usually long and narrow
Any structure shaped like a church pew, as a stall, formerly used by money lenders, etc.; a box in theater; a pen; a sheepfold

pewee.definition: A common American tyrant flycatcher (Sayornis phœbe, or Sayornis fuscus).  Called also pewit, and phœbe

pewfellow.definition: One who occupies the same pew with another

pewter.definition: A hard, tough, but easily fusible, alloy, originally consisting of tin with a little lead, but afterwards modified by the addition of copper, antimony, or bismuth
Utensils or vessels made of pewter, as dishes, porringers, drinking vessels, tankards, pots

pewterer.definition: One whose occupation is to make utensils of pewter; a pewtersmith

pewtery.definition: Belonging to, or resembling, pewter; as, a pewtery taste

peyer's glands.definition: Patches of lymphoid nodules, in the walls of the small intestiness; agminated glands; -- called also Peyer's patches.  In typhoid fever they become the seat of ulcers which are regarded as the characteristic organic lesion of that disease

peytrel.definition: The breastplate of a horse's armor or harness. [Spelt also peitrel.] See Poitrel

peziza.definition: A genus of fungi embracing a great number of species, some of which are remarkable for their regular cuplike form and deep colors

pezizaceae.definition: A large natural family comprising many typical cup fungi

pezizales.definition: An order of mostly saprophytic fungi having cup-shaped ascocarps

pezizoid.definition: Resembling a fungus of the genus Peziza; having a cuplike form

pezophaps.definition: A genus constituted by the extinct solitaire

pfalz.definition: A territory in southwestern Germany formerly ruled by the counts palatine

pfannkuchen.definition: A puffy mildly sweet lemon-flavored egg mixture sprinkled with confectioners' sugar and served with jam or a wine or fruit sauce

pfennig.definition: A small copper coin of Germany.  It is the hundredth part of a mark.  In 2001 it was superseded by the euro

phacellus.definition: One of the filaments on the inner surface of the gastric cavity of certain jellyfishes

phacolite.definition: A colorless variety of chabazite; the original was from Leipa, in Bohemia

phacops.definition: A genus of trilobites found in the Silurian and Devonian formations. Phacops bufo is one of the most common species

phaeacian.definition: Of or pertaining to the Phæacians, a fabulous seafaring people fond of the feast, the lyre, and the dance, mentioned by Homer

phaenogam.definition: Any plant of the class Phænogamia

phaenogamia.definition: The class of flowering plants including all which have true flowers with distinct floral organs; phanerogamia

phaenogamous.definition: Having true flowers with distinct floral organs; flowering

phaeospore.definition: A brownish zoospore, characteristic of an order (Phæosporeæ) of dark green or olive-colored algæ

phaethon.definition: The son of Helios (Phœbus), that is, the son of light, or of the sun. He is fabled to have obtained permission to drive the chariot of the sun, in doing which his want of skill would have set the world on fire, had he not been struck with a thunderbolt by Jupiter, and hurled headlong into the river Po
A genus of oceanic birds including the tropic birds

phaeton.definition: A four-wheeled carriage (with or without a top), open, or having no side pieces, in front of the seat. It is drawn by one or two horses

A handsome American butterfly (Euphydryas Phaëton syn. Melitæa Phaëton). The upper side of the wings is black, with orange-red spots and marginal crescents, and several rows of cream-colored spots; -- called also Baltimore

phagedenic.definition: Of, like, or pertaining to, phagedena; used in the treatment of phagedena; as, a phagedenic ulcer or medicine

phagocyte.definition: A leucocyte which plays a part in immunity and retrogressive processes by taking up (eating), in the form of fine granules, foreign objects such as bacteria or cellular parts to be removed.  There are two principle subtypes, (1) microphages, polymorphonuclear lymphocytes which principally digest bacteria; and (2) macrophages, mononucleated cells which primarily scavenge dead tissue and degenerate cells

phainopepla.definition: A small crested passerine bird (Phaïnopepla nitens), native of Mexico and the Southern United States. The adult male is of a uniform glossy blue-black; the female is brownish. Called also black flycatcher

phakoscope.definition: An instrument for studying the mechanism of accommodation

phalaena.definition: A linnæan genus which included the moths in general

phalaenid.definition: Any moth of the family Phalænidæ, of which the cankerworms are examples; a geometrid

phalaenopsis.definition: A genus of ornamental epiphytic orchids of Asia and Australia

phalangeal.definition: Of or pertaining to the phalanges. See Phalanx, 2

phalanger.definition: Any marsupial belonging to Phalangista, Cuscus, Petaurus, and other genera of the family Phalangistidæ.  They are arboreal, and the species of Petaurus are furnished with lateral parachutes. See Flying phalanger, under Flying

phalangist.definition: Any arboreal marsupial of the genus Phalangista.  The vulpine phalangist (Phalangista vulpina) is the largest species, the full grown male being about two and a half feet long.  It has a large bushy tail

phalangite.definition: A soldier belonging to a phalanx

phalangoidea.definition: A division of Arachnoidea, including the daddy longlegs or harvestman (Phalangium) and many similar kinds.  They have long, slender, many-jointed legs; usually a rounded, segmented abdomen; and chelate jaws.  They breathe by tracheæ.  Called also Phalangides, Phalangidea, Phalangiida, and Opilionea

phalansterian.definition: One who favors the system of phalansteries proposed by Fourier

phalansterism.definition: A system of phalansteries proposed by Fourier; Fourierism

phalanstery.definition: An association or community organized on the plan of Fourier. See Fourierism
The dwelling house of a Fourierite community

phalanx.definition: A body of heavy-armed infantry formed in ranks and files close and deep.  There were several different arrangements, the phalanx varying in depth from four to twenty-five or more ranks of men
Any body of troops or men formed in close array, or any combination of people distinguished for firmness and solidity of a union
One of the digital bones of the hand or foot, beyond the metacarpus or metatarsus; an internode
A group or bundle of stamens, as in polyadelphous flowers

phalarope.definition: Any species of Phalaropus and allied genera of small wading birds (Grallæ), having lobate toes. They are often seen far from land, swimming in large flocks.  Called also sea goose

phalaropidae.definition: A natural family of birds, consisting of the phalaropes

phalaropus.definition: The type genus of the Phalaropidae: the phalaropes

phallaceae.definition: A natural family of fungi consisting of the true stinkhorns

phallales.definition: An order of fungi comprising the stinkhorns and related forms whose mature hymenium is slimy and fetid; sometimes placed in the subclass Homobasidiomycetes

phallic.definition: Of or pertaining to the phallus, or to phallism

phallism.definition: The worship of the generative principle in nature, symbolized by the phallus

phallus.definition: The emblem of the generative power in nature, carried in procession in the Bacchic orgies, or worshiped in various ways
The penis or clitoris, or the embryonic or primitive organ from which either may be derived
A genus of fungi which have a fetid and disgusting odor; the stinkhorn

phanar.definition: A quarter of Constantinople which, after the Turkish conquest of the city, became the chief Greek quarter; hence, the Greek officials of Turkey, or phanariots, as a class

phanariot.definition: One of the Greeks of Constantinople who after the Turkish conquest became powerful in clerical and other offices under Turkish patronage

phanerocodonic.definition: Having an umbrella-shaped or bell-shaped body, with a wide, open cavity beneath; -- said of certain jellyfishes

phanerocrystalline.definition: Distinctly crystalline; -- used of rocks. Opposed to cryptocrystalline

phanerogamia.definition: That one of the two primary divisions of the vegetable kingdom which contains the phanerogamic, or flowering, plants

phanerogamic.definition: Having visible flowers containing distinct stamens and pistils; -- said of plants

phaneroglossal.definition: Having a conspicious tongue; -- said of certain reptiles and insects

phantascope.definition: An optical instrument or toy, resembling the phenakistoscope, and illustrating the same principle; -- called also phantasmascope

phantasm.definition: An image formed by the mind, and supposed to be real or material; a shadowy or airy appearance; sometimes, an optical illusion; a phantom; a dream
A mental image or representation of a real object; a fancy; a notion

phantasmagoria.definition: An optical effect produced by a magic lantern.  The figures are painted in transparent colors, and all the rest of the glass is opaque black.  The screen is between the spectators and the instrument, and the figures are often made to appear as in motion, or to merge into one another
The apparatus by which such an effect is produced
Fig.: A medley of figures; illusive images

phantasmagorial.definition: Of, relating to, or resembling phantasmagoria; phantasmagoric

phantasmagoric.definition: Of or pertaining to phantasmagoria; phantasmagorial

phantasmal.definition: Pertaining to, of the nature of, or resembling, a phantasm; spectral; illusive

phantasmatography.definition: A description of celestial phenomena, as rainbows, etc

phantom.definition: That which has only an apparent existence; an apparition; a specter; a phantasm; a sprite; an airy spirit; an ideal image
Being, or of the nature of, a phantom

phantom circuit.definition: The equivalent of an additional circuit or wire, in reality not existing, obtained by certain arrangements of real circuits, as in some multiplex telegraph systems

pharaoh.definition: A title by which the sovereigns of ancient Egypt were designated

pharaonic.definition: Of or pertaining to the Pharaohs, or kings of ancient Egypt

pharisaic.definition: Of or pertaining to the Pharisees; resembling the Pharisees
Addicted to external forms and ceremonies; making a show of religion without the spirit of it; ceremonial; formal; hypocritical; self-righteous

pharisaism.definition: The notions, doctrines, and conduct of the Pharisees, as a sect
Rigid observance of external forms of religion, without genuine piety; hypocrisy in religion; a censorious, self-righteous spirit in matters of morals or manners

pharisean.definition: Following the practice of Pharisees; Pharisaic

pharisee.definition: One of a sect or party among the Jews, noted for a strict and formal observance of rites and ceremonies and of the traditions of the elders, and whose pretensions to superior sanctity led them to separate themselves from the other Jews

pharmaceutic.definition: Of or pertaining to the knowledge or art of pharmacy, or to the art of preparing medicines according to the rules or formulas of pharmacy; as, pharmaceutical preparations

pharmaceutist.definition: One skilled in pharmacy; a pharmacist; a druggist. See the Note under Apothecary

pharmacist.definition: One skilled in pharmacy; a pharmaceutist; a druggist; an apothecary

pharmacodymanics.definition: That branch of pharmacology which treats of the action and the effects of medicines in the body, and also their distribution in various bodily tissues over time, and their breakdown and excretion

pharmacognosis.definition: That branch of pharmacology which treats of unprepared medicines or simples; -- usually called pharmacognosy, and also pharmacography, and pharmacomathy

pharmacognosy.definition: The study of the distribution of, methods for finding, and properties of medically useful agents in natural sources, especially plants

pharmacolite.definition: A hydrous arsenate of lime, usually occurring in silky fibers of a white or grayish color

pharmacology.definition: The science dealing with knowledge of the preparation, use, and effects of drugs or medicines; the art of preparing medicines
A treatise on the art of preparing medicines

pharmacon.definition: A medicine or drug; also, a poison

pharmacopoeia.definition: A book or treatise describing the drugs, preparations, etc., used in medicine; especially, one that is issued by official authority and considered as an authoritative standard

pharmacopolist.definition: One who sells medicines; an apothecary

pharmacosiderite.definition: A hydrous arsenate of iron occurring in green or yellowish green cubic crystals; cube ore

pharmacy.definition: The art or practice of preparing and preserving drugs, and of compounding and dispensing medicines according to prescriptions of physicians; the occupation of an apothecary or a pharmaceutical chemist
A place where medicines are compounded; a drug store; an apothecary's shop

pharology.definition: The art or science which treats of lighthouses and signal lights

pharos.definition: A lighthouse or beacon for the guidance of seamen

pharyngeal.definition: Of or pertaining to the pharynx; in the region of the pharynx

A pharyngeal bone or cartilage; especially, one of the lower pharyngeals, which belong to the rudimentary fifth branchial arch in many fishes, or one of the upper pharyngeals, or pharyngobranchials, which are the dorsal elements in the complete branchial arches

pharyngobranchial.definition: Of or pertaining to the pharynx and the branchiæ; -- applied especially to the dorsal elements in the branchial arches of fishes. See Pharyngeal

pharyngognathi.definition: A division of fishes in which the lower pharyngeal bones are united.  It includes the scaroid, labroid, and embioticoid fishes

pharyngolaryngeal.definition: Of or pertaining both to pharynx and the larynx

pharyngopneusta.definition: A group of invertebrates including the Tunicata and Enteropneusta

pharyngotome.definition: An instrument for incising or scarifying the tonsils, etc

pharyngotomy.definition: The operation of making an incision into the pharynx, to remove a tumor or anything that obstructs the passage

pharynx.definition: The part of the alimentary canal between the cavity of the mouth and the esophagus.  It has one or two external openings through the nose in the higher vertebrates, and lateral branchial openings in fishes and some amphibias

phascolarctos.definition: A genus of animals consisting of the koalas

phascolome.definition: A marsupial of the genus Phascolomys; a wombat

phase.definition: That which is exhibited to the eye; the appearance which anything manifests, especially any one among different and varying appearances of the same object
Any appearance or aspect of an object of mental apprehension or view; as, the problem has many phases

A particular appearance or state in a regularly recurring cycle of changes with respect to quantity of illumination or form of enlightened disk; as, the phases of the moon or planets. See Illust. under Moon

Any one point or portion in a recurring series of changes, as in the changes of motion of one of the particles constituting a wave or vibration; one portion of a series of such changes, in distinction from a contrasted portion, as the portion on one side of a position of equilibrium, in contrast with that on the opposite side

A homogenous, physically distinct portion of matter in a system not homogeneous; as, the three phases, ice, water, and aqueous vapor; in a mixture of gasoline and water, the gasoline will settle as the upper phase.  A phase may be either a single chemical substance or a mixture, as of gases

In certain birds and mammals, one of two or more color variations characteristic of the species, but independent of the ordinary seasonal and sexual differences, and often also of age.  Some of the herons which appear in white and colored phases, and certain squirrels which are sometimes uniformly blackish instead of the usual coloration, furnish examples.  Color phases occur also in other animals, notably in butterflies

the relation at any instant of any cyclically varying physical quantity, such as voltage in an A.C. circuit, an electromagnetic wave, a sound wave, or a rotating object, to its initial value as expressed as a fractional part of the complete cycle. It is usually expressed in angular measure, the complete cycle being 360°.   Such periodic variations are generally well represented by sine curves; and phase relations are shown by the relative positions of the crests and hollows of such curves.  Magnitudes which have the same phase are said to be in phase

The relation at any instant of a periodically varying electric magnitude, as electro-motive force, a current, etc., to its initial value as expressed in factorial parts of the complete cycle.  It is usually expressed in angular measure, the cycle being four right angles, or 360°
To disturb the composure of; to disconcert; to nonplus; -- an older spelling, now replaced by faze

phase converter.definition: A machine for converting an alternating current into an alternating current of a different number of phases and the same frequency

phase displacement.definition: A charge of phase whereby an alternating current attains its maximum later or earlier. An inductance would cause a lag, a capacity would cause an advance, in phase

phase in.definition: To begin an activity or to incorporate new elements or replace older elements of an activity in steps, or by degrees

phase meter.definition: A device for measuring the difference in phase of two alternating currents of electromotive forces

phase out.definition: To halt (an activity) in steps, or gradually; as, to phase out use of 386-based PC's

phase rule.definition: A generalization with regard to systems of chemical equilibrium, discovered by Prof. J. Willard Gibbs.  It may be stated thus: The degree of variableness (number of degrees of freedom) of a system is equal to the number of components minus the number of phases, plus two.  Thus, if the components be salt and water, and the phases salt, ice, saturated solution, and vapor, the system is invariant, that is, there is only one set of conditions under which these four phases can exist in equilibrium.  If only three phases be considered, the system is univariant, that is, the fixing of one condition, as temperature, determines the others

phase splitter.definition: A device by which a single-phase current is split into two or more currents differing in phase. It is used in starting single-phase induction motors

phase splitting.definition: The dephasing of the two parts of a single alternating current in two dissimilar branches of a given circuit

phasel.definition: The French bean, or kidney bean

phaseless.definition: Without a phase, or visible form

phaseolus.definition: A genus of leguminous plants, including the Lima bean, the kidney bean, the scarlet runner, etc. See Bean

phasianidae.definition: A natural family of fowl including the pheasants, quails, and partridges

phasianus.definition: The type genus of the Phasianidae: the typical pheasants

phasing.definition: Pertaining to phase or differences of phase

phasing current.definition: The momentary current between two alternating-current generators when juxtaposed in parallel and not agreeing exactly in phase or period

phasing transformer.definition: Any of several transformers (there must be at least two) for changing phase

phasm.definition: An apparition; a phantom; an appearance

phasmatidae.definition: A natural family consisting of the stick insects
synonyms: Syn. -- Phasmidae, family Phasmidae, family Phasmatidae.

phasmatodea.definition: in some classifications considered a suborder of Orthoptera: stick insects; leaf insects
synonyms: Syn. -- Phasmida, order Phasmida, order Phasmatodea.

phasmid.definition: Any orthopterous insect of the family Phasmidæ, as a leaf insect or a stick insect

synonyms: Syn. -- family Phasmidae, Phasmatidae, family Phasmatidae.

phasmidia.definition: One of two subgroups of Nematoda used in some classification systems

phassachate.definition: The lead-colored agate; -- so called in reference to its color

phatagin.definition: The long-tailed pangolin (Manis tetradactyla); -- called also ipi

phd.definition: A scholastic degree awarded for study beyond college; the Doctorate degree in Philosophy.  In America it is usually based on at least 3 years graduate study and a dissertation; the doctorate is the highest degree awarded by a graduate school, and is awarded in other fields, such as Doctor of Arts.  The Ph.D. is broadly applicable, as in most fields of science and technology; -- the term philosophy being derived from an earlier label for experimental science as Natural Philosophy

pheasant.definition: Any one of numerous species of large gallinaceous birds of the genus Phasianus, and many other genera of the family Phasianidæ, found chiefly in Asia

pheasantry.definition: A place for keeping and rearing pheasants

pheese.definition: To comb; also, to beat; to worry

phelloderm.definition: A layer of green parenchymatous cells formed on the inner side of the phellogen

phellogen.definition: The tissue of young cells which produces cork cells

phenacetin.definition: A white, crystalline compound, C10H13O2N, once used in medicine principally as an antipyretic.  It is now seldom used because of serious side effects
synonyms: Syn. -- N-(4-ethoxyphenyl)acetamide, p-acetophenetidide, p-ethoxyacetanilide, acetophenetidin, para-acetphenetidin, p-acetophenetide.

phenacite.definition: A glassy colorless mineral occurring in rhombohedral crystals, sometimes used as a gem.  It is a silicate of glucina, and receives its name from its deceptive similarity to quartz

phenakistoscope.definition: A revolving disk on which figures drawn in different relative attitudes are seen successively, so as to produce the appearance of an object in actual motion, as an animal leaping, etc., in consequence of the persistence of the successive visual impressions of the retina.  It is often arranged so that the figures may be projected upon a screen

phenalgin.definition: An ammoniated compound of phenyl and acetamide, used as an analgesic and antipyretic.  It resembles phenacetin in its therapeutic action

phenanthrene.definition: A complex hydrocarbon, C14H10, found in coal tar, and obtained as a white crystalline substance with a bluish fluorescence

phenanthridine.definition: A nitrogenous hydrocarbon base, C13H9N, analogous to phenanthrene and quinoline

phenanthroline.definition: Either of two metameric nitrogenous hydrocarbon bases, C12H8N2, analogous to phenanthridine, but more highly nitrogenized

phenetol.definition: The ethyl ether of phenol, obtained as an aromatic liquid, C6H5.O.C2H5

phenic.definition: Of, pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, phenyl or phenol

phenicine.definition: A purple powder precipitated when a sulphuric solution of indigo is diluted with water

phenicious.definition: Of a red color with a slight mixture of gray

phenix.definition: A bird fabled to exist single, to be consumed by fire by its own act, and to rise again from its ashes.  Hence, an emblem of immortality
A person or thing that suffered destruction or defeat and was restored to its former state

phenocryst.definition: One of the prominent embedded crystals of a porphyry

phenol.definition: A white or pinkish crystalline substance, C6H5OH, produced by the destructive distillation of many organic bodies, as wood, coal, etc., and obtained from the heavy oil from coal tar
Any one of the series of hydroxyl derivatives of which phenol proper is the type

phenolate.definition: A compound of phenol analogous to a salt

phenology.definition: The science of the relations between climate and periodic biological phenomena, as the migrations and breeding of birds, the flowering and fruiting of plants, etc

phenolphthalein.definition: A white or yellowish white crystalline substance, C20H14O4, formed by condensation of the anhydride of phthalic acid and phenol. Its solution in alkalies is brilliant red, but is decolorized by acids.  This reaction, being very delicate, is used as a pH indicator.  It is sometimes used as a laxative in veterinary medicine

phenomenal.definition: Relating to, or of the nature of, a phenomenon; hence, extraordinary; wonderful; as, a phenomenal memory

phenomenalism.definition: That theory which limits positive or scientific knowledge to phenomena only, whether material or spiritual

phenomenist.definition: One who believes in the theory of phenomenalism

phenomenology.definition: A description, history, or explanation of phenomena

phenomenon.definition: An appearance; anything visible; whatever, in matter or spirit, is apparent to, or is apprehended by, observation; as, the phenomena of heat, light, or electricity; phenomena of imagination or memory
That which strikes one as strange, unusual, or unaccountable; an extraordinary or very remarkable person, thing, or occurrence; as, a musical phenomenon

phenose.definition: A sweet amorphous deliquescent substance obtained indirectly from benzene, and isometric with, and resembling, dextrose

phenotype.definition: The observable characteristics of an organism, resulting from the genetic characteristics influenced by a particular environment.   Contrasted with genotype

phenotypic.definition: Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of a phenotype; as, phenotypic profile.   Contrasted with genotypic

phenyl.definition: A hydrocarbon radical (C6H5) regarded as the essential residue of benzene, and the basis of an immense number of aromatic derivatives

phenylacetamide.definition: A white crystalline compound used as an analgesic and also as an antipyretic

phenylamine.definition: Any one of certain class of organic bases regarded as formed from ammonia by the substitution of phenyl for hydrogen

phenylene.definition: A hypothetic radical (C6H4) occurring in certain derivatives of benzene; as, phenylene diamine

phenylic.definition: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, phenyl

pheon.definition: A bearing representing the head of a dart or javelin, with long barbs which are engrailed on the inner edge

phial.definition: A glass vessel or bottle, especially a small bottle for medicines; a vial
To put or keep in, or as in, a phial

philadelphia lawyer.definition: A lawyer knowledgeable about the most detailed and minute points of law, especially one with an exceptional propensity and ability to exploit fine technical points of law for the client's advantage

philadelphian.definition: Of or pertaining to Ptolemy Philadelphus, or to one of the cities named Philadelphia, esp. the modern city in Pennsylvania
A native or an inhabitant of Philadelphia
One of a society of mystics of the seventeenth century, -- called also the Family of Love

philadelphus.definition: Any of various chiefly deciduous ornamental shrubs of the genus Philadelphus having white sweet-scented flowers, single or in clusters; it is widely grown in temperate regions

philander.definition: To make love to women; to play the male flirt

philanderer.definition: One who hangs about women; a male flirt

philanthropic.definition: Of or pertaining to philanthropy; characterized by philanthropy; loving or helping mankind; as, a philanthropic enterprise

philanthropinism.definition: A system of education on so-called natural principles, attempted in Germany in the last century by Basedow, of Dessau

philanthropinist.definition: An advocate of, or believer in, philanthropinism

philanthropist.definition: One who practices philanthropy; one who loves mankind, and seeks to promote the good of others; especially, a wealthy individual who donates large amounts of money to charitable or philanthropic causes.  Opposite of misanthrope

philanthropistic.definition: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, a philanthropist

philanthropy.definition: Love to mankind; benevolence toward the whole human family; universal good will; desire and readiness to do good to all men; -- opposed to misanthropy
An active effort to promote human welfare; humanitarian activity.  in this sense, it is an action, not merely a state of mind

An organization whose purpose is to engage in philanthropy(2), and is supported by funds from one or a small number of wealthy individuals; a type of charity, the source of whose funds is typically from a wealthy individual or a corporation, or a trust fund established by a wealthy individual.  It is distinguished from other charitable organizations in that the source of funds of other charities may come from a large number of sources, or from public solicitation

philatelist.definition: One versed in philately; one who collects postage stamps, as a hobby or for investment; a stamp collector

philately.definition: The collection of postage stamps of various issues

philathea.definition: An international, interdenominational organization of Bible classes of young women

philatory.definition: A kind of transparent reliquary with an ornamental top

philharmonic.definition: One who loves harmony or music

philhellene.definition: A friend of Greece, or of the Greeks; a philhellenist

philhellenist.definition: A friend of Greece; one who supports the cause of the Greeks; particularly, one who supported them in their struggle for independence against the Turks; a philhellene

philippian.definition: Of or pertaining to Philippi, a city of ancient Macedonia

philippic.definition: Any one of the series of famous orations of Demosthenes, the Grecian orator, denouncing Philip, king of Macedon
Hence: Any discourse or declamation abounding in acrimonious invective

philippine.definition: The official language of the Philippines,  based on Tagalog; it draws its lexicon from other Philippine languages

philippines.definition: An East Asian country occupying the Phillipine Islands
An archipelago off the eastern coast of Asia

philippium.definition: A rare and doubtful metallic element said to have been discovered in the mineral samarskite

philippize.definition: To support or advocate the cause of Philip of Macedon
To write or speak in the style of a philippic

philister.definition: A Philistine; -- a cant name given to townsmen by students in German universities

philistine.definition: A native or an inhabitant of ancient Philistia, a coast region of southern Palestine
A person deficient in liberal culture and refinement; one without appreciation of the nobler aspirations and sentiments of humanity; one whose scope is limited to selfish and material interests
Of or pertaining to the Philistines

philistinism.definition: The condition, character, aims, and habits of the class called Philistines. See Philistine, 3

phillipsite.definition: A hydrous silicate of aluminia, lime, and soda, a zeolitic mineral commonly occurring in complex twin crystals, often cruciform in shape; -- called also christianite

phillygenin.definition: A pearly crystalline substance obtained by the decomposition of phillyrin

phillyrea.definition: A genus of evergreen plants growing along the shores of the Mediterranean, and bearing a fruit resembling that of the olive

phillyrin.definition: A glucoside extracted from Phillyrea as a bitter white crystalline substance. It is sometimes used as a febrifuge

philo-.definition: A combining form from Gr. fi`los loving, fond of, attached to; as, philosophy, philotechnic

philogynist.definition: A lover or friend of women; one who esteems woman as the higher type of humanity; -- opposed to misogynist

philogyny.definition: Fondness for women; uxoriousness; -- opposed to misogyny

philologize.definition: To study, or make critical comments on, language

philology.definition: The study of language, especially in a philosophical manner and as a science; the investigation of the laws of human speech, the relation of different tongues to one another, and historical development of languages; linguistic science
A treatise on the science of language

philomath.definition: A lover of learning; a scholar

philomathic.definition: Having love of learning or letters

philomathy.definition: The love of learning or letters

philomela.definition: A genus of birds including the nightingales

philomot.definition: Of the color of a dead leaf

philopena.definition: A present or gift which is made as a forfeit in a social game that is played in various ways; also, the game itself

philoprogenitive.definition: Having the love of offspring; fond of children

philoprogenitiveness.definition: The love of offspring; fondness for children

philosophate.definition: To play the philosopher; to moralize

philosopheme.definition: A philosophical proposition, doctrine, or principle of reasoning

philosopher.definition: One who philosophizes; one versed in, or devoted to, philosophy
One who reduces the principles of philosophy to practice in the conduct of life; one who lives according to the rules of practical wisdom; one who meets or regards all vicissitudes with calmness

philosophic.definition: Of or pertaining to philosophy; versed in, or imbued with, the principles of philosophy; hence, characterizing a philosopher; rational; wise; temperate; calm; cool

philosophism.definition: Spurious philosophy; the love or practice of sophistry

philosophistic.definition: Of or pertaining to the love or practice of sophistry

philosophize.definition: To reason like a philosopher; to search into the reason and nature of things; to investigate phenomena, and assign rational causes for their existence

philosophy.definition: Literally, the love of, inducing the search after, wisdom; in actual usage, the knowledge of phenomena as explained by, and resolved into, causes and reasons, powers and laws
A particular philosophical system or theory; the hypothesis by which particular phenomena are explained
Practical wisdom; calmness of temper and judgment; equanimity; fortitude; stoicism; as, to meet misfortune with philosophy
The course of sciences read in the schools

philostorgy.definition: Natural affection, as of parents for their children

philter.definition: A potion or charm intended to excite the passion of love
To impregnate or mix with a love potion; as, to philter a draught
To charm to love; to excite to love or sexual desire by a potion

phimosis.definition: A condition of the penis in which the prepuce can not be drawn back so as to uncover the glans penis

phlebogram.definition: A tracing (with the sphygmograph) of the movements of a vein, or of the venous pulse

phlebolite.definition: A small calcareous concretion formed in a vein; a vein stone

phlebology.definition: A branch of anatomy which treats of the veins

phlebotomize.definition: To let blood from by opening a vein; to bleed

phlebotomus.definition: A mild viral disease transmitted by the bite of the sand fly Phlebotomus papatasii
A genus of small blood-sucking mothlike sand flies

phlebotomy.definition: The act or practice of opening a vein for letting blood, in the treatment of disease; venesection; bloodletting

phlegethon.definition: One of the principal rivers of Hades, in the channel of which fire flowed instead of water

phlegm.definition: One of the four humors of which the ancients supposed the blood to be composed. See Humor
Viscid mucus secreted in abnormal quantity in the respiratory and digestive passages
A watery distilled liquor, in distinction from a spirituous liquor
Sluggishness of temperament; dullness; want of interest; indifference; coldness

phlegmagogue.definition: A medicine supposed to expel phlegm

phlegmasia.definition: An inflammation; more particularly, an inflammation of the internal organs

phlegmatic.definition: Abounding in phlegm; as, phlegmatic humors; a phlegmatic constitution
Not easily excited to action or passion; cold; dull; sluggish; heavy; as, a phlegmatic person

phlegmon.definition: Purulent inflammation of the cellular or areolar tissue

phlegmonous.definition: Having the nature or properties of phlegmon; as, phlegmonous pneumonia

phleum.definition: A genus of grasses, including the timothy (Phleum pratense), which is highly valued for hay; cat's-tail grass

phloem.definition: That portion of fibrovascular bundles which corresponds to the inner bark; the liber tissue; -- distinguished from xylem

phlogistian.definition: A believer in the existence of phlogiston

phlogistic.definition: Of or pertaining to phlogiston, or to belief in its existence
Inflammatory; belonging to inflammations and fevers

phlogisticate.definition: To combine phlogiston with; -- usually in the form and sense of the p. p. or the adj.; as, highly phlogisticated substances

phlogistication.definition: The act or process of combining with phlogiston

phlogiston.definition: The former hypothetical principle of fire, or inflammability, regarded by Stahl as a chemical element; it is now known to be nonexistent

phlogopite.definition: A kind of mica having generally a peculiar bronze-red or copperlike color and a pearly luster.  It is a silicate of aluminia, with magnesia, potash, and some fluorine.  It is characteristic of crystalline limestone or dolomite and serpentine.  See Mica

phlogosis.definition: Inflammation of external parts of the body; erysipelatous inflammation

phloramine.definition: A basic amido derivative of phloroglucin, having an astringent taste

phloretic.definition: Pertaining to, or derived from, or designating, an organic acid obtained by the decomposition of phloretin

phloretin.definition: A bitter white crystalline substance obtained by the decomposition of phlorizin, and formerly used to some extent as a substitute for quinine

phlorizin.definition: A bitter white crystalline glucoside extracted from the root bark of the apple, pear, cherry, plum, etc

phloroglucin.definition: A sweet white crystalline substance, metameric with pyrogallol, and obtained by the decomposition of phloretin, and from certain gums, as catechu, kino, etc.  It belongs to the class of phenols. [Called also phloroglucinol.]

phlorol.definition: A liquid metameric with xylenol, belonging to the class of phenols, and obtained by distilling certain salts of phloretic acid

phlorone.definition: A yellow crystalline substance having a peculiar unpleasant odor, resembling the quinones, and obtained from beechwood tar and coal tar, as also by the oxidation of xylidine; -- called also xyloquinone

phlox.definition: A genus of American herbs, having showy red, white, or purple flowers

phlyctenular.definition: Characterized by the presence of small pustules, or whitish elevations resembling pustules; as, phlyctenular ophthalmia

phobia.definition: Any irrational and persistent fear, whether of a situation, activity, or object;  a phobia typically leads to a strong desire to avoid the object of the phobia

phobic.definition: A person suffering from a phobia

phobophobia.definition: A morbid fear of developing a phobia

phoca.definition: A genus of seals. It includes the common harbor seal and allied species. See Seal

phocacean.definition: Any species of Phoca; a seal

phocenic.definition: Of or pertaining to dolphin oil or porpoise oil; -- said of an acid (called also delphinic acid) subsequently found to be identical with valeric acid

phocine.definition: Of or pertaining to the seal tribe; phocal

phocodontia.definition: A group of extinct carnivorous whales.  Their teeth had compressed and serrated crowns.  It includes Squalodon and allied genera

phoenicopterus.definition: A genus of birds which includes the flamingoes

phoenicurus.definition: A genus of Old World thrushes

phoenix.definition: A genus of palms including the date tree

pholas.definition: Any one of numerous species of marine bivalve mollusks of the genus Pholas, or family Pholadidæ.  They bore holes for themselves in clay, peat, and soft rocks

pholistoma.definition: A genus of straggling herbs of the southwestern U.S

phonal.definition: Of or relating to the voice; as, phonal structure

phonascetics.definition: Treatment for restoring or improving the voice

phonation.definition: The act or process by which articulate sounds are uttered; the utterance of articulate sounds; articulate speech

phonautograph.definition: An instrument by means of which a sound can be made to produce a visible trace or record of itself.  It consists essentially of a resonant vessel, usually of paraboloidal form, closed at one end by a flexible membrane.  A stylus attached to some point of the membrane records the movements of the latter, as it vibrates, upon a moving cylinder or plate

phone.definition: An instrument that converts sound into signals that can be transmitted over distances and then converts received signals back into sounds; a telephone; as, I talked to him on the phone
An individual sound unit of speech without concern as to whether or not it is a phoneme of some language.  A speech sound
A device for converting electric signals into sounds; it is held over or inserted into the ear
To get or try to get into communication with, using a telephone; as, I phoned him this morning
synonyms: Syn. -- call, telephone, call up, ring.

phone-in.definition: A radio or telephone program, or part of a program, during which the audience participates by telephone

phoneidoscope.definition: An instrument for studying the motions of sounding bodies by optical means.  It consists of a tube across the end of which is stretched a film of soap solution thin enough to give colored bands, the form and position of which are affected by sonorous vibrations

phoneme.definition: One of a small set of speech sounds that are used by and distinguished by the speakers of a particular language.  They are combined into morphemes, words, and sentences

phonemic.definition: Of or pertaining to a phoneme; as, phonemic analysis

phonemics.definition: The study of the sound system of a given language and the analysis and classification of its phonemes

phonetic.definition: Of or pertaining to the voice, or its use
Representing sounds; as, phonetic characters; -- opposed to ideographic; as, a phonetic notation

phonetician.definition: One versed in phonetics; a phonetist

phonetics.definition: The doctrine or science of sounds; especially those of the human voice; phonology
The art of representing vocal sounds by signs and written characters

phonetism.definition: The science which treats of vocal sounds

phonetist.definition: One versed in phonetics; a phonologist
One who advocates a phonetic spelling

phonetization.definition: The act, art, or process of representing sounds by phonetic signs

phoney.definition: Imitating something superior; intended to deceive; fraudulent; having a misleading appearance; not genuine; false; counterfeit; fake; as, a phoney diamond; a phoney hundred-dollar bill
synonyms: Syn. -- bogus, counterfeit, fake, ersatz; fraudulent; false.

phoney.definition: Pretending to be other than one is; putting on false appearances; insincere; hypocritical; -- of people
Something or someone that is phoney

phonic.definition: Of or pertaining to sound; of the nature of sound; acoustic

phonics.definition: A method of teaching reading and spelling to beginning students, emphasizing the sound values of individual letters and syllables, and the relationship between pronunciation and spelling.  Contrasted to whole language method and sentence method

phono.definition: A South American butterfly (Ithonia phono) having nearly transparent wings

phono-.definition: A combining form from Gr. fwnh` sound, tone; as, phonograph, phonology

phonogram.definition: A letter, character, or mark used to represent a particular sound
A record of sounds made by a phonograph

phonogramic.definition: Of or pertaining to a phonogram

phonograph.definition: A character or symbol used to represent a sound, esp. one used in phonography

An instrument for the mechanical registration and reproduction of audible sounds, as articulate speech, etc. An early simple version consisted of a rotating cylinder or disk covered with some material easily indented, as tinfoil, wax, paraffin, etc., above which is a thin plate carrying a stylus.  As the plate vibrates under the influence of a sound, the stylus makes minute indentations or undulations in the soft material, and these, when the cylinder or disk is again turned, set the plate in vibration, and reproduce the sound.  Modern versions use electronic circuitry and various more stable recording media to record sound more accurately

An instrument for reproducing sounds, especially music,  previously recorded on a plastic cylinder or disk as a pattern of bumps or wiggles in a groove.  A needle (stylus) held in the groove is made to vibrate by motion (rotation) of the recording, and the vibrations caused by the bumps and wiggles are transmitted directly to a membrane, or first transduced into electrical impulses and sent to an electronic amplifier circuit, thereby reproducing with greater or less fidelity the original sounds.  A phonograph which is equipped with electronics enabling the playback of sound with high fidelity to the original is often called a hi-fi

phonographer.definition: One versed or skilled in phonography
One who uses, or is skilled in the use of, the phonograph. See Phonograph, 2

phonographic.definition: Of or pertaining to phonography; based upon phonography
Of or pertaining to phonograph; done by the phonograph

phonographically.definition: In a phonographic manner; by means of phonograph

phonography.definition: A description of the laws of the human voice, or sounds uttered by the organs of speech
A representation of sounds by distinctive characters; commonly, a system of shorthand writing invented by Isaac Pitman, or a modification of his system, much used by reporters
The art of constructing, or using, the phonograph

phonolite.definition: A compact, feldspathic, igneous rock containing nephelite, haüynite, etc.  Thin slabs give a ringing sound when struck; -- called also clinkstone

phonology.definition: The science or doctrine of the elementary sounds uttered by the human voice in speech, including the various distinctions, modifications, and combinations of tones; phonetics. Also, a treatise on sounds

phonometer.definition: An instrument for measuring sounds, as to their intensity, or the frequency of the vibrations

phonomotor.definition: An instrument in which motion is produced by the vibrations of a sounding body

phonoscope.definition: An instrument for observing or exhibiting the motions or properties of sounding bodies; especially, an apparatus invented by König for testing the quality of musical strings

phonotype.definition: A type or character used in phonotypy

phonotypic.definition: Of or pertaining to phonotypy; as, a phonotypic alphabet
